column2: LEAD: A quotation in the front-page index last Sunday was misattributed. It was the interviewer - not Yuri A. Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief - who noted that for Soviet politicians, ''to be a Communist is a minus, and to be a Communist Party functionary is a huge minus.''

LEAD: What is it about Joan of Arc that frustrates the efforts of opera composers to bring her to life? At least two dozen musical versions of this promising subject exist, but none has established itself in the repertory. There is no Joan to compare even remotely with adored heroines like Mimi, Violetta, Tatiana or the many other mistreated women who lead vivid stage existences.

LEAD: If Coach Valvano had spent more time admiring the blue Carolina sky with his players instead of chasing the green American dollar, he would have developed a more solid and trustworthy relationship with his young men.

LEAD: CONNECTIONS TO THE WORLD: The Basic Concepts of Philosophy, by Arthur C. Danto. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) In a recasting of his book ''What Philosophy Is,'' Arthur C. Danto now proposes that it can be thought of as ''the effort to understand the relationships between subjects, representations, and reality.

LEAD: The engagement of Grace Elizabeth Gray to Benjamin Hill White has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. William B. Gray of New York. Mr. White is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David White of Eugene, Ore. The future bride is also a daughter of the late Reverend Gray. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: ARGENTINA has become ridiculously cheap for travelers with dollars, and the elegant old mountain city of Cordoba is one of the greatest values. But $20 first-class hotel suites and $10 three-course meals with wine can't last forever in a place that gives such good quality, so if you want to see the other Argentina, the Argentina beyond Buenos

LEAD: In the indigo moment before the sun rises and the night is not yet gone, the vast lava plain that lies at the foot of the Lost River Range in eastern Idaho reveals itself - raw, empty, magnetic. In July, the wind blows hot, and dust rakes the brush and fills the gullies. In February, the sky turns deep blue, and blinding snow robes the western summits and chokes the craggy canyons.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Buried in a mountain range deep in the Arctic Circle and completed in 40-below weather, critical sections of the nation's main oil pipeline are corroding and will require years of costly repair work.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. William I. Rosenblum of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Claire Helen Rosenblum to Oren M. Cohen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Cohen of New York. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: HIGHER THAN HOPE The Authorized Biography of Nelson Mandela. By Fatima Meer. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: ENROLLMENT for the current semester at Norwalk Community is 10 percent higher than last spring, one of the most dramatic increases in the school's history. And with a planned move to new quarters on Richards Avenue that would more than double its space to 122,000 square feet, the college was looking forward to even more growth.

LEAD: Bridgeport, Conn. $160,000 5350 Park Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old tri-level frame home; in-law apartment, newly carpeted; taxes $3,355. Trumbull, Conn. $247,500 11 Thorburn Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; flagstone patio, 1-car garage, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,191.

LEAD: Pamela Jennifer Macleod and James Leon Daigle 4th plan to marry in May. Ms. Macleod, 29 years old, is the daughter of Jennifer S. Macleod of Princeton Junction, N.J., and John A. Macleod of Clearwater, Fla. Mr. Daigle, 28, is a son of Beverly V. DeLaney of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and Mr. Daigle 3d of Bowie,

LEAD: LONDON, for all its reputation as a world capital, used to be an early closing town. Few restaurants took orders after 9 o'clock and, as for late-night bars and cafes, you could pretty much forget anything public - or legal. For theatergoers the alternatives were eat early or not at all. All that has changed in the last few years.
LEAD: With a sweep of her hand, Charlene Moats traces the cycle of devastation and renewal that has changed the face of her Bronx neighborhood.

LEAD: Empty-headed pop music usually comes in the form of sleek, high-tech disco or pounding, three-chord rock. But the Church, an Australian quartet that has just released its seventh album, ''Gold Afternoon Fix'' (Arista AL-8579; all three formats) makes lightweight pop of a different sort. Instead of disco's synthetic tracks and drum machines, or commercial rock's tired riffs and cliched baby-I-love-you lyrics, the Church combines 12-string guitar, bass and drums with dreamy images to make an elegant surface of sound.
LEAD: TThe omens seemed right tonight for the Islanders to end their dual streaks of 5 consecutive defeats and 11 games without a victory.

LEAD: President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala has failed to move against a surge of killings, abductions and torture perpetrated by the army, according to a report released this week by Americas Watch, an independent human rights group.
LEAD: On Horseback in Alaska

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grodd of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Debra Lynn Grodd and Stanley George Lee, the son of Jane Shedlin of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Stanley Lee. He is the stepson of Edward Shedlin.
LEAD: Checking Out Cholesterol
LEAD: A GENERATION LOST China Under the Cultural Revolution. By Zi-ping Luo. 342 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $22.50.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.

LEAD: Leslie Ann Mills and Peter Clark Santos were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., by the Rev. Douglas S. Phillips. Mrs. Santos is the daughter of R. Jeffries Mills Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Jo Ann Yow Mills. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Santos of Long Meadow, Mass.

LEAD: The marriage of Jennifer M. Hyams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Hyams of Jericho, L.I., to Scott B. Prizer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Prizer of East Hills, L.I., took place last evening at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson and Cantor Stephen Dubov officiated. Mrs. Prizer, 26 years old, is a product manager at the Williamsburgh Savings Bank in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Six months after the first major battle of the so-called Font Wars, the smoke is starting to clear. One camp is led by Adobe Inc., which once had a virtual monopoly on outline fonts, the typography that is stored as mathematical formulas rather than as images formed by a collection of dots. The other camp is led by Apple Computer Inc.

LEAD: Gia Costa and Bruce Newman, a senior writer at Sports Illustrated in New York, were married yesterday at the Highlands Inn in Carmel, Calif., by the Rev. Garth Van Nest, a Unitarian minister. Mrs. Newman, 23 years old, graduated in December from Arizona State University. She is a daughter of Marilyn Costa of Verdi, Nev., and the late Sam Costa.

LEAD: EVEN an hour of home improvement activities involving lifting can cause a sore back or even an injury that lasts for days or longer. Back muscles are among the body's weakest, and sedentary living causes the backs of many adults to be out of condition.

LEAD: A correspondent for a British newspaper has been sentenced to death in Iraq after being convicted of espionage, and a British nurse has been sentenced to 15 years in prison on charges of helping him, the Foreign Office said today.

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 2 7 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgitesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 2 1 3 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life, as depicted in verse and pictures.
LEAD: In a city known for racial politics, no elected official speaks in stronger and more hostile terms than Representative Gus Savage.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently returned from an unusual adventure in the Basque country, sponsored by Backroads International. It was a two-week tour through the Spanish and French Basque country, conducted by Jim Beterbide, an American who now lives in Bilbao. He imparted fresh, interesting information.
LEAD: TO Louise Caputo, when the wind is just right, blowing in from the north, the noises fly through the sky like an airborne invasion.

LEAD: A New work by Erick Hawkins is not an ordinary event, simply because Mr. Hawkins is not an ordinary choreographer. For decades, he has, with integrity, stood apart from the mainstream of other contemporary dance. It is a choice, one suspects, imposed less by will than by necessity. To see Hawkins choreography is to have the sensation that it could have taken no other form, that any departure from Mr.

LEAD: Most Americans over age 10 still remember those dramatic televised reports. It was only 12 weeks ago that U.S. troops invaded Panama, in the largest military operation since the Vietnam War. President Bush's political stock soared when the assault brought the capture and removal to Miami of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega,

LEAD: If Oliver L. North and John M. Poindexter ever get together to swap stories about the Iran-contra affair, it may be a bit like a duet of ''Yes, I Remember It Well.'' Mr. North, testifying for the prosecution last week in Mr. Poindexter's trial, shared recollections that were at odds with what Mr. Poindexter has said under oath.

LEAD: Two photographs with the Architecture View in the Arts and Leisure section on Feb. 25 were not credited. The photographs, which depicted drawings by Louis Kahn at the Yale University Art Gallery, should have been credited to the Louis I. Kahn Collection, University of Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission.

LEAD: ''SILENCE of everybody secures the rest of all. Thank you not to forget it.'' So reads the English version of the rather stern French and German admonitions posted in the hallways of Le Chalet, a charming country inn four miles from Moulins, a market town of 25,000 in the Auvergne region.

LEAD: ''Do you have the new Rickie Lee Jones record?'' a house guest recently asked Ronald Prince. ''Sure,'' Mr. Prince remembers saying, pulling out a compact disk. ''How about Janet Jackson's 'Rhythm Nation?' '' the guest asked later.
LEAD: First, the good news.

LEAD: Concerned about tensions between the United States and Japan, a group of former officials of both nations was reported today to be planning a conference on mutual problems that is to be attended by several former American Presidents and Japanese Prime Ministers.

LEAD: ''Be about 20 minutes'' could be Michael Baron's break into stardom. Mr. Baron, a sophomore theater arts major at Wake Forest University, will say the line in the film ''Mr. Destiny,'' in which he will play a pizza-parlor worker who takes an order from Jim Belushi.

LEAD: East Williston $267,000 210 Auburn Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, attic, porch, 1-car attached garage; taxes $4,100. Levittown $135,000 28 Jester Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, screened porch, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300.
LEAD: While snow and freezing temperatures still threaten outside, work inside greenhouses and nurseries around the state is at a feverish pace in preparation for the spring season, the busiest.

LEAD: Congressional Republicans did everything but tie yellow ribbons around the Capitol pillars last week in welcoming Richard M. Nixon back to Washington. The former President drew cheers from House Republicans who gathered to hear him deliver a lecture on foreign affairs. Then there were photo opportunities, a news conference and good cheer all around.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In the 80's, we were asked to feel sorry for the homeless. In the 90's, we are asked to feel sorry for the people who share much of the blame for putting the homeless on the street. I have in mind those who, through frenzied real-estate speculation, have sent the value of New York City apartments soaring and who are only now beginning to pay fair property taxes based on those outrageous levels.

LEAD: For years, my siblings and I struggled with our parents' marriage problems, trying to provide support and keep them together. Finally, after seven years, they divorced and sold the family home. Both remarried. At my father's wedding, I gave a toast. I said that his wedding day was the last day of a job for me - a job that I was happy to hand over to his new wife.

LEAD: In the rapidly gentrifying area of north London known as Islington, age-old pubs with names like the Slug and Lettuce vie for patronage with newly glamorized restaurants. Drunks inhabit the main thoroughfare, Upper Street, buttonholing for money the recently arrived yuppies, who are drawn to the area because of its proximity to London's financial center, the City.

LEAD: About 9 o'clock one morning shortly after Paul Tagliabue moved into the commissioner's office at National Football League headquarters, a club owner phoned. After a brief conversation with one of Tagliabue's aides, the club owner, accustomed to Pete Rozelle's habit of arriving closer to 10 o'clock, left a message for ''when the commissioner gets in.

LEAD: As a teen-ager growing up in Washington, Ozey Thorpe remembers that it was not always easy finding men's clothing that complemented his 6-foot-6-inch frame. ''I used to tinker a lot with sewing machines as a kid,'' Mr. Thorpe said. ''That way, I was able to do my own alterations.''

LEAD: ''I hear America singing,'' wrote Walt Whitman in the last century. Today, he would have difficulty hearing himself think. According to audiologists, 20 million Americans are exposed daily to persistent noise loud enough to cause hearing loss. The racket also contributes to high blood pressure, peptic ulcers, aggression, poor reading, lack of consideration and, understandably, the urge to give up.

LEAD: The Jan. 21 article ''Enrollment Slips at Many Private Schools'' is certainly thought-provoking. But it surprises me that a plausible contributory reason for the decline in private-school matriculation has been overlooked. I am referring to the fact that the overall quality to education in the public school systems of New

LEAD: The engagement of Marcia Elaine Cleveland to Mark Thomas Green, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Green of New York and St. Paul, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Carolyn Cleveland of Greenwich, Conn., and Robert W. Cleveland Jr. of North Palm Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Sternick of Cranford, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Jane K. Sternick, and Patrick J. Hitchcock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Hitchcock Jr. of San Mateo, Calif. Miss Sternick, 24 years old, is an economic analyst for the California Bankers Clearing House Association in San Francisco.

LEAD: Britain is pressing the Bush Administration to pay most of the cost of caring for the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people now being housed in its colony of Hong Kong, as well as for building a new refugee camp, possibly on Guam, diplomats and United Nations officials here say.

LEAD: Washington is not without literary tradition, of course, but when a member of Congress writes a book that somehow makes money, it is often suspected that something unseemly has transpired. Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, raised such suspicions about a book written by former House Speaker Jim Wright, who resigned last year after a House ethics panel found improprieties in connection with his book sales.

LEAD: Exhibitions, like plays and films, are rarely without their headliners and supporting players. And in the case of ''The Golden Age of Dutch Manuscript Painting,'' at the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan through May 6, top billing goes, hands down, to the tiny paintings in a Book of Hours from the middle of the 15th century that belonged to Catherine of

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Charles T. Goodsell of Blacksburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Holly Delight Goodsell to Gary Kevin Fechtmeyer, a son of Mrs. Bernard Potof of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Gary P. Fechtmeyer of Minneapolis. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: If John Gotti is innocent, Jim Valvano is Mother Theresa. NORMAN KLINE Larchmont, N.Y.

LEAD: It has been a year since the Merce Cunningham Dance Company last appeared in New York City. In that time, Mr. Cunningham has toured with his dancers to England, Italy, France and Germany, and from coast to coast in the United States. He has taught class regularly, conducted workshops and choreographed and rehearsed three pieces that will be performed at City Center during a two-week season that opens on Tuesday.

LEAD: Jill Trenary's long climb to the highest level of figure skating ended today when she won the women's title of the world figure-skating championships. The way it happened, though, provided little proof she is the best skater in the world.

LEAD: St. Luke's United Methodist Church in Houston was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Dawn Alane Lee and Brett Alfred Smith. The Rev. Dr. Mark Lewis performed the ceremony. Karen L. Carter was the maid of honor and the Rev. William Bramlett Smith was his brother's best man. Attendants included Daryn Rae Lee, Debra Jeanne Lee and Dana Lynne Lee, the bride's sisters, and her brother, Douglas Brent

LEAD: Russell Fox Hodges of Rosemont, Pa., and Jean Glover Hodges of Ardmore, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Fox Hodges to Andrew McDara Blau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence McDara Blau of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: PAN AMERICAN'S Eurosaver fare from New York to London for travelers leaving May 31 is $535 round trip. For those leaving the next day, it is $704. Much of the difference is in the season: May 31 falls within shoulder season, and June 1 begins the high season (and is a weekend departure).
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Susannah R. Labov and Gregory M. Page were married yesterday at Delmonico's restaurant in New York by Samuel Morgenstern, a justice of the peace. The bride is a daughter of Dr. Teresa Gnasso Labov and Dr. William Labov, both of Philadelphia. The bridegroom is the son of Lieut. Col. W. Mark Page of Orlando, Fla., and the late Dr.
LEAD: Athletes, Terry Cummings said, don't like the ''no'' word.

LEAD: CONSERVATIVES have railed for years against the Supreme Court's expansive criminal procedure rulings of the 1950's and 1960's. The Court was permitting the guilty to go free on ''technicalities,'' they said.

LEAD: Deon van der Walt, a South African tenor, made an auspicious Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as Belmonte in Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail.'' Mr. van der Walt has sung the same role at the Salzburg Festival (a widely circulated televised production), the Royal Opera in London, the Bavarian State Opera in Munich and other prestigious theaters, and on Thursday one could hear and see why.

LEAD: PARIS, we are endlessly assured, is no longer truly Paris but instead a city, like many others, in thrall to sheiks, Japanese conglomerates and fast-food operatives. It is true that foreign investment has changed the character of certain of the city's arrondissements, and that the once classy Champs-Elysees now has a hectic, honky-tonk glow to it.
LEAD: Tompkins County residents, who have long considered their area a pristine refuge from the world, are suddenly feeling that something has gone terribly wrong.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.
LEAD: Frederick Evoy Kneip, a retired executive in the paper products industry, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Lakeland (Fla.) Regional Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Lakeland.
LEAD: ABOUT a year ago, a physician came into the Rye Brook office of Dr. Andrew Bronin as a patient.
LEAD: Amid a design expansion in swim wear, beach cover-ups are being transformed from a functional to a fashion item.

LEAD: DIANA KAPPEL-SMITH settled into a wing-back chair and began describing a five-month journey through a world of darkness. Leaving her home in Rowayton, she traveled in search of alligators in Louisiana kangaroo rats in Arizona, coyotes in North Dakota, octopuses in Hawaii and brown bats in Connecticut.
LEAD: ''We're just not a superpower anymore. Economically, we are not as strong as Japan or West Germany right now.

LEAD: ''INTROSPECTIVES,'' a show by Americans and Brazilians of African descent, comes to the Bronx Museum of the Arts from the California Afro-American Museum in Los Angeles. There, it was organized by Henry J. Drewal, a professor of art history at Cleveland State University, and David C. Driskell, professor of art at the University of Maryland.
LEAD: ''THE Great American Backstage Musical'' begins in 1939 and ends in 1945 in Johnny's Bar, where having a fancy drink means putting olives in your beer.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Tinh N. Tran of San Diego have announced the engagement of their daughter Nga Thi-Tuyet Tran and Peter Charles Manbeck, the son of Harry F. Manbeck Jr. of McLean, Va., and the late Lois L. Manbeck. A spring wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Gottfried Kleiber of Sands Point, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for Mrs. Kleiber's daughter Ingrid Maria Elizabeth von Lepel and Charles McNulty, the son of Rosemary McNulty of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Charles H. McNulty.

LEAD: In the stark Manhattan meeting room, under fluorescent glare, the studious, well-fed man in the three-piece suit chomped on a cigar. He put a derby on, took it off. He bellowed: ''We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about states' revenue problems misstated New York's bond rating in some editions. It is now ''very good.'' A chart with the article referred incorrectly to Vermont's budget and the estimated deficit. Vermont is on a two-year budget cycle and is working to avoid a $90 million deficit for the fiscal years 1990 and 1991.

LEAD: ECONOMIES OF THE HEART. By Christopher Zenowich. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The 10 stories collected in ''Economies of the Heart'' document a poor boy's introduction to the brutish world of manual labor, a world he chooses to enter so he'll make enough money to escape to college. Christopher Zenowich's protagonist is Bob Bodewicz, a younger version of the hero of Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ROOTIE KAZOOTIE By Lawrence Naumoff. 281 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: When Sonia M. Rivera was appointed principal of the academically troubled Eastern District High School in Brooklyn in 1981, she had 19 years of experience in public schools and a reputation for hard work and dedication to students.

LEAD: WITH an anatomy consisting of no more than a glob of genetic material wrapped in a protective coat of protein, viruses exist on the boundary between the living and the dead. Under a plan announced last week, these borderline creatures would be used as messengers to smuggle missing genes into the cells of children otherwise doomed by a devastating congenital disorder.
LEAD: On a night when they relived some of their glorious past and may have got some hope for the future, the Knicks also attended to their present business and beat the New Jersey Nets, 110-91.

LEAD: Over two decades, Central America's bloodiest carnage has taken place not in El Salvador or Nicaragua but in Guatemala. An army counter-insurgency campaign and extremist death squads have taken some 75,000 lives. The civilian Government of President Vinicio Cerezo has brought some positive changes but has failed to halt politically inspired killings.

LEAD: The marriage of Helen E. Lepaw to Joseph Gregory Barlow took place yesterday at the Beaver Creek Chapel in Vail, Colo. The Rev. Don Simonton performed the nondenominational ceremony. Mrs. Barlow, 29 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin I. Lepaw of Dix Hills, L.I. A graduate of the Parsons School of Design, she is a graphic design consultant in New York.

LEAD: Once again, the heat is on the American Express Company and its chairman, James D. Robinson 3d. Having been forced to rescue its brokerage subsidiary with a massive capital infusion, American Express is facing criticism for a series of missteps over the past decade.

LEAD: The mascot for the Duke Blue Devils wore a headband that proclaimed: ''Pride of North Carolina!'' But on a day when past form proved irrelevant, the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament got its first non-North Carolina final as Georgia Tech defeated Duke, 83-72, and Virginia eliminated top-seeded Clemson, 69-66, in semifinal games at the Charlotte

LEAD: The reply by R. S. McCord (''Some Suggestions for Better Health'') gave a grossly simplistic view of modern health care. The health care professionals he listed may not be able to help every patient 100 percent of the time, but then physicians can't either.
LEAD: A mysterious gas leak sent 110 people to hospitals Friday after they complained of nausea and vomiting, officials said.

LEAD: Vice Adm. and Mrs. John A. Baldwin Jr. of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Sewell Baldwin, to Lieut. (j.g.) Samuel Cranage Baker of the Navy, the son of Rear Adm. Edward B. Baker Jr. of San Diego and the late Michal Baker. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, Haiti's military ruler for the last 18 months, stepped down today after a week of nationwide protests. An army officer said a provisional government would take power within 72 hours to organize elections.

LEAD: CACOPHONY can be beautiful, say members of a new foreign-language club that meets once a month here at Manhattanville College. The club, sponsored by the Cross-Cultural Center of the college, brings together native speakers of various languages with those who want to practice their own foreign-language skills.

LEAD: As he set out on a drive through East Jerusalem Friday afternoon, trying to demonstrate despite Washington's suggestion to the contrary that the Arab half of the city is an inseparable part of the Israeli capital, Mayor Teddy Kollek could hardly restrain his anger.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: It would be reasonable to suppose that a player who is struggling in a difficult contract would always feel grateful when the defense errs and gives him an easy road home. But there can be rare exceptions for those more concerned with esthetics than results. Consider the diagramed deal played Feb.
LEAD: An article last Sunday about Westchester County's environmental policies misstated Marc Moran's title. He is director of government operations.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The University of Maryland has filed a letter of appeal with the National Collegiate Athletic Association, requesting that the appeal of sanctions levied against its men's basketball program be heard in April rather than in August.

LEAD: Sneakers, those once-lowly and often ragged athletic shoes, have evolved into high-tech status symbols that, in turn, have become a source of growing concern among high school and college officials.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: IF I NEVER GET BACK. By Darryl Brock. (Crown, $18.95.) Submitted for your approval: Sam Fowler, a frustrated crime-and-disaster reporter for The San Francisco Chronicle whose wife has left him for a television anchorman, boards a train in Cleveland after his father's funeral, collapses and wakes up in 1869, surrounded by the Cincinnati Red Stockings, just as they are about to begin their legendary 64-0 season.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hank Gathers had a $1 million insurance policy that he might have been able to collect on when his heart problem was first diagnosed, but it covered him only for disability, not death. The late Loyola Marymount basketball star bought the policy from Lloyd's of London last May, obtaining a bank loan to pay the $6,600 premium, said Mike Petersen, vice president of Petersen Marketing and Management Corporation, the Los Angeles representative for

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Dogan Kizilay of South Orange, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Ayse Kizilay and Ralph Gilbert Mallory 3d, a son of Marjorie Garvey of Natick, Mass., and Mr. Mallory Jr. of Belmont, Mass. Miss Kizilay, an Allegheny College graduate, is the executive assistant to the director of the reproductive endocrinology and fertility division at the Medical Center of George Washington University, where Mr.
LEAD: The Smudge of Spontaneity

LEAD: Forget about accountants being a mild-mannered bunch of milquetoasts. When it comes to competing for clients, they are actually some of the most ruthless predators known to humankind. As Barry R. Wallach, a tax expert with Arthur Andersen & Company, boasted, ''I kind of view nonclients as clients being held in trust for us by the competition until we get there.

LEAD: The revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe appear to have swept eastward into Asia, with the Communist leadership in the remote nation of Mongolia preparing for a meeting on Monday that may lead to the ouster of its Politburo.

LEAD: Researchers at the College of Aeronautics, Queens, N.Y., and at Ixion Inc., a Seattle-based computer and video programming company, have devised an interactive video system that can teach oxygen acetylene welding under different conditions without danger.

LEAD: If you are a wanderer of the winter woods - whether skiing, snowshoeing, camping or hunting -with an inquisitive mind, ''Winter -an Ecological Handbook'' by James C. Halfpenny and Roy Douglas Ozanne (Johnson Books, 275 pages, paperback, $16.95) will add zest to your excursions.
LEAD: To supporters' cheers and opponents' cries of ''murderer,'' Gen. Augusto Pinochet ended his last full day in power today with a call for national unity behind his elected successor.

LEAD: To the Editor: Last October one of the many kindnesses shown to us by our French friends in Nimes was to take me, a confessed do-it-yourselfer, for a look around the local Castorama. Peter D. Lawrence (''French Supermarkets of Stylish Wares for the Home,'' Travel, Jan. 7) nicely described the excellent examples of design found there, and the special style of some of the European solutions to home improvement needs.
LEAD: Coleman Carter Walker, a former vice president of Bankers Trust Company, died on Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: When the biggest apple in the barrel is rotten, it will poison the whole barrel. I think that time for North Carolina State's basketball program has come. It was inevitable. DAVID I. FISHER Basking Ridge, N.J.

LEAD: Once again, The Phantom of the Opera has been sighted, according to reports from the capital. Last fall, the masked figure in full evening regalia made a sudden appearance on the roof of the Paris Opera House. Fortunately, he was cornered by the police and unmasked.

LEAD: At a special meeting of the County Board of Legislators on Feb. 13 the Board voted 15 to 1 for a budget amendment that restored over $14 million in spending [''Budget Impasse Comes to an End,'' Feb. 18] . By doing so, the Board voted to reinstate more than 450 jobs that County Executive O'Rourke had threatened to terminate.

LEAD: A DECLINE in occupancy over the last several years has led to the closing of the Parkview Hilton, once the premier hotel in the heart of downtown Hartford, to a struggle for guests by a major new hotel and to the pullout of a major partner in still another.
LEAD: Everyone belongs to one tribe or another. Sometimes just for the weekend.

LEAD: Now that it's the 90's, looking back at the 60's with gales of laughter is a party game more popular than Trivial Pursuit. The funny clothes! The angry people! The drugs! The hair styles! What pretensions! What a hoot it all was! Weren't we silly! That about sizes it up for SIXTIES PEOPLE (Knopf, $24.95) by Jane Stern and Michael Stern, whose previous books include ''Elvis World'' and ''Square Meals.

LEAD: To the Editor: Apropos Betsy Wade's discussion of cartography (Practical Traveler, Jan. 14), I wish to bring to the attention of your readers a distressing observation. In Michelin's map of Northeast Africa (No. 954), the frontispiece shows the borders of Jordan including all of Israel, which goes nameless.

LEAD: May wedding plans for Roberta Pam Soble and Eric M. Dochter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Dochter of East Hills, L.I., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. Soble of Lido Beach, L.I.

LEAD: So how did they play in Enfield, Conn.? To test a long-held belief in the video industry that outside of New York and Los Angeles the country doesn't want to watch foreign films, Orion Home Video deployed 24 of its best foreign titles (such as ''Babette's Feast'' and ''Manon of the Spring'') in 500 exurban stores, all of them in prosperous towns and many of them near universities.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Cherashore of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Beth Madeline Cherashore, and Eric Dean Schlager, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Lawrence Schlager of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S drunken driving laws, now among the toughest in the country, have become so severe that their enforcement has begun to infringe on drivers' civil rights, say lawyers and advocates for motorists groups.

LEAD: You didn't mention the way in which many residents of New York City spend Saturday night. For many of us, it is a time to stay away from the nightspots and the crowds that crowd in from suburbia. It is a time to avoid the touring automobiles and roaming band of visitors. During the week, the noise of the city has a certain rhythm, a sense of purpose that is somehow absent from the weekend ruckus.

LEAD: A chart last Sunday about elections in the Soviet Union gave an incorrect figure for the population of the Russian republic. It is 147,386,000.

The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man was charged with stealing 15 sacred Jewish scrolls from synagogues in New Jersey and Pennsylvania last month, the United States Attorney for New Jersey has announced.

LEAD: There I was, cross-country skiing in Yellowstone Park with my friend Tom Telemark. Bald eagles swooped overhead and bison and elk congregated at steaming thermal pools only yards from the trail. Every hour and a quarter, give or take 10 minutes, Old Faithful gushed forth in the distance.
LEAD: MEANS OF ASCENT The Years of Lyndon Johnson. By Robert A. Caro. Illustrated. 506 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

LEAD: An agreement by the Pyramid Companies to buy five Bonwit Teller stores is likely to insure the survival of one of the nation's oldest retailers at a time when a number of other famous chains have vanished.

LEAD: ''What did he know, and when did he know it?'' This now-famous question should be asked of Jim Valvano. A major college basketball coach sets the tone for his players on the court with the tactics he teaches them. He sets the tone for them off the court by his own behavior. If Jim Valvano was not aware of his players' unlawful activities, he is guilty of incompetence.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Mark Hess, an artist and a graphic designer, is used to turning out commissioned works - typically magazine covers - in a few days. But it took him two years to design his first stamp.

LEAD: Tseng Kwong Chi, an artist and photographer who for the last 10 years documented the downtown art scene in Manhattan and particularly the works of the artist Keith Haring, died of AIDS early yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. Mr. Tseng was 39 years old.

LEAD: Dr. Kim Lisa Gilbert and Laurence Mark Rubin, a son of Marilyn Rubin of Newton, Mass., and the late William Rubin, plan to marry in August, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Gilbert of Floral Park, Queens, have announced.
LEAD: The Soviet Union and Hungary signed an agreement today calling for all Soviet troops to be withdrawn from Hungarian territory by the middle of next year, Hungarian radio reported.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Thomas Glover of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Glover, to Mark Bruce Pendleton, the son of Bruce Pendleton of Sagamore Hills, Ohio, and Judy Wilson of Jacksonville, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: AS the mists rise each morning, the calm and graceful Nam Khan River in northern Laos slowly takes shape, ornamented with saffron-robed Buddhist monks on the banks and naked children swimming in the middle, and destined a few hundred yards later to end its journey in the embrace of the larger, ever-churning Mekong River.

LEAD: Every set of Olympic Games has its dominant figure. In Rome in 1960 it was a boxer named Cassius Clay. In Montreal in 1976 it was a gymnast named Nadia Comaneci. In Seoul in 1988 it was a runner named Ben Johnson skulking out of town.

LEAD: Dr. Elliott J. Goldstein of Pittsburgh and Dr. Marion Zucker Goldstein of Amherst, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lillian Rachel Goldstein to Robert Andrew Schapiro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Schapiro of New York. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Irv Levinson and Vi Krichinsky grew up on Appleton Street in southwest Baltimore, where they met more than 50 years ago and, later, were married. Today they're back for the first time in decades, along with Irv's younger brother Herb and a few cousins, and they can hardly believe what they see. Lining Appleton are 1940's vintage Cadillacs, Buicks, Chevrolets and Hudsons.
LEAD: CLUMP, bang, ouch - the thrust from the working world into maternity leave leaves scars.

LEAD: For a main dish of marinated pork, the meat can be marinated overnight or for 20 minutes. The shorter time will not produce quite the same results, but the seasonings are so intense that even the quick version is very appealing.

LEAD: I've just finished reading the article about the outstanding James quilt collection [''County Couple's Quilts Chosen for Japan Tour,'' Feb. 18] . As a quilt collector and enthusiast I was especially interested. However, as a supremely satisfied client of Betsy Prokop, I can just imagine the frustration of potential quilt-owning clients, who will never be able to locate her through your article.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Dugan of Chalfont, Pa., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Jean Marie Dugan and Stephen Brooks Faber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ross Faber of Madison, N.J.

LEAD: ANOTHER thing a faint heart never won is a Texas election. Ann Richards, who until recently was regarded as a shoo-in to win the Democratic gubernatorial nomination this week, has lately been losing ground in a rough-and-tumble campaign that has focused on two issues - the death penalty and drugs - and has left no room for subtleties of position on either.

LEAD: MONDAY: Valentin Pavlov, the Soviet Minister of Finance, begins meeting with Nicholas Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, in Washington. The American Paper Institute begins a three-day conference in New York. An automatic card shuffler debuts in Atlantic City. TUESDAY: The Commerce Department releases retail sales for February and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter.
LEAD: Just when those wonderful denizens of Wall Street, the arbs, thought things couldn't get worse, they did.
LEAD: September wedding plans for Kelly Ann Heller and David Michael Shelsky have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin G. Heller of Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: Robert L. Kaufman, former president of Mollie Parnis Inc. and a former president of the New York Fashion Council, died on Thursday of complications from lung cancer at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.
LEAD: Two brothers who are heirs to a $14 million estate are expected to be charged next week with the shotgun murders of their parents in a Beverly Hills mansion last summer.

LEAD: As the first director of the Environmental Protection Agency in the early 1970's, William D. Ruckelshaus won praise for standing up to industry on a range of pollution issues. In 1983, he returned to the E.P.A. and restored public trust in the agency, which had become mired in corruption under Anne Gorsuch Burford.

LEAD: FOR the first time in recent memory, the Board of Legislators invited the public to address it last week. Like nervous hosts, the members opened the doors Monday night and waited to see if anyone would come. They were nearly trampled in the crush.

LEAD: Youmadeyourpoint, perhaps the most improved horse in Florida this winter, outran a strong field and broke a course record while winning the $157,600 Gulfstream Breeders' Cup Handicap on the grass today at Gulfstream Park.

My apartment has been robbed; thank goodness, there is little left to steal. I've been assaulted on the street; thank goodness, it'll be

The bride is a daughter of Anneke deBruyn Overseth of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Oliver Enoch Overseth Jr. of Ann Arbor and Geneva. The bridegroom is the son of Mr.

LEAD: FAKING IT IN AMERICA: Barry Minkow and the Great ZZZZ Best Scam. By Joe Domanick. (Contemporary Books, $19.95.) Barry Minkow belongs to the great tradition of American con men. At first glance, Mr. Minkow had the look of a modern-day Horatio Alger hero - an energetic if rough-edged lower-middle-class teen-ager who, while still in high school, had made the startling entrepreneurial leap from cleaning carpets after school to founding his own carpet-cleaning company, ZZZZ Best.

LEAD: The engagement of Frances Danise Stewart to Frederic Sanborn Waugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Waugh of Southport, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Frances D. Edge of Chester, Ga., and Daniel P. Stewart of Forsyth, Ga. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: A key Lebanese Shiite Muslim leader said in remarks published today that he was ''encouraging elements'' that may lead to the release of Westerners taken hostage in Lebanon.
LEAD: The issue of Jim Valvano's accountability cannot be addressed until another question is considered: are the charges of point-shaving true or false?
LEAD: Six goals in the second period sparked the Devils to their most productive game of the season tonight and a 9-3 triumph over the Quebec Nordiques at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: FOR the last few years - 29 and counting - my wife has thought I don't worry enough and that, of course, worries her. To my mind there are only a handful of things you really have to be concerned about: enough money for rent and groceries, your health and that of the ones you love, trying not to appear overly dumb in front of your children, and whether the planes you ride stay up long enough.
LEAD: The Coney Island of dreams and memories - the magical seaside Brooklyn playground of wondrous amusements and rides - is still a part of New York.

LEAD: Ellen Rose Unterberg, a daughter of Susan Unterberg and Thomas Unterberg, both of New York, was married last evening at the Plaza to Andrew George Celli Jr., a son of Judge and Mrs. Celli of Rochester. Rabbi Bert Aaron Siegel and the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: INCENSED by what they say is an intolerable level of jet noise over their homes, New Jersey residents in dozens of communities have banded together to draw the attention of politicians and government officials to the problem.

LEAD: THE Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains is home to an endeavor known as Downtown Music at Grace. ''The charming Victorian architecture and fine acoustics of the church provide a warm, intimate setting for all types of music,'' said the group's music director, Timothy Lewis.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Boston Red Sox yesterday completed their 40-player roster when Ellis Burks, the center fielder, accepted a hefty pay raise and Jody Reed, the shortstop, received a healthy salary increase with the renewal of his contract. The Red Sox did not disclose financial terms, but Burks reportedly signed a one-year contract for $475,000 guaranteed, plus incentives based on games and plate appearances worth an additional $75,000.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Guests arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria on Monday night in variations of dress suggesting a masked ball at a sultan's court. This year's Purim Ball, the Jewish Museum's annual fund-raising gala, had an Ottoman theme to herald the museum's spring exhibition, ''In the Court of the Sultan: Sephardi Jews of the Ottoman Empire.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Carlson of Boston have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Dr. Nancy Ann Carlson, and Dr. John Matthew Fisher, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Fisher of St. Albans, Vt. Dr. Carlson, 29 years old, is a chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington, where her fiance, 30, is an attending anesthesiologist.

LEAD: A painful back injury recently sent me to top medical specialists in Washington and New York. One doctor rated the injury an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10 and recommended immediate surgery. The other rated it a 2 and suggested plenty of rest and physical therapy. I opted for the latter and am in fine physical shape today.

LEAD: The engagement of Kimberli Rose Cohn to Dr. Scott Higgins Bailey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Higgins D. Bailey of Bethesda, Md., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman U. Cohn of Radnor, Pa. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: TRAVELING with children, especially small ones, no doubt promotes family unity but on occasion it can also present problems. Take a city like Bangkok, for example - not by reputation nor, from a first glimpse of its perilous traffic, by physical layout an ideal place for juvenile amusement.

LEAD: ALMOST everyone who goes to Italy feels drawn to Siena's curving medieval streets, that perfect fan-shaped piazza, the glittering paintings with almond-eyed madonnas, and the exotic striped cathedral. No one goes there to eat. Of all the Tuscan towns, Siena has the worst reputation for restaurants.

LEAD: THE Simsbury Light Opera Company is distinctive on a number of counts, not the least of them having survived to celebrate its 45th anniversary season. And as one of only about a dozen non-university companies in the country that maintains its own set and costume shop, Simsbury not only makes its facilities available to other arts groups, but also shares its performance surpluses with education, performing arts and health maintenance organizations.

LEAD: Colorado, which keeps extending the career of Coach Tom Miller, defeated Oklahoma State, 82-72, today in the semifinals of the Big Eight tournament to advance to the final against No. 1 Oklahoma.

LEAD: The engagement of Heather Allison Stiers to Jonathan Andrew Dorn, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob H. Dorn of Dayton, Ohio, has been made known by her parents, the Rev. Brenda J. Stiers and the Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers of Greenwich, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Three children playing on a Bronx street yesterday made a grisly find: a round object wrapped in a cloth that turned out to be a human head, the police said. The father of one of the children then found a plastic bag in a box nearby containing two legs.

LEAD: The Lincoln Theater, a 65-year-old former playhouse in New Haven, has dodged the wrecker's ball and, in the best tradition of melodrama, has been revived - as the Little Theater on Lincoln Street.

LEAD: THE SUN IN CAPRICORN. By Paul Rosenblatt. (Watermark Press, 149 North Broadway, Wichita, Kan. 67202, $18.50.) Jonathan, a much beloved American who teaches literature and poetry in Rio de Janeiro, has been set up. A guerrilla named Verlande has tricked him into a compromising situation and the innocent academic has become ''a temporary liability'' who must be sent stateside.

LEAD: Ending four days of soul-searching, Italy's troubled Communist Party, the largest in the West, agreed at a meeting here today to transform itself into a new political grouping known for now only as The Thing.

LEAD: An article in the Sports Section on Feb. 25 about the experiences of black players in the National Hockey League incorrectly described the professional level at which an incident involving Willie O'Ree, the first black player in the N.H.L., took place. The incident, in which O'Ree said he became entangled with a group of fans who made racial remarks and grabbed at his jersey, occurred when O'Ree was playing for the Quebec Aces in the minor leagues, not in the N.H.L.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Christie's, one of the world's two major auction houses, has abruptly reversed a longstanding policy and has guaranteed a minimum price for a collection of artworks it is to auction in May.

LEAD: In Eastern Europe, Hungary is leading the way in shifting trade away from the Soviet Union and toward the West. The abrupt about-face has jolted many Hungarian companies that grew fat and happy relying on the huge Soviet market.
LEAD: International
LEAD: Louisiana Tech, Washington, Stanford and Tennessee received the top seedings today for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I women's basketball tournament.

LEAD: AIDS patients who have taken an experimental drug in a new and controversial distribution system have been dying at more than 10 times the rate of those who are taking the drug in standard tests, its manufacturer says.
LEAD: The Sultan of Brunei has denied that he played a role in the $1 billion takeover of House of Fraser P.L.C., the owner of the Harrods department stores, by the Fayed brothers in 1985.
LEAD: A Japanese auto parts maker last week rejected a demand by the American investor T. Boone Pickens to review the company's financial records.

LEAD: * Martha Voutas Productions will promote a ''fantasy auction'' at Sotheby's to benefit the Manhattan Center for Living.
LEAD: FRIDAY was another typical day of trading in the New York Stock Exchange's so-called basket product: nobody bought one, and nobody sold one.

LEAD: Anti-Government demonstrators marched today through the capital and in Timisoara, the cradle of the December revolution, protesting what they said was the continued prevalence of Communists and the dreaded security police.

LEAD: As a rule, ballets conceived by Jean Cocteau did not resemble ballets, and ''Le Train Bleu,'' which has now received a major and engaging reconstruction job from the Oakland Ballet, is no exception.
LEAD: The Arab League agreed in principle today to move its headquarters back here, in the high point of a two-year campaign by Egypt for full rehabilitation in the Arab world.

LEAD: ''Parabola'' at the Dia Art Foundation on Saturday night was the blanket title for a series of musical events meant to be seen - even tasted - as well as heard. Two performers and creators, Takehisa Kosugi and Fast Forward (yes, that is his name), perambulated an open space before a small audience in bleacher seats and made music on a number of instruments, household objects and themselves.

LEAD: G.M. Deal With East Germany. The largest American auto maker tentatively agreed to a joint venture with the larger of East Germany's two car makers. General Motors could invest as much as $600 million in the venture, which would make components and assemble cars at a factory near the West German border.

LEAD: Amending a controversial bill proposed last week, the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly approved an unconditional amnesty late Saturday that would cover all crimes committed by either side in the country's civil war.

LEAD: The Bush Administration urged the Soviet Union today to respect the decision of the Lithuanian parliament to restore its sovereignty, but stopped short of an explicit statement of recognition of the newly declared government.
LEAD: The second of two brothers accused of killing their parents at the family's Beverly Hills mansion last year surrendered to the authorities early today, the police said.
LEAD: Susan Tina Hosat and Dr. Stewart Alan Levine were married yesterday at Temple Shalom in Fresh Meadows, Queens, by Rabbis Stuart Berman and Pierce Neuman.

LEAD: A fire swept through a Harlem apartment yesterday morning, killing a 2-year-old girl who was found dead in her crib, the police said. The fire was contained in the top floor apartment at 301 West 152d Street. The infant's five brothers and sisters; her mother, Yvette Adams, 26; and her grandmother, Nettie Adams, 53, managed to safely flee the building.

LEAD: Israeli Coalition Cracks Shimon Peres and other Labor leaders stormed out of a Cabinet meeting over differences with the Likud on the American peace plan. Page A7. LEAD: In what he described as a budget challenge to his own party and the Bush Administration, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee today called for a combination of tax increases and spending cuts, including a one-year freeze on increases in Social Security benefits.
LEAD: Joe Kleine was in an unfamiliar situation - taking the big shot with the game on the line and making it. But these are strange times for the Boston Celtics.

LEAD: Haiti was a country without a government today as political leaders failed to find a replacement for Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, who resigned on Saturday but did not immediately leave the country.
LEAD: As the proxy season approaches, investors are girding for battle over everything from ''golden parachutes'' and ''poison pills'' to ousting directors.
LEAD: Boston College and Colgate were both one goal better than their opponents tonight as they captured the championship matches in two college hockey tournaments.

LEAD: * Mike Bienstock, associate media director; Howard Finkelberg, associate director of marketing sciences, and Buz Sawyer, management representative, have been named senior vice presidents at BBDO New York.

LEAD: Nearly three months after American forces invaded Panama, the Panamanian economy is in ruins and $1 billion in emergency aid remains stalled in the United States Congress. At the Metropolitan Cathedral here, President Guillermo Endara has devised an unusual but apt way to dramatize the plight of a country starved for money: he has gone on an indefinite hunger strike.

LEAD: Two inmates in a crowd leaving a chapel service on Rikers Island were shot yesterday, the authorities said. But while correction officers found the .25-caliber gun on the floor outside the chapel, by last night they had no suspects and said they did not know the motive.
LEAD: Except for the fan who waited all winter, who is the biggest loser in baseball's short spring?
LEAD: * Calvin Klein Cosmetics, to Chiat/ Day/Mojo in New York, for its Eternity and Obsession fragrance lines, with a budget of $20 million to $30 million.
LEAD: I SAW a young man sitting in the stands in Madison Square Garden yesterday wearing a deflated basketball for a hat and a basketball net pulled over it and covering his face like a veil.

LEAD: WHEN Donald Wardlow, a ''color commentator,'' is ushered to his press box seat by a Seeing Eye dog named Duffer, heads inevitably turn. Sports fans watch in amazement as he unloads a bag that contains a microphone, a mixer, and a Braille typewriter.

LEAD: The way New York City governs land, perhaps its most precious commodity, is in quiet turmoil these days, with the Dinkins administration behind schedule in putting in place changes under the new City Charter and developers rushing to act on big projects before the system changes.
LEAD: Credit market analysts are predicting that short-term interest rates, which have recently been inching up, are likely to move even higher.
LEAD: A Vietnam-era program intended to give poor youths and those with low aptitudes a ''leg up'' on life by lowering standards for entry into the military was a failure, a new study says.
LEAD: The executive director of the state Democratic Party has resigned after calling the Republican Governor a fascist.
LEAD: The Untouched Key Tracing Childhood Trauma in Creativity and Destructiveness By Alice Miller Translated by Hildegarde and Hunter Hannum. Doubleday. 180 pages. Illustrated. $17.95.

LEAD: * Allegheny Power System Inc., New York, a utility holding company, named Stanley I. Garnett 2d chief financial officer. He replaces Alan J. Noia, who becomes executive vice president of Allegheny's Potomac Edison Company unit.
LEAD: Venezuela and its commercial bankers are moving toward a debt agreement that is expected to include a provision for substantial, but temporary, debt relief.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that the latest coup attempt in Afghanistan showed that President Najibullah is weak and vulnerable and faces substantial opposition from within the Communist Party and the Afghan armed forces.
LEAD: The proper number of knotholes in a sheet of plywood does not constitute anyone's definition of subject matter fit for review by the leaders of Japan and the United States.

LEAD: Now and then, amid the clutter of local news programs, one comes upon a useful and entertaining item, like finding in a junkyard a cuckoo clock that works. LEAD: Three young children died Saturday night in a fire that choked their Brooklyn apartment with heavy smoke, and investigators said yesterday that they were searching for a woman who was supposed to be baby-sitting them when the fire broke out.
LEAD: rrA picture booklet with pages the size of baseball cards has been produced to instruct athletes on how to improve their play through animation.
LEAD: Long the detached observer, Mario Vargas Llosa dismissed politics a few years ago as ''a very dirty business.''
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed an overhaul of the Communist Party as he pressed his strategy to de-emphasize the party's position. Page A10.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera began broadcasting its Saturday matinees to a national radio audience in 1931, but nearly called its series to a halt in 1939 when it had trouble finding a sponsor. In 1940, Texaco began sponsoring the weekly broadcasts, and on Saturday afternoon, the Met and Texaco celebrated their half-century alliance with a gala concert that was, naturally, broadcast live.
LEAD: Robinson Nugent Inc., a small maker of electronic connectors, has named a new president and chief executive, Larry W. Burke.

LEAD: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who is seeking control of the Lockheed Corporation, outlined his strategy for the company today, saying Lockheed needs to refocus on its core military and space businesses.

LEAD: All-news cable television and radio stations have obliged compulsive Americans to follow current events during midnight snacks, at the dinner table and even, for owners of waterproof radios, in the shower. Now even the afternoon flight home from an out-of-town meeting, a quiet respite in the sky from the tumult of information below, may have its own hourly newspaper.

LEAD: Because of a computer malfunction, an article on Feb. 28 about a Supreme Court ruling on the treatment of mentally ill prisoners was scrambled in some copies. The opening paragraph should have read, ''The Supreme Court ruled today that prison officials can treat mentally ill prisoners with antipsychotic drugs against their will without first receiving permission in a formal judicial hearing.

LEAD: When voters turn out for the Illinois gubernatorial primary this month, they will face an unfamiliar choice. For the first time since 1976, the Republican ballot will not include the name James R. Thompson.

LEAD: Labor Party ministers stormed angrily out of an Israeli Cabinet meeting today after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud party refused to put to a vote a plan by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

LEAD: Last spring, the rain began leaking into the small room on the fourth floor of the northern Bronx elementary school where Louise Warren teaches reading and writing to students who have fallen behind.

LEAD: Martial Singher, a French baritone who became a leading American operatic and concert artist and later a noted teacher, died of heart disease on Saturday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: Edye Kleiman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Kleiman of Coram, L.I., was married yesterday at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., to Rand Kevin Rosenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Rosenbaum of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbi Ronald Millstein officiated.

LEAD: Simon & Schuster, already a leading force in educational publishing, is expanding further through the acquisition of the Computer Curriculum Corporation, a software company providing computer-based learning systems for schools.
LEAD: When Robert A. Iger was named president of ABC Entertainment nearly a year ago, he felt as if he had entered a Federal witness protection program.

LEAD: The great Kiki Vandeweghe mystery finally came to an end tonight when the Knick forward dressed for his first road game of the season. But how much of a factor he is going to be in the stretch run remains a significant question.

LEAD: Suddenly frozen in time, the Connecticut Huskies strode one by one through the noise to the center of the court at Madison Square Garden to accept the wristwatches and handshakes that go to the champions of the Big East Conference tournament.
