LEAD: Six minutes into yesterday's Big East championship game between Syracuse and Connecticut, Derrick Coleman took a pass from Michael Edwards and slammed in an authoritative dunk.

LEAD: The most lucrative deal in television history, $3.65 billion over four years, was unanimously approved here today by the National Football League owners in the opening session of their annual meeting.

LEAD: For nine years, Cornelia and Michael Bessie have published books that have earned them and their imprint a reputation as publishers of quality. Their authors have included Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Theodore H. White, Doris Lessing, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Anwar Sadat and the Nobel laureate Peter Medawar.
LEAD: Dozens of tiny plastic crack vials litter the ground-floor hallway of the small tan brick apartment building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. That is the present.
LEAD: Abbott Laboratories has taken the unusual step of removing its chairman, Robert A. Schoellhorn, and in turn, Mr. Schoellhorn has sued the company and four outside directors.
LEAD: Robert Kramer improperly received game tickets from an unidentified North Carolina State player in 1988, an investigation by the school and the National Collegiate Athletic Association showed.

LEAD: Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts owes a large debt to the owners of the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire: $2 billion. That's the cost of his refusal to help his New Hampshire neighbors devise an emergency evacuation plan.

LEAD: After beating its neighborhood rival, Abraham Lincoln, for the third time this season in a heart-stopping 47-46 Public Schools Athletic League semifinal yesterday, William E. Grady High School of Brooklyn is looking to be part of the first P.S.A.L. championship game at Madison Square Garden since 1964.
LEAD: Big East vs. A.C.C. I
LEAD: A QUEST for cottontail rabbits in Massachusetts helped begin a snowshoe-testing forest ramble in Maine.

LEAD: Does the price of mail really have to go up again? Yes, and 30 cents for a first-class letter is still a bargain compared with prices in other countries. But costlier service could also be better service. The U.S. Postal Service is, and acts like, a monopoly. Competition is the answer.

LEAD: A dispute over the role of a new international development bank to help Eastern Europe has been resolved with a decision that the bank will provide loans not only to the private sector, but also to public-sector projects like road building, European officials said today.
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins has intervened in a South Bronx special election to help an early supporter and to reduce competition and tensions between black and Hispanic Democrats.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WPP Group P.L.C., the world's largest marketing communications conglomerate, said its 1989 profit after taxes rose 89.4 percent, to $66.1 million, or $1.19 a share, from $34.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in 1988. Revenues increased 83.7 percent, to $1.64 billion, from $892.8 million in 1988. The company said its improved performance was helped by the acquisition of the Ogilvy Group, whose operating margin increased, and to a continued rise in the operating margins of J.

LEAD: For 25-year-old Jack Noseworthy, singing and dancing in ''A Chorus Line'' was always the stuff of dreams. Last month, Mr. Noseworthy's dreams came true. He was offered, and he accepted, a role in the Michael Bennett musical, the longest-running show in Broadway history. And then came the afternoon of Feb.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Last year, nearly everyone who is anyone in golf was asked to speculate about how Lee Trevino would do on the Senior Tour. Reactions ran the gamut, but it turns out the most accurate prognostication was the most drastic.
LEAD: For some people working on Madison Avenue these days, Mies vander Rohe certainly had the right idea: Less is more.

LEAD: Mar. 17: Townwide Fund St. Patrick's Run. Huntington, L.I., 8:30 A.M. A four-mile road race and one-kilometer fun run. Information: (516) 549-3006. St. Patrick's Day Horoscope Run. Central Park, 10 A.M. A five-kilometer run. Information: (212) 860-4455. Long Island Trout Unlimited Fly Fishing Clinic.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In a major step toward achieving independence from the Soviet Union, a congress selected by a majority of Estonians living in Estonia today called on the United Nations and the Soviet Parliament to restore ''the free and independent republic of Estonia.''

LEAD: The American tournament scene lost its much-loved oldest inhabitant Thursday when Jay Feigus of Middletown, N.J., died at the age of 97. He owned, apparently, two world records in competition of any kind and they may never be broken.
LEAD: Philip Glass and Allen Ginsberg will be the first adversaries in a series, ''Face the Music,'' starting at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.

LEAD: Golf Huston's First Victory: Mark Calcavecchia's late bid failed, and John Huston went on to win the Honda Classic yesterday in Coral Springs, Fla. Huston, 28 years old, led throughout the final 18 holes and earned the first victory of his three-season PGA Tour career with a closing 71. He won by a two-stroke margin over Calcavecchia with a 282 total, six under par on the windswept Tournament Players Course at Eagle Trace.

LEAD: A Georgia Tech team that may be just beginning to realize its strength completed a sweep through the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament this afternoon, defeating Virginia, 70-61, to capture the league title.

LEAD: The distance, the weights, and the odds were different, but the outcome was the same today at Gulfstream Park, when Charon beat Trumpet's Blare and De La Devil to win the $200,000 Bonnie Miss Stakes.

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev thinks Lithuanians are wrong to secede but accepts their right to be wrong. That's a mark of his liberation as well as theirs. Lithuania only declared itself independent yesterday. Now it must negotiate terms and timing. But Mr. Gorbachev has already said yes to the principle of a free Lithuania by agreeing to talks and by refusing to use force.
LEAD: A shot that Dwayne Stephens did not want to take proved to be the biggest basket of the season for Michigan State.

LEAD: Following are the principal economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Retail Sales ... Feb. Wednesday Inventories Sales Ratio ... Jan. Thursday None Friday Housing Starts ... Feb. Producer Price Index ... Feb. Industrial Production ...
LEAD: The American Express Company's dabble into real estate in the 1980's is proving to be one of its biggest blunders.
LEAD: United Press International is seeking arbitration of its claim that the Reuters news agency has deprived it of photography revenue for the last five years.
LEAD: Beware, all ye who enter, of Joe Baranyi, keeper of the Garden State's electric chair and curator of the mysterious New Jersey finger.
LEAD: As the 75th world figure skating championships concluded today with exhibition performances by the winners, the sport left behind part of its staid and traditional past.
LEAD: Does the name Judith Campbell Exner ring a bell? She is a woman, now coming to the end of her life, who was used and abused by three powerful men.
LEAD: Nuns and priests in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles who are 65 years old or older have been asked to volunteer to be inoculated with an experimental AIDS vaccine.

LEAD: Three weeks before the day when the last exhibition games are scheduled, the baseball commissioner and the players' labor leader met again yesterday. The outcome, however, was the same as it was after their meeting the previous day: no progress in the labor dispute.

LEAD: A theater company from the Soviet republic of Georgia is to make its American debut with a production of ''King Lear'' from April 2 to 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section.
LEAD: A prolific, inedible European shellfish that stowed away on freighters has become a multimillion-dollar menace in three years, lawmakers from Great Lakes states say.

LEAD: A Federal judge has frozen the assets of the founder of the Crazy Eddie electronics chain, who is being sought by Federal marshals in connection with an order to repatriate $52 million in overseas finances. Federal District Judge

LEAD: One volleyed, sliced, and worked the ball like a yo-yo; the other didn't. And today the quest of 13-year-old Jennifer Capriati ended in the blur of the topspin that wafted from Gabriela Sabatini's racquet as the determined Argentine put aside her own performance anxieties to defeat the first-timer, 6-4, 7-5, in the final of the Virginia Slims of

LEAD: Last fall, five days before the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo bought control of the Rockefeller Group, which owns Rockefeller Center, Mitsubishi's sister companies made another New York investment.
LEAD: A gunshot fired into a Greyhound bus outside Jacksonville injured seven people yesterday, the police and company officials said.
LEAD: Oliver Stone, the director of ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' won top honors from his peers on Saturday as the Directors Guild of America celebrated its own.
LEAD: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher left today for trade talks in Tokyo, saying he wanted to convey to the Japanese ''a certain sense of urgency about the trade problem.''

LEAD: Probably not since Judy Garland has a pop diva encouraged more extravagant exchanges of love between a performer and her audience than Patti LaBelle. On Friday evening, at the final concert of a three-night engagement at City Center, the 45-year-old pop-gospel singer from Philadelphia was besieged by floral tributes, and one admirer even crept up on the stage to kiss her feet.

LEAD: ''Expressing the will of the people, the Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Republic declares and solemnly proclaims the restoration of the exercise of sovereign powers of the Lithuanian state, which were annulled by an alien power in 1940. From now on, Lithuania is once again an independent state.''

LEAD: In the crowded ballroom of the New York Hilton Saturday night, an announcer introduced the Mayor of the City of New York, but David N. Dinkins was nowhere to be seen. The black-tie audience waiting for his rebuttal to the annual City Hall reporters' roast heard only whistling and the sound of running water.

LEAD: Bishop EMERSON J. MOORE, JOHN B. CARTER and Dr. BETTY SHABAZZ are to receive the New York Urban League's Frederick Douglass Award, the league's highest honor. The awards will be presented at a dinner on May 3, the 25th anniversary of the award presentation.

LEAD: VILNIUS, Lithuania, March 11 -Lithuania tonight proclaimed itself a sovereign state, legally free of the Soviet Union, and named the leaders of a non-Communist government to negotiate their future relations with Moscow.

LEAD: Christof Perick is to make his New York Philharmonic conducting debut in a series of concerts starting March 22 at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall, replacing Klaus Tennstedt, who is ill. The program is to include Weber's Overture to ''Oberon,'' Beethoven's Sixth Symphony and Sibelius's Violin Concerto, with Kyung-Wha Chung as soloist.

LEAD: In a move reflecting its push for growth in the United States and other markets, the Toyota Motor Corporation will build the world's biggest automotive proving ground near Phoenix, auto industry executives say.

LEAD: The Justice Department has begun a formal investigation of Citadel Military College of South Carolina in Charleston to determine whether its policy of admitting only men violates the Constitution and laws against discrimination.
LEAD: A war between rival taxi companies has turned this quiet black township a dozen miles southeast of Johannesburg into a battleground.

LEAD: SOME National Football League players have wounded egos because their clubs did not protect them in the current Plan B free-agency period. Other players are upset because their clubs did protect them, thus depriving the players of a chance for big money.
LEAD: February 1918 Lithuania, an independent state and later a Grand Duchy under the former Russian empire, is proclaimed an independent kingdom under the protection of Germany.
LEAD: Virginia, where tobacco has been king since Colonial times, has taken a major step toward limiting public smoking.

LEAD: A little more than two years ago, when Kurt L. Schmoke took over as Mayor of Baltimore, expectations soared that he would get this troubled old port city moving in a new direction. Time has tempered those hopes. An athletic Rhodes scholar who had managed to become the first black elected to the job, Mr.
LEAD: Gov. Wallace G. Wilkinson of Kentucky has dropped his proposal to impose a 5 percent sales tax on advertising. He made the announcement on Friday.

LEAD: An intense, costly search has failed to find a medical or environmental cause for the bizarre illness of 34 Triborough Bridge toll workers, leading bridge officials to suspect that the symptoms may have been psychosomatic.

LEAD: The Irish pianist Barry Douglas, who won the Tchaikovsky International Competition in 1986, gave a backward glance in his recital at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. His program included Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' which he performed to great acclaim in Moscow, and Tchaikovsky's Sonata in G (Op.

LEAD: In the latest in a series of deals by Western car companies in Eastern Europe, the General Motors Corporation announced tentative plans today to form a joint venture in East Germany with Automobil-Werk Eisenach, the bigger of East Germany's two car makers.

LEAD: THERE are still two legs and some 12,000 miles to go in the six-leg, 33,000-mile Whitbread round-the-world yacht race, but by one measure the 22 boats representing four yacht classes and 13 nations have already sailed around the world, or an icy chunk of it, anyway.
LEAD: Outside a polling place in Moscow last week, a voter framed the issue as a bitter joke: ''What is the difference between the Soviet Union and the United States?''

LEAD: ''Putting It Together,'' a two-hour celebration of the career of Stephen Sondheim on the composer and lyricist's 60th birthday is to be broadcast by WNYC-FM (93.9)at 2 P.M. on March 22. Produced by National Public Radio, the program is to feature Angela Lansbury as the host and include interviews with the producer and director Hal Prince and the singer Bernadette Peters.

LEAD: Audrey Judith Tobias, the treasurer and a former president of Waif Inc., a national organization that helps find homes for homeless children, and Lewis F. Davis, a builder, were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York by Judge George B. Daniels of City Criminal Court.
LEAD: After years of debate over how to relieve congestion at O'Hare Airport here, a political tug-of-war has begun over where to build a new one.

LEAD: Martin Stepanek works at the Prague Zoo with large animals. It is a good job, but his heart is really in snakes and crocodiles, he said as he waited to register with a newly formed association of entrepreneurs. He would like to open his own pet shop.
LEAD: The Wall Street money manager Fred Alger has settled an administrative action with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the S.E.C. said last week.

LEAD: Before four spills dumped hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill and the connecting Kill Van Kull this year, the two waterways were hardly known outside maritime circles, even though they carry more traffic than the Panama Canal. But the 16-mile channel winding between northern New Jersy and Staten Island is an important contributor to the economic vitality of the Northeast.

LEAD: WITH an energy not seen since the heyday of the multinationals 20 years ago, American companies are building factories overseas, buying companies and getting into all sorts of joint ventures. But while they expand their production abroad, they are somehow managing to do it without hiring a lot of foreign workers.

LEAD: A member of the Senate Banking Committee says he plans to propose a bill to put a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on the Security and Exchange Commission.

LEAD: Top-ranked Oklahoma opened a 17-point second-half lead on the shooting of William Davis and Jackie Jones then held on to beat Colorado, 92-80, today for the Big Eight Conference tournament title.

LEAD: Nine private citizens who advise the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee are drafting a proposal to change the Federal espionage laws, partly to strengthen the authority of investigators to search for spies, according to Government officials and private intelligence experts.
LEAD: Kokichi Akasaka, a guitarist from Japan who has lived in Spain since 1977, made his United States debut on Saturday evening at Weill Recital Hall.
LEAD: The Syrian-backed Government of President Elias Hrawi has rejected Gen. Michel Aoun's offer to start peace talks to end the fighting in Beirut.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed a basic overhaul of the troubled Communist Party, but stopped short of demanding competitive secret-ballot participation by all 19 million Communists in the election of the 5,000 delegates to the approaching party congress.

LEAD: Nelson Mandela ended a two-week, four-country African tour today and headed for Sweden despite suggestions that he might cancel his trip because of fatigue and mounting violence in South Africa.

LEAD: A man apparently upset over divorce proceedings walked into a church today, shot his wife twice, then turned the gun on himself as 55 churchgoers watched, the authorities said. The woman, Tawanna Jo Lynch, 32 years old, was shot in the head and was in critical condition at a hospital in Oklahoma City.

LEAD: Deborah Hay isn't an easy performer to watch or to understand. Her dances, like her stage presence, tend to be on the gnomic side. There is no man, for instance, in ''The Man Who Grew Common in Wisdom,'' a new work presented on Friday night at the Warren Street Performance Loft.
LEAD: An Air Force lieutenant accused of having sexual relations with a sergeant at a Titan 2 missile silo has been acquitted by a military jury.

LEAD: The long and often bitter era of military rule came to an end in Chile today with the installation of Patricio Aylwin, a genial Christian Democrat and longtime political figure, as the elected successor to Gen. Augusto Pinochet.
LEAD: AN advertising man who once battled for the wallets of the wealthy on behalf of Mercedes-Benz will now be fighting for the hearts and minds of citizens concerned about drug cartels in Colombia.

LEAD: Stock-car racing, a peculiarly American sport, could not be more foreign to CARY ELWES, who was reared in London. So to prepare for his role in ''Days of Thunder'' with TOM CRUISE, he went to the source, the Daytona 500 and the Winston 500, to associate with drivers.

LEAD: There was a birthday party here last week for Dana Madolciu, who turned 34, and in a number of ways it illustrated the remarkable changes that have taken place in Romanian households since the overthrow of President Nicolae Ceausescu in December.

LEAD: College basketball's troubled season turned toward its traditional upbeat conclusion yesterday when the pairings for the 64 teams of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's basketball tournament were announced in a national telecast from Kansas City, Mo.

LEAD: Striking teachers said today that they would continue their statewide school walkout until Gov. Gaston Caperton called a special legislative session to deal with their demands for a pay increase and financing of higher education.

LEAD: Fashion in the office has taken a truly odd turn. Sit at a typical in-office meeting and it's hard to miss. The men, mostly, come without their jackets. The women, to a woman, come with their jackets on. Men show no compunction about displaying generous paunches. Women hide their unbusiness-like chests and not-so-flat stomachs.
LEAD: Michael Stewart, who as British Foreign Secretary in the late 1960's became involved in efforts to end the Vietnam War, died on Saturday in London. He was 83 years old.
LEAD: Towers Perrin, the consulting and reinsurance organization, said yesterday that it had named John T. Lynch as president and designated him as the next chief executive.

It is owned by MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., a company controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, and by the Texas banker Gerald J. Ford.

LEAD: There were ghosts all over the ice and one even behind the bench: former forwards, former defensemen, a former goaltender, a former coach. But for the Rangers, without doubt, the most haunting aspect of last night's game at the Garden was that they played like their former selves.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This was supposed to be the election year in which Congress tamed its urge to send free mail to constituents. But the House of Representatives seems destined again to overspend its postal allowance.

LEAD: ''I've participated in the binge of irresponsibility,'' says Representative Dan Rostenkowski. ''But, no more,'' vows the blunt chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Writing in The Washington Post, Mr. Rostenkowski outlines a bold plan to attack the Federal budget deficit with a combination of new taxes and spending cuts.
LEAD: Responding to a growing democracy movement, Mongolia's Communist leaders proposed giving up their monopoly on power and held out the prospect of free elections.

LEAD: Turtles crawled the earth and swam in its waters before the dinosaurs appeared. Now they are facing the first broad-scale threat to their future in 200 million years, and some of the world's leading conservation organizations are gearing up to combat it.

LEAD: Roy S. Roberts, a fast-rising executive who abruptly left General Motors 18 months ago to take a job at Navistar, is returning to G.M. at a rank below his previous one to take over the top manufacturing post at the No. 1 auto maker's Cadillac division.

LEAD: Lawrence K. Fish, who last week became chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation, said today that he plans to reduce the troubled holding company's work force, continue selling assets and possibly sell subsidiaries.

LEAD: The new made-for-cable movie ''Fellow Traveler'' carries some significant credits: It was produced by Home Box Office and the BBC in association with the British Film Institute. The subject of the HBO Showcase presentation - which can be seen tonight at 11:30 - is blacklisting and red-baiting in Hollywood during the 1950's.

LEAD: Differing with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, a top Pentagon expert on Soviet affairs has endorsed the assessment of William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, that there is little chance of renewed Soviet dominance over Eastern Europe if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ousted by hard-liners.
LEAD: Raymond C. McCron, former senior vice president and treasurer of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died of lung cancer on Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: President Bush will ask Congress this week to provide the newly elected government of Nicaragua with $300 million in assistance to rehabilitate the country's war-ravaged economy, Administration officials said tonight.

LEAD: With the cheers from Chile's return to democracy still ringing in his ears, President Patricio Aylwin moved today to address the most troublesome problem he has inherited: old political crimes and political prisoners.

LEAD: The Soviet Parliament struggled with the nation's long history of centralized and dictatorial authority today as critics and proponents agreed that the executive powers proposed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would give him broad new control over the life of the nation.

LEAD: H. George Decancq, who was in charge of construction of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, died of Parkinson's disease last Tuesday in a nursing home in Rochester. He was 88 years old and had lived in Lakehurst, N.J., until he entered the nursing home three years ago.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in sluggish trading yesterday, largely on continued strength in the dollar. Traders said a dip in the price of oil and other commodities also provided support, but for the most part activity was listless.

LEAD: When MARILYN MONROE died in 1962, she left 75 percent of her estate to LEE STRASBERG, who had been her coach at the Actors' Studio, and 25 percent to DR. MARIANNE KRIS, her psychiatrist. Yesterday ANNA STRASBERG, Mr. Strasberg's widow, lost her challenge to get control of that 25 percent of the estate.

LEAD: ''Rembrandt's Landscapes: Drawings and Prints,'' which opened Sunday at the National Gallery of Art, will give pleasure to anyone who likes Rembrandt and anyone who likes prints and drawings. What the exhibition will not do is provide a way of coming to terms with the polemics that have thrown almost everything about Rembrandt into question.
LEAD: The old Barge Inn on River Road along the Hudson River here has a new name and spiffy new decor, but it is still a drinker's bar.

LEAD: The Government of Luxembourg plans to establish a stock market watchdog agency to deal with insider trading, a Finance Ministry official said today. The planned bourse commissariat is part of draft legislation approved recently by the Government making insider trading a criminal offense, said the official, who asked not to be identified.

LEAD: The Bush Administration signaled interest today in Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan to raise certain taxes and freeze domestic spending, while Democratic colleagues of the House Ways and Means Committee chairman responded with far more caution.

LEAD: Stung by a defector's charge that the K.G.B. once conspired to assassinate Pope John Paul II, the Soviet Union said today that it had complained strongly to the State Department that such accusations were ''clearly'' engineered by the Central Intelligence Agency.

LEAD: Blues revues, which flourished from the 1940's through the 60's, were roof-raising fun. We had already passed the McDonald's where, we imagined, Shakespeare had written ''Twelfth Night.'' (Or was it ''As You Like It'' at Burger King?) As we later wolfed down curry just in time to make the curtain at the Royal Shakespeare Company's evening performance of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' we concluded that we had finally found a Stratford restaurant the Bard might have missed.

LEAD: Maurice Saatchi said today that he and his brother, Charles, were cutting their $1 million salaries by 30 percent and that the other directors of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company were taking 10 percent pay cuts. LEAD: Although most music lovers know the name of the Swiss composer Frank Martin, few in this country have heard much of his music. And since Martin was an independent spirit who ranged widely in the slow development of his mature style, including a serious flirtation with serialism, fewer still have any distinct impression of his idiom.

LEAD: ENOUGH of this kid stuff. Now that peanut butter is 100 years old, let's face facts and stop beating around the bush. Isn't it time for peanut butter to grow up? But this country is still serving most of its peanut butter with jelly when so many other parts of the world are using it subtly to enhance stews, thicken soups, or top grilled fish.

LEAD: History remembers Alessandro Scarlatti for the same wrong reasons as it does Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach. The first is known as the father of a famous son (Domenico), the second as the son of a famous father (Johann Sebastian). Yet from his musical stronghold in Naples, the elder Scarlatti dominated Italian opera in the latter half of the 17th century much as the younger Bach presided over Central Europe's transition from Baroque to Classical style about 75 years later.

LEAD: Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood's defense lawyers rested today without calling him to the stand to give his own description of the Exxon Valdez grounding, which resulted in the nation's worst oil spill. Captain Hazelwood, from Huntington, L.I., is charged with one felony and three misdemeanor counts stemming from the spill of nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in Alaska a year ago.

LEAD: DESPITE Mikhail S. Gorbachev's high standing abroad and his unopposed election as the Soviet Union's first Executive President, his popularity appears to be sinking like a stone with his own people as a result of his failure to deliver on his economic promises.

LEAD: Since John Purtle left the Arkansas Supreme Court, its deliberations have gone far more smoothly. His former colleagues can break for lunch sooner and wrap things up earlier in the afternoon. Above all, there are fewer - far fewer - dissents.

LEAD: This year's New Directors/New Films festival begins this evening with Go Takemine's ''Untamagiru,'' a colorful, satiric but often obscure variation on what is said to be a famous Okinawan folk legend. The film will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art at 6 P.M. and again at 3 P.M. on Sunday.

LEAD: The body of a woman found stuffed in a wooden crate last week at a bus stop on West End Avenue was identified yesterday as a Manhattan actress who the police said had been feuding with her brother over a family inheritance.

LEAD: In a stinging report issued yesterday, the commission examining the New York City public school system said the work of the Board of Education's chief investigative arm was ''reminiscent of the Keystone Kops'' and deserved blame for much of the corruption and crime within the system.

LEAD: Kathryn Bigelow's police thriller ''Blue Steel'' gets off to a brilliant start as it introduces the bright, eager rookie Megan Turner (Jamie Lee Curtis) and meticulously examines the tools of her trade. With fetishistic fascination, Ms. Bigelow inventories every feature of Megan's brand-new uniform and, at the police academy's graduation ceremony, captures the tears of hope and idealism in her eyes.

LEAD: In a three-day nationwide sweep of businesses, Federal investigators found 7,000 children who appeared to be working under illegal conditions, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced today.
LEAD: The bedrock legal principle of caveat emptor - ''let the buyer beware'' - applies just as much to ghosts as to shady Florida land deals, a judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

LEAD: THE country-fund mania that swept share prices to a 31 percent premium at the end of January is subsiding. This means there may be some attractive investments soon in these funds that buy stocks in companies of a single country or region, analysts say.

LEAD: In a government-subsidized building in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx, a man in his early 60's shares a one-bedroom apartment with three relatives - his son, his daughter-in-law and their 9-month-old daughter - without the knowledge of the landlord, the welfare office and anyone else who might take an interest in such an arrangement.

LEAD: Although some advertising executives worry that agencies are resisting the call to diversify the range of communications services they offer, there is increasing evidence that their message is getting through.

LEAD: President Bush will soon make major changes in his Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board, converting what has been a wide-ranging watchdog over the intelligence community into a far smaller panel of expert policy advisers, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Lorraine Lester, a producer who worked in theater, films and television, died after a heart attack on Wednesday in the Coronary Care Unit of the New Rochelle Medical Center. She was 88 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.
LEAD: A once-obscure bond, invented by Drexel Burnham Lambert to encourage financing for takeovers and leveraged buyouts, is now instead contributing to problems in the ''junk bond'' market.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits after Wednesday's strong rally and awaited the release of new economic statistics.

LEAD: Charles Pilling will conduct the Central City Chorus in psalm settings and motets by Felix Mendelssohn and Johannes Brahms, and Mendelssohn's Organ Sonata No. 1, at 7 P.M. on Sunday at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. The soloists are to be Elizabeth Pruett, soprano; Deborah Andrews, mezzo-soprano; Darrell Lauer, tenor; Richard Christopher, baritone, and Lawrence Maycher, organist.

LEAD: Local officials said today that they would begin making random inspections of bomb shelters owned by a church group whose members are ready to live underground because they fear an imminent nuclear attack.
LEAD: The hardest thing to handicap about the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park this Saturday is why nine horses were entered instead of 59.

LEAD: The conviction of a former leader of the Black Panther Party on attempted murder charges in the machine-gun attack on two New York City policemen in 1971 was reversed yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice. He ordered a new trial.

LEAD: It is carnival time at the Marquis Theater, where Franco Fontana's ''Oba Oba '90'' has settled in through April 22. LEAD: West Point-Pepperell Inc. announced yesterday that it had established a new $1.2 billion credit facility with its major banks. It includes a $550 million term loan and a revolving line of credit of up to $650 million. They mature on Dec. 31, 1994. Interest on both will be at 150 basis points more than the prime rate, and the interest rates will be automatically reduced if the company satisfies certain financial conditions.

LEAD: Holders of defaulted bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System could receive as much as 32 cents on the dollar or as little as 10 cents under an agreement announced today by two groups sharing a $753 million settlement fund.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums ''ABE LINCOLN AND THE COOL KID,'' a show by the Don Quixote Experimental Children's Theater, 10:30 A.M. today and on March 23, and 2 P.M. on Sunday, at the Lincoln Square Theater, 250 West 65th Street. Admission: weekdays, $2.50, $3; Sunday, $5. Information: 496-8009.
LEAD: Orlando was awarded the first World League of American Football franchise today as the National Football League club owners concluded their five-day meeting here.

LEAD: Every day the news about Covenant House grows grimmer. And every day, therefore, it becomes more urgent to reassure the conscientious citizens whose contributions support the organization. The survival of Covenant House requires a wholly new board of directors.

LEAD: At a time when theater ticket prices have reached $60, Playwrights Horizons is introducing a $5 ticket for two new productions at its second-floor Studio Theater at 416 West 42d Street. This springtime bargain, called the New Theater Wing, begins with ''Subfertile,'' a comedy by Tom Mardirosian about an anxious man celebrating his 40th birthday with a museum dinosaur skeleton.
LEAD: The Knicks lost the first time they played the Hornets in Charlotte. They did the same against the Heat the first time in Miami and the Magic in Orlando.

LEAD: After two days of meetings with Japanese Government officials, trading companies and political leaders, the United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, warned today that Japan's trade surpluses had ''achieved a semipermanent status.''

LEAD: An Ohio woman and her estranged husband, who were accused of an insider trading scheme involving the stock of Revco Drug Stores and two other companies, settled without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Federal regulators said today.

LEAD: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is dancing fantastically at the City Center, where its second program of the season, on Wednesday night, included the premiere of Mr. Cunningham's ''Inventions'' as well as ''Rainforest'' and ''Pictures'' -wondrous works both.

LEAD: Events in the yearlong investigation by the Board of Education's Inspector General into reports of drug abuse by Matthew Barnwell, the principal of P.S. 53 in the South Bronx at the time. Nove. 25, 1987: Michael P. Sofarelli, the Inspector General, receives memorandum from Howard S. Tames, the Deputy Executive Director of the Board of Education's Division of Personnel.

LEAD: A $390.6 million sale of certificates backed by home equity loans from the Goldome Savings Bank of St. Petersburg, Fla., and serviced by the Goldome Credit Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

LEAD: George Robert Lyon, an advertising executive, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco. He was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: Assemblywoman Aurelia Greene, her husband and a former Bronx school superintendent have been cleared by a jury on grand larceny and other charges stemming from the removal of a baby grand piano from a school to the Greenes' house in 1983.

LEAD: With the first free elections in this country only three days away, a conservative coalition allied with the West German Chancellor elected a longtime dissident as its leader today to replace a man who admitted he had been an undercover agent of the ousted Communist Government's secret police.

LEAD: The J & L Specialty Products Corporation agreed to be acquired by the French stainless steel producer Ugine Aciers de Chatillon et Gueugnon S.A. Terms were not disclosed. J & L said that it would keep its Pittsburgh headquarters and that the Paris-based Ugine would appoint a new board.

LEAD: Elmer L. Hann, an American shipbuilding executive who was instrumental in rebuilding Japan's industry after World War II, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Kuakini Medical Center in Honolulu. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: William Golding's ''Lord of the Flies,'' long a fashionable novel with adolescent readers or others with a taste for broad allegory, is now a fashionable-looking film. Shot in lavish color (unlike Peter Brook's much more stark black-and-white 1963 version), and so thoroughly Americanized that its characters bring with them the kind of light-sword used in ''Star Wars'' and make reference to the television show ''ALF,'' this ''Lord of the Flies'' features a cast of young actors seemingly chosen on the basis of lean physique and languid good looks.
LEAD: Three young men were stabbed, one fatally, during a fight last night with a group of youths on a street in the East Village, the police said.

LEAD: OPEC oil ministers will start a meeting on Friday in which they will wrestle with how to play a strong hand: essentially whether to settle for oil prices at about $18 a barrel or to try to raise them.
LEAD: The Soviet Parliament overwhelmingly rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence, but the resolution was stripped of vague threats of retaliation. Page A6.

LEAD: Until now, perhaps the most maligned entrepreneurs in this city were its ''tin men,'' the fast-talking aluminum-siding salesmen depicted in a 1987 Barry Levinson movie of the same name. But if some newly proposed legislation is enacted, the tin men may be displaced by lawyers.
LEAD: Dr. John Adrian Onderdonk Jr., chief of cardiology at the Chestnut Hill Hospital in Philadelphia, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Radnor, Pa. He was 55 years old.

LEAD: Since 1935, scientists have dreamed of converting hydrogen into a metal with wonderful properties. Now, physicists have reported here that they are a little closer to that elusive goal.

LEAD: For several years so much attention has focused on Manhattan's downtown dining scene that one could forget there is anyplace to eat above 79th Street. While it is true that most gastronomic tributaries flow south, it is reassuring to paddle upstream and find some places holding their own.

LEAD: ''I've never been to New York on St. Patrick's Day before,'' said Shane MacGowan, lead singer for the Irish band the Pogues, in a recent telephone interview from London. ''I've got mates who've been there, and they say it's mad.''

LEAD: Stocks marked time yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 7.88, to 2,695.72, in the fourth day of light volume this week. With interest rates on bonds remaining almost unchanged, traders had no clear sign of the way stocks might go.

LEAD: PRESIDENT BUSH says REPRESENTATIVE RICHARD A. GEPHARDT of Missouri, the House majority leader, really, truly, does not get under his skin, notwithstanding Mr. Gephardt's biting attacks on Mr. Bush's foreign policy. Yesterday, Mr. Gephardt put him to the test.

LEAD: Five years ago today in Beirut, in the clear light of a city that was just waking up to another weary morning of war, Terry A. Anderson played tennis for an hour on a court by the sea.

LEAD: It is self-evident that the people of Eastern Europe have much to gain from freedom and democracy. What is less obvious, but no less important, is what America can gain: billions in defense savings, thousands of jobs, new markets and a chance to pull our children from the brink of nuclear Armageddon.
LEAD: George Sands Hastings, a retired vice president of the American Machine and Foundry Company, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: It was Scott Fitzgerald who observed that the very rich are not like you and me - and not, as Hemingway retorted, because they have more money. The same might be said of the very poor, and that, too, it is not merely a matter of money.

LEAD: James Patrick, with a sobering visit to the hospital behind him and aware of a radically altered future, sat in the lobby of the Rangers' Toronto hotel early yesterday. The 26-year-old defenseman talked, paused, then shook his head over and over again.

LEAD: The Connecticut House and Senate on Wednesday approved legislation that allows out-of-state banks to buy Connecticut banks.
LEAD: A new poll conducted for a Democratic group underscores what many Democrats feared: The voters have little sense of what the Democratic-controlled Congress is doing.
LEAD: More bad news for the Perrier crowd.

LEAD: When the Monty Python troupe celebrated its 20th birthday last year, two documentaries were made by Tiger Television for the BBC for the occasion. They are now being presented on the Showtime pay-cable channel under the very appropriate umbrella title ''20 Odd Years.'' The first part, produced by Mark Redhead, is ''Life of Python,'' a collection of interviews with the performers, whose recollections are illustrated with clips from their television shows and films.
LEAD: Someone apparently forgot to tell 16th-seeded Murray State it had little chance to win its opening-round game with top-seeded Michigan State today in the Southeast Regional.

LEAD: Nancy Klein of Long Island, 10 weeks pregnant, was severely injured in a car crash on Dec. 13, 1988. For two months she was in a coma. Doctors had little hope that she would come out of it, but they thought she might have a better chance if she had an abortion. Her husband, Martin, told them to go ahead.

LEAD: In recent years the upstart personal computer known as a work station has spoiled the minicomputer business by attaining comparable speed at far lower prices. Now comes the first independent confirmation that a new work station from the International Business Machines Corporation can solve certain scientific problems faster than even one of the most powerful supercomputers.

LEAD: On the day baseball officials plan to announce the cancellation of the first games of the regular season, the owners' bargaining committee will make a new proposal to the union today in an effort to end the dispute that has kept spring training camps closed for four weeks.

LEAD: Fifty-one years to the day after Hitler arrived here at the head of an occupying army, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today greeted the President of West Germany with a speech that equated anti-German feeling with anti-Semitism, and an offer to build a Europe free of recriminations.
LEAD: A bomb explosion destroyed a mosque in western France today in what the police described as the latest manifestation of racial tensions in this country.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Harold R. Medina, a Federal judge for more than three decades, who achieved lasting fame for his handling of the trial of 11 Communist leaders in the 1940's, died in his sleep on Wednesday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., where he was admitted on Monday with a slight fever, his grandson Standish Forde Medina Jr.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on Tuesday about a contract vote at the International Paper Company mill in Jay, Me., referred incorrectly to proceedings to remove the United Paperworkers International Union as bargaining agent for employees. An employee, not the company, filed the petition with the National Labor Relations Board for decertification.

LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Administration was studying plans to enlarge the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission that would strip at least some authority from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: A subsidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation will sell a specialty chemical business to the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, a West German company, for an undisclosed price, officials said. The Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company said it had reached an agreement to sell its primary alcohol ethoxylates business.

LEAD: Mikhail Bulgakov's novel ''Heart of a Dog'' is a malicious political parable on what the author envisioned as the inevitable corruption of a socialist state. Written in 1925 (and unpublished in the Soviet Union until 1987), the book follows the rise and fall of a mongrel scientifically transformed into a man but unable to avoid the curse of atavism.

LEAD: The Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency managing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, today approved its first program to sell the housing stock of failed savings institutions to low- and medium-income families.

LEAD: For two years JOHN F. KENNEDY JR. has worked on a program to provide additional training for people working with the handicapped. Together with administrators at the City University of New York and health professionals, he helped develop Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities Studies, which started last month at the College of Staten Island.

LEAD: ''All we can tell you now is that the five of us have the deepest conviction that Mongolian society should be entirely renewed, that democracy should develop, that all human rights should be insured, and that social justice must prevail.'' - Gombojavyn Ochirbat, the new General Secretary of the Mongolian Communist Party.

LEAD: Of the Islanders' 11 defeats and three ties in their 14-game slump, tonight's 5-4 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers was among the most maddening. One Islander showed his frustration at the final buzzer with a display of temper that might draw a review from league authorities.

LEAD: The Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation said yesterday that the president of its American operations had resigned. Steven Fellingham, 44 years old, had been president of Kentucky Fried Chicken-USA since May 1988. He resigned yesterday to ''join another company,'' Kentucky Fried Chicken said in a statement.

LEAD: After 40 minutes of all-out effort and emotion, the Princeton Tigers left the Erwin Center tonight with sad faces and nothing to savor. The end result was another gut-wrenching post-season defeat.
LEAD: It took 22 years and 10 trips to the National Invitation Tournament, but Fordham finally won another N.I.T. game last night.
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that financial results for its second fiscal quarter, which will end March 30, will be better than previously expected.

LEAD: Six months after opening talks on the deep-rooted causes of their trade problems, Japan and the United States are dissatisfied with each other's concessions. And the Japanese are fearful that the discussions themselves are making tensions even worse.

LEAD: Nearly 9,000 miles from the Supreme Court, on the Pacific island of Guam, a territorial legislature has passed the most restrictive abortion legislation in the United States, a measure that explicitly challenges the constitutional right to abortion that was established in the landmark Roe v. Wade case.

LEAD: Having ruled this West African country with nearly absolute power for three decades, President Felix Houphouet-Boigny is under increasing political challenge amid growing economic and social disarray.

LEAD: Terry Waite's entry in Britain's Who's Who reads the same today as it did more than three years ago, when he disappeared in Beirut on a mission to negotiate the release of Western hostages. Listed among his interests are ''international affairs and politics'' and ''travel (especially in remote parts of the world).

LEAD: With the Karl Lagerfeld opening on Friday, the serious part of the French fall and winter showings began. Not too serious, of course. Not with bracelets worn three at a time on the sleeves of jackets - on the upper arm, just below the elbow and at the wrist. Or single earrings dangling past the bosom, or elaborate gold medallions on the chest.
LEAD: The Bolshoi Ballet has announced an American tour, to open with a two-week residency at the New York State Theater from July 10 to 22.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Xtra Corporation referred incorrectly to a proxy contest between the management of the USX Corporation and Carl C. Icahn. Mr. Icahn has proposed spinning off USX's steel business, not unseating the company's board.

LEAD: Situated on a broad plain, this city of 142,000 has much in common with other German urban centers: a ducal castle with vestiges of a moat, a university, medium-sized industries, a splendid museum, handsomely restored patrician houses and remarkably clean streets.
LEAD: Housing starts fell 7 percent in February but remained well above the level of the last 11 months of 1989, the Government reported today. Analysts said the building pace could not be sustained.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Brian Leetch, the accomplished young Ranger defenseman, underwent two hours of surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan yesterday to repair his fractured left ankle and a torn ligament. He suffered the injuries in the Rangers' 8-2 victory Wednesday night over the Maple Leafs in Toronto.

LEAD: Thousands of people who want to become homeowners find themselves further away from their goal each year because of high interest rates and high prices. The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, recently introduced a ''two-step'' mortgage for first-time buyers, and now 80 lenders around the country offer it.

LEAD: The American physician who is widely credited with organizing the United Nations' worldwide fight against AIDS resigned today in what he said was a dispute with his boss, the head of the World Health Organization.

LEAD: John Taras, associate artistic director of American Ballet Theater, resigned on Thursday. Mr. Taras cited artistic differences with Jane Hermann, who was named co-director of the company with Oliver Smith on March 7, as the reason for his resignation. Mrs. Hermann said the decision had been mutually agreed upon.

LEAD: Some political analysts here fret that the West's preoccupation with Eastern Europe has pushed Turkey onto a back burner - even worse, perhaps off the stove - in its dogged pursuit of full membership in the European Community.

LEAD: With some of the biggest companies in the United States leading the way, Hungary has become corporate America's main port of entry into Eastern Europe. In recent months, General Electric, General Motors, Levi Strauss, McDonald's and others have set up businesses in Hungary, and the stream of American concerns seeking joint ventures here is accelerating daily.

LEAD: It took Jim Florio only a few months to admit something he wasn't prepared to concede last fall when he was running for governor: New Jersey needs new taxes. The time has come, Mr. Florio said this week, to confront ''harsh realities and hard decisions.'' He then unveiled a budget with $1.4 billion in tax increases.

LEAD: The General Development Corporation said today that it had agreed to plead guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the Federal mail fraud law.

LEAD: The delinqency rate for home mortgages held steady in the final three months of 1989 after jumping sharply in the previous quarter, a trade group said this week. The group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said a seasonally adjusted 4.99 percent of mortgage payments on one-to-four-family homes were 30 days or more late.
LEAD: The idea of a central committee putting together a five-year plan for agricultural production seems archaic in the age of perestroika. But that's exactly what we are about to see in Congress.
LEAD: William J. Simmer, public-affairs director of the Regional Plan Association, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 39 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The former Communist Party, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, wound up its campaign tonight for Sunday's first free parliamentary elections in East Germany with the largest and most enthusiastic rallies the capital has seen.

LEAD: John S. Vento, regarded as a major prosecution witness in the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Bensonhurst until he changed his mind about testifying, was indicted yesterday on charges of second-degree murder. Bail was denied, and he remained in jail. Mr. Vento, who had agreed to testify in exchange for immunity from prosecution, fled in December.

LEAD: A delegation of American Jewish leaders met with Pope John Paul II in Rome yesterday, ending the two-year hiatus in such high-level audiences brought on by tensions over the existence of a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.

LEAD: Japanese financiers are making a strong push to expand their role in financing new office buildings in the United States just as American banks, dismayed by shrinking profit margins and loan losses from a glut of unoccupied buildings, are becoming more cautious and cutting back.

LEAD: The Bush Administration welcomes efforts by the Baltic States to free themselves from Moscow's grasp. It also refuses to grant diplomatic recognition and economic aid. That position is principled and practical.

LEAD: Jumper cables are usually sure bets for starting cars with battery trouble, but using them properly is essential. The cables' jaws have to be properly attached to a working battery in another car. Here's how.

LEAD: Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, one of India's most prominent political figures, resigned from Prime Minister V. P. Singh's administration today, threatening to split the ruling coalition. Mr. Lal, a peasant leader from the northern state of Haryana, did not give reasons for his resignation. It followed a bitter campaign against him and his son, the Chief Minister of Haryana, by critics in the Singh Cabinet and the press.

LEAD: James Ortman, president of J. Ortman Inc., a Manhattan jewelry concern, died on Tuesday at New York University Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan and Quogue, L.I.
LEAD: Three of the six defendants in the Central Park rape case were ordered yesterday to stand trial on April 16. The three others were ordered to be tried later.

LEAD: PAUL O'DWYER got a St. Patrick's Day plum yesterday when Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS appointed him Commissioner for the United Nations and Consular Corps. A former City Council president, political powerhouse and activist in Irish causes, Mr. O'Dwyer, 82 years old, had lobbied for a job in the city administration.

LEAD: Investigate before you invest has long been a watchword on Wall Street. But when it comes to buying a retirement home, particularly in a distant state or country, the purchase is all too often made site unseen. Others travel to the area they are interested in and see only real-estate salespeople.

LEAD: Rockefeller Center, Columbia Pictures, CBS Records. What other American icons do the Japanese want to buy? They can have it all. Here in the Tarrytowns, we've learned that Japanese corporations, and not American ones, make the best neighbors.

LEAD: San Francisco and Charleston, S.C., radio and television stations won Peabody Awards on Thursday for their coverage of two natural disasters: the earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area last October and the hurricane that swept the Carolinas and the Caribbean last September.

LEAD: Four pairs of feet held a party on Monday night at the Top of the Village Gate. Those feet were fine company. So were the people attached to them. They'll be having parties every Monday night for the rest of this month at the Gate, at Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

LEAD: With the prosecution rapidly winding down its case against John M. Poindexter, a former aide to the National Security Council testified today that Mr. Poindexter expressed his dislike and distrust of Congress as lawmakers were pressing him in 1986 to explain the White House role in aiding the Nicaraguan contras.

LEAD: Horace Reynolds Moorhead, a retired treasurer of the former Gulf Oil Corporation who served as a financial officer of several other companies, died of heart disease on Monday at a retirement village in Bryn Mawr. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Slightly more than 4,000 U S West Inc. managers and administrators have accepted the company's latest voluntary retirement program, a U S West spokesman, Dick MacKnight, said. He said 4,022 people left the payroll last month.

LEAD: Jim R. Lyons, a retired management consultant and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Thursday while vacationing at Las Brisas Hotel in Acapulco, Mexico. He was 69 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: The public is fed up with the oil industry's sloppiness. There are thousands of oil spills a year, many of them dribbles, a few disasters. Last week a barge exploded in the Arthur Kill waterway, which runs between Staten Island and New Jersey, sending 100,000 gallons of home heating oil into waters near the Pralls Island bird sanctuary.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.34 percent, up from 10.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.55 percent this week, up from 8.5 percent the week before.
LEAD: The sight of Georgetown's 7-foot-2-inch center, Dikembe Mutombo, was intimidating enough for Texas Southern today. But his 18 points, 16 rebounds and 3 blocked shots were too much.

LEAD: Abraham Hershson, a retired manufacturing company executive and a philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.
LEAD: The Iranian-born journalist hanged as a spy by Iraq on Thursday was described today as a convicted bank robber who had been sentenced in 1981 to 18 months in a British jail.

LEAD: The momentum is growing now to speed integration of the European Community as the best way to deal with the dramatic changes going on. Some old arguments about states versus supranationalism are resurfacing.
LEAD: Stocks rallied strongly in spirited trading yesterday for the week's best gain by far, with the much-anticipated ''triple witching hour'' playing a significant role.
LEAD: Cheered by his first visit to Brazil in 30 years, Fidel Castro said today that Latin American markets could make up for the loss of trading partners in Eastern Europe.
LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today vetoed a bill that would have reinstated the death penalty in New York, as he has done in each of the last seven years.

LEAD: Because of the St. Patrick's Day Parade today, a number of streets in Manhattan will be closed. The parade begins at 11:30 A.M. at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue and heads north to 86th Street. Streets will close at 10:30 A.M. and reopen around 2:30 P.M.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Two Brooklyn men, one of them a Brinks Armored Car guard, were arrested and charged with selling two kilos of heroin to undercover F.B.I. agents, the authorities said today.

LEAD: The engagement of Amy Allyson Brown to John William Fraser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth William Fraser Jr. of Eden, N.C., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Sherburne Carleton Brown of Southampton, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Ms. Brown, who is 28 years old, is a graduate of Southampton High School and Cornell University.

LEAD: I have been a dedicated dyed-in-the-Ranger-blue fan for more than 30 years. I, and many others like me, know. We know that if the Rangers obtained Gretzky, Lemixeux, Yzerman, Coffey, Borque and Messier, they would probably manage not to win the cup. Why? The answer, we know is simple but takes a lifetime to truly understand.

LEAD: The first signs of spring are already evident at the Conservatory Garden, a formal garden tucked away in the northeast corner of Central Park.
LEAD: Poor little bulldozers wagging their tails at Suffolk County's pine barrens. All they want to do is to clear a few more trees.

LEAD: IN HOW MANY FILMS have I seen the touching episode of the father tossing a football to his son, or shooting hoops or going fishing? Hemingway used to drag his toddler along while he blasted ducks out of the sky. Even Paul Simon plays baseball with his kid.
LEAD: Few who were there Friday night will ever forget it. Perhaps some of the details will fade, but the emotion will linger in memory.

LEAD: The killings of two policemen in January were bad enough. But after gunmen in recent weeks killed a leading lawyer and a prominent newspaper columnist, in street attacks in Ankara and Istanbul, Turks have begun nervously asking themselves whether they are back to the terrorism that led to a military coup in 1980.
LEAD: Lithuana today rejected a deadline set by Moscow for renouncing the republic's independence and it appealed to ''democratic nations'' to recognize the newly declared state.

LEAD: Repeatedly throughout the article [''Pine Barrens Suit Halts Construction,'' Feb. 25] , the developers made the point that their development in the Pine Barrens would solve the areas economic problems by creating new jobs and/or new housing. Donald Patrick reasoned that some 6,000 Manorville residents would greatly benefit from having their jobs closer to home.

LEAD: O.K., class, clear your desks; it's time for a quiz. Today is March 18. That means the season is: (A) winter, (B) spring, (C)summer or (D) all of the above. The correct answer, as anyone who has been in New York City the last few days knows, is D. Those who are majoring in fashion appreciation also know that this is also called a transitional period, when the weather is a bit too warm for heavy winter wools but, most days at least, a little too brisk for lightweight clothes.

LEAD: In Garry Marshall's new romantic fantasy, a pretty woman is seen walking down the street, and she is indeed - as Roy Orbison sings - the kind you ''like to meet.'' But in this post-modern Cinderella story, with Shavian overtones and Los Angeles locales, the heroine happens to be a hooker. And the man who would be her Prince is a mendacious corporate raider whose only regal trait is a passion for opera, specifically Verdi.

LEAD: The most powerful word-processing programs have been borrowing features from desktop publishing programs for some time, allowing people who work with words to embellish their documents with graphics, illustrations, multiple columns and fancy typography. Now, a new generation of desktop publishing programs is borrowing features from the word-processing programs, including spelling checkers, search-and-replace abilities, document templates (or style sheets) and other features that make editing easier.

LEAD: The rain began to fall just a few hours after Henri Matisse installed himself in the Hotel Villa de France in Tangier at the end of January, 1912. For days it poured. ''Shall we ever see the sun in Morocco?'' the artist complained in a letter to Gertrude Stein after his first week.
LEAD: FOR those who listen closely, a new debate on American policy toward the Soviet Union can be heard stirring in Washington.
LEAD: The goaltending, the defense, the special teams, the offense - everything worked effectively for the Devils tonight in their 4-1 triumph over the Oilers at the Northlands Coliseum.

LEAD: A census taker in this southern Mississippi town was shot Thursday by a 71-year-old man who said he had been pestered lately by boisterous teen-agers. The census taker, Harmon Broome, 52 years old, was treated at a hospital for face and neck wounds and discharged Friday. His assailant was identified as Cornelius Starks, who was charged with aggravated assault.

LEAD: The State Department said today that President Bush has released an additional $10 million to help resettle Vietnamese refugees, most of whom have gone to crowded camps in Hong Kong after dangerous sea voyages.

LEAD: WITH the major league baseball season threatened by a labor dispute, some college teams may be trying to fill the gap by extending their own seasons a bit. That, at least, seemed to be the case in Seattle on Friday when four teams played four consecutive extra-inning games against each other. As a result, what would have normally been 36 innings of baseball turned into a 49-inning, 17-hour marathon that lasted from 9 A.M.

LEAD: The Law Review of Stanford University, one of the most prestigious law journals in the nation, has elected Shauna D. Jackson president. A second-year law student from Olathe, Kan., she is the first black woman to head the law review here.

LEAD: Through his Cable News Network, Ted Turner has viewers in some 90 countries, and he wants them to know that as far as he is concerned, they are not just a bunch of foreigners. In a memo to news personnel last week, Mr. Turner banned the use of the word ''foreign'' where the word ''international'' will do.

LEAD: Over the last few years in the entertainment industry, independent record companies have been selling like food during a famine. LEAD: Last year I got a B.A. in philosophy. Now I am waiting tables, writing, and taking pictures; it's a beginning. I'm not sure what will come of it, but I do know that I won't spend my years parading other people's causes, not that it's not useful, it's that I've made other choices. Nor will I wear $200 paisley ties, the usefulness of which I would call into question.

LEAD: ''HE was the first citizen of Rochester, the Kodak king,'' said William Seale, a former White House historian who oversaw the recent $1.8 million restoration of the George Eastman House in Rochester. The house, a National Historic Landmark, reopened to the public Jan. 30, having been closed for 14 months.

LEAD: In some ways, it seemed astonishing for Mayor Richard M. Daley, son and namesake of this city's most famous political boss and kingmaker, to belittle the importance of political parties.
