LEAD: Julio Cesar Chavez knocked out Meldrick Taylor in the final seconds of a spirited 12-round bout between junior welterweight champions here at the Hilton Hotel tonight, but it was a controversial ending. Chavez was behind on two of the judges' cards at the time that Referee Richard Steele stopped the fight with just two seconds remaining.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Investigators said today that they had pinpointed a leak in a propane gas line near a bank where an explosion killed three employees and injured 14 other people last week.
LEAD: Tens of thousands of people marched through Baghdad and surrounded the British Embassy today to denounce Britain's protest against Iraq's execution of a London-based journalist.
LEAD: Re: '''Caller ID' Stirs Debate on Phone Privacy,'' Feb. 11:

LEAD: Mrs. Ryland Ellis Dickinson Chase of New York has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Rebecca Ellis Chase and William Leggette Hughes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Hughes of Durham, N.C. The prospective bride is also a daughter of the late Mr. Chase.

LEAD: Faced with widespread pressure from Congress and elsewhere, the Bush Administration has decided to retreat on the 1991 military budget and accept cuts almost as large as those that lawmakers are urging, senior Government officials say.

LEAD: VERGING ON THE PERTINENT. By Carol Emshwiller (Coffee House Press, Paper, $9.95.) When the aliens land, I hope Carol Emshwiller is around to explain what's up with Earth women these days. She certainly knows how to take the Martian view of ordinary domestic life - how to get at the truth of things by rendering them strange.

LEAD: With the arrival of cable television, VCR's and video rental stores, futurologists predicted that Saturday nights at the Bijou would go the way of community sings. Why would people stand in long lines, pay $7 and suffer whisperers in a cramped movie house when they could be home in their jammies eating microwaved popcorn with an incredible choice of things to see?

LEAD: There is no question that Roger Neilson's coaching and the addition of Bernie Nicholls and Mike Gartner have enabled the Rangers to become true Stanley Cup contenders. But the Rangers will lose in the Wales Conference championship to either Buffalo or Montreal. LESLIE A. WINOKUR New York

LEAD: Men's fashion moves forward not by leaps but by small steps, and changes are often imperceptible. All the more reason to welcome the spring of 1990 as a season of real - and sometimes radical - shifts in style. Conventional tailoring hasn't been scrapped so much as re-examined, with the emphasis on comfort, mobility and self-expression.

LEAD: AHMED JIBRIL, A PAUNCHY , avuncular man with a fondness for colorful sports clothes, was born in 1937, in the village of Yazur, near Jaffa, in what was then Palestine. After the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, he left with his family and settled in Syria. In Damascus, he attended the military college, becoming a demolition expert.

LEAD: North Carolina proved something today to Oklahoma, to the rest of the country and to a tournament committee that seeded the Tar Heels eighth in their region. And by defeating the country's No. 1-ranked team, North Carolina established itself as a legitimate contender for the national championship.
LEAD: A GRACEFUL PASSAGE Notes on the Freedom to Live or Die. By Arnold R. Beisser. 229 pp. New York: Doubleday. $16.95.

LEAD: For the finale of his one-man clown show, ''Feast of Fools,'' Geoff Hoyle does something incomparable with his three legs. All three are trousered and shod and they peep out from under a long greatcoat. Mr. Hoyle walks on stage at the Westside Arts Theater as if it were the most natural thing in the world to be a triped.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''A World of Butterflies in Florida'' stirred happy memories of seeing butterflies last winter at Callaway Gardens in Georgia. Seventy miles southwest of Atlanta, Callaway has the largest glass-enclosed butterfly house in the country. Tropical vines and shrubs and cascading water plus computer climate control keep butterflies flying all year.

LEAD: Anne Elizabeth Segrest, an associate in the law firm of Gordon & Barnett, and Edgar H. McCulloch 3d, a lobbyist for the Service Employees International Union, both in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Calvin Chesnutt performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Athens,

LEAD: WHEN Archduke Otto of Habsburg recently revisited Hungary on two separate occasions, he stayed at the Gellert Hotel on the west bank of the Danube River. It was the newest and most sumptuous establishment in town when he was last in the country - in 1918, as a 5-year-old prince. If, like the Archduke, you are the son of the last Emperor of Austria-Hungary, and if, furthermore, you are able to enchant Hungarians by your fluency in their language, as the 77-year-old Archduke and member of the European Parliament does, you can presumably pick your own hotel even on short notice.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical
LEAD: The criminal trial of the Rev. Al Sharpton, one of New York City's most flamboyant and vocal civil rights leaders, is set to begin tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: Q. The cement deck around our swimming pool has become dark and dirty looking. Scrubbing with bleach solutions has not helped much. Do you know of anything we can use to make the deck look nice again?

LEAD: Kathryn Watterson and Ronald L. Sitts were married yesterday at the John Maclean House at Princeton University. The Rev. Alvin Ahern, a Methodist minister who is an uncle of the bride, performed the nondenominational ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Haines Slingluff Jr. of Rumson, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Melissa King Slingluff and Christopher John Morley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Morley of Lloyd Neck, L.I.

LEAD: IT is well known that San Juan's major hotels have gambling casinos and nightclubs in which one can hear slick popularizations of Latin culture, but what is less familiar is the city's many venues for music, dance and film. Even if you don't gamble and don't like nightclubs, you can usually find something interesting to do in the temperate evenings.

LEAD: Mrs. Mandeville Mullally of Lawrence, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter Amanda Mandeville Mullally to Matthew Bouvy Drake, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Griffith Drake of Portland, Ore. Miss Mullally also is a daughter of the late Mr. Mullally Jr. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: About 12,000 gallons of the chemical solvent cumene spilled aboard a tanker in the Delaware River during unloading this morning, forcing the evacuation of about 250 people from a three-block area. Five workers at a pier near the spill were treated at a hospital for headaches and nausea after breathing the fumes of the chemical.

LEAD: Farmingdale $175,000 97 Lawrence Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1- car garage; taxes $3,400. Kings Park $235,000 9 Sesame Street 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; family room, new kitchen, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $6,700.

LEAD: Hearing loss is not a reportable disease. There are no official statistics. But doctors suspect that this incurable ailment is becoming epidemic and that the willful or ignorant misuse of audio equipment is a major cause.
LEAD: Tennis
LEAD: I read with considerable interest your story on News 12 Long Island's coverage of the Avianca plane crash (Feb. 4).

LEAD: GOV. JIM FLORIO'S sweeping transformation of the state's automobile insurance regulations is being criticized by industry officials, business and medical professionals and legislators who say the new law is poorly conceived and will ultimately lead to even higher premiums for New Jersey drivers, who already pay some of the highest auto insurance rates in the nation.
LEAD: Diplomas, 40% Off

LEAD: ''EVERY day brings changes,'' said Alexey N. Mesiatsev, the deputy general director of Intourist in New York, ''not just in opening roads but in our societies.'' Asked how many miles of road in the Soviet Union were open to drivers from the West at the end of February, he smiled wistfully, implying that it was difficult to say.

LEAD: Appropriately enough, the ball ended up in Kenny Anderson's hands. And after surviving 10 blocked shots, a 15-point blitz by Louisiana State in the game's opening minutes, and a final, desperation shot by the Tigers' Maurice Williamson, Georgia Tech watched the last second tick off the clock in a breathtaking 94-91 victory over L.S.U.

LEAD: Tracy Lis had 23 points to lead Providence College, the Big East Conference champion, to a 77-75 victory over Maryland today in the second round of the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament.

LEAD: FROM the East Berlin side of the Brandenburg Gate to Wenceslas Square in Prague, Americans are discovering Eastern Europe in record numbers, particularly as the changes in governments there have led to the loosening of visa and customs procedures. However, the resulting confusion at border crossings and crowds in consulates may still mean lost time, effort and frustration for travelers.

LEAD: The way Kathleen Turner tells it, the first time she saw herself on the big screen she had much the same reaction as most viewers did. It was 1981; the movie was ''Body Heat,'' in which Ms. Turner, as the murderous seductress Mattie Walker, and William Hurt as Ned Racine, the lover she betrays, enact some of the sweatiest, most fevered scenes of passion that Hollywood has ever dared.

LEAD: CANNERY CAFE in the center of Canaan, in the state's northwest corner, is the kind of place weary travelers dream of finding, but rarely do, when passing through an unfamiliar town at mealtime. The modest storefront facade sends few signals of the delicious food that awaits within.
LEAD: Wines from California

LEAD: Until recently, visors were seen mostly on the beach, tennis court or fairway. And the ones for women generally came in pastel pink, blue or white. But that was before the shun-the-sun movement.
LEAD: Conflict on a Condo Board
LEAD: FLOATING IN MY MOTHER'S PALM By Ursula Hegi. 187 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $17.95.
LEAD: BOLSHEVIK SALUTE A Modernist Chinese Novel. By Wang Meng. Translated and with a critical essay by Wendy Larson. 154 pp. Seattle: University of Washington Press. $19.95.

LEAD: TODAY: East Germany holds national elections, with questions of economic and reunification issues foremost. TUESDAY: The Labor Department reports consumer prices for February. The Commerce Department releases the January merchandise trade balance. The British Government presents its annual budget.

LEAD: Representatives of striking drivers for Greyhound Lines presented a proposal here today in the first meeting between the bus company and the union since the violent strike began two weeks ago, but no details were disclosed.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AS a result of a state regulation aimed at limiting prescriptions for such tranquilizers as Valium, the use of such drugs has been cut in half, to 250,000 prescriptions a year in Nassau and 150,000 in Suffolk, according to State Department of Health officials.
LEAD: A front-page article last Sunday on air pollution and automobiles misidentified the group for which Michael Oppenheimer is a senior scientist. It is the Environmental Defense Fund, not the

LEAD: May wedding plans for Jennifer Monique Lacks and Howard Jay Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kaplan of New Rochelle, N.Y., have been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Sanford A. Lacks of Brookhaven, L.I.

LEAD: When President F. W. de Klerk announced last month that the Government would release Nelson Mandela and legalize the African National Congress, he opened the door to another kind of liberty: freedom for South African newspapers, broadcasting outlets and book publishers to cover the country as they choose.

LEAD: AMERICA was all the rage last week at the Kremlin Hall of Congresses, as the remodelers of the Soviet Constitution fashioned a new Western-looking Presidency for Mikhail S. Gorbachev and legalized a multiparty system. From the debate in the hall and the banter in the corridors, a visitor might have gathered that the Soviet people, having sampled McDonald's and Bon Jovi, were ready for Madison and Jefferson.
LEAD: The National Assembly here is considering a sweeping petition to pardon current and former military people accused or convicted of common crimes and human rights violations.

LEAD: Thomas Eck, the Southeast Paper Manufacturing Company's assistant technical manager, understands every cog in every machine in Southeast's recycled-paper plant here. He cheerfully answers the same questions, again and again. Ask him if he is bored, and he says, ''Oh, no, this is fun.''
LEAD: Chris Antley was almost too choked up for words yesterday at Aqueduct after he won his first race in seven months.

LEAD: AFTER losing a round in court, Josephine Thornton, the mother of David Croudip, the Atlanta Falcons' defensive back who died of a cocaine overdose in 1988, has given up her legal battle to claim $200,000 in life insurance proceeds from her daughter-in-law by proving that the younger woman administered the fatal dose.
LEAD: A retired Chicago butcher who was a Nazi concentration camp guard in World War II has been stripped of his American citizenship but will be allowed to remain in the United States.
LEAD: INTIFADA The Palestinian Uprising - Israel's Third Front. By Ze'ev Schiff and Ehud Ya'ari. Edited and translated by Ina Friedman. 352 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Berry of New York and Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Mills Berry to Donald Henry Gips, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Gips Jr. of Princeton, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: A RESURGENCE in home building under way in Newark over the last two years is about to take a new turn toward one- to four-family houses. This is the likely result of the New Jersey Legislature's authorization last year of five-year tax abatements for them in urban areas.
LEAD: THE WHIRLPOOL By Jane Urquhart. 214 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $18.95.

LEAD: One of New York City's grand old moviehouses of the 1930's, the Loew's Kings Theater, or ''The Kings'' as it was more commonly called by the residents of Brooklyn's Flatbush neighborhood at that time, may be restored to its original flamboyancy if city officials have their way. The city's Public Development Corporation is soliciting ideas about how best to use the theater, which has been dark for 12 years.

LEAD: FOR a quick glimpse of the problem, take a two-minute walk in Brooklyn Heights, New York City's best-preserved enclave of 19th-century brownstones, its first landmark district and a neighborhood with a glut of religious real estate.

LEAD: ''PRAGUE THE GOLDEN'' was always beautiful, but for the last 21 years the mood was sullen, brooding, resentful. Today Prague is radiant with the pride of a people who succeeded in wresting democracy from the grip of Communist dictatorship. The really hard work may be yet to come, but for now they are basking innocently in their freedom like students on the first sunny day of spring under the medieval spires and Baroque domes of a city that is one of the glories of
LEAD: WITH the unexpected arrival of springlike weather last week, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's announcement that all county parks will remain open this season seemed propitious.

LEAD: Even though President Roh Tae Woo has formed an overwhelming legislative majority by merging two opposition parties into his ruling party, he was unable to break a deadlock on major bills in a special session of Parliament that ended this week.
LEAD: The number of refugees in the world has doubled in the last decade, but the international organization charged with caring for them is facing a growing financial crisis.

LEAD: The quincentenary of Columbus's discovery of the New World is upon us, and Franco Cardini's EUROPE 1492: Portrait of a Continent Five Hundred Years Ago (Facts on File, $50) is disguised as a commemoration of that event. More accurately, the book is a general treatment of European life at the end of the 15th century.
LEAD: Nelson Mandela returned home today and said he would lead the African National Congress delegation that has been invited to meet President F. W. de Klerk on April 11.

LEAD: GHOST TOWNS ARE AMONG HER FIRST EXHIBITS. Patricia Nelson Limerick, who teaches Western history at the University of Colorado, takes out a bundle of glossy black-and-white prints that she keeps at her home in Boulder and shows me scenes of dilapidated cabins, saloons, sagging mining shacks amid empty landscapes.
LEAD: Storm-Struck Forest Reopens In Puerto Rico

LEAD: They will appear sometime next month as if by magic at garden centers, nurseries, supermarkets and discount stores. Rows and rows of plastic trays will be stuffed with sturdy seedlings, most of them with their first flowers.

LEAD: THINK of the race for governor as one of those sliding-tile picture puzzles, where all the little squares move around, but nobody knows what the final picture is supposed to look like. That is the scene political experts in Connecticut are trying to gauge.

LEAD: What others discard - plastic six-pack rings and torn fishing line - Irene Neal gathers to make jewelry. For Mrs. Neal, a 53-year-old sculptor and painter, the inspiration came from a deep-sea diving project that she, her husband and their two children made with the oceanographer Jean-Michel Cousteau.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: SAM GEJDENSON, the 41-year-old Bozrah Democrat who has been elected five times to Congress from Connecticut's Second District, has long been an advocate of economic diversification to make Connecticut less reliant on defense industries.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a seven-day stay at Taroudant, I thought I'd keep this authentic Moroccan spot to myself. Lo and behold, a piece extolling its virtues appeared in the Travel section (''Palmy Days at a Hideaway in Morocco,'' Dec. 31).

LEAD: Three guest artists appeared with Fourworks in ''Reality and Illusion,'' an evening of works choreographed by the company's director, Marijeanne Liederbach, in a benefit performance on Tuesday evening at Marymount Manhattan Theater.

LEAD: WHEN peace comes it will be ushered in on my bird feeder. Certain political pundits, pondering peace, suggest that recent events in Eastern Europe presage an era of peace; soon the Messiah will ride through the Brandenburg Gate on a white donkey. I know differently. The age of peace will not arrive until the occupants of my bird feeder get their act together.

LEAD: IT WAS A DARK AND STORMY AFTERNOON in the dead of winter. I had just picked my way around a sad slab of salmon with limp but woody asparagus and tomatoes the color and texture of wet ash. Partly to prolong leaving a warm neighborhood restaurant, but mostly to cheer myself up, I succumbed to the waiter's hard sell on the special dessert, a ''harvest'' tart.

LEAD: The shares of Southland Communications Inc., a small paging company based in Santa Ana, Calif., jumped 43 percent in over-the-counter trading last Wednesday. With refreshing candor, the company's executives put out a statement that day saying they knew of no reason for the rise in the share price.

LEAD: THE pictures were striking, just as they were intended to be: Children paralyzed from the waist down crawling up the steps of the Capitol, and more than 100 protesters, most in wheelchairs, being arrested by police officers in riot gear after a raucous demonstration in the Rotunda.

LEAD: After more than two years of controversy, a Massachusetts state commission has dealt a setback to Harvard students who say that exclusive undergraduate men's clubs on campus illegally discriminate against women.

LEAD: Though jazz and Latin music have mingled regularly over the last century, their relationship has always been uneasy. Despite their similar roots, their rhythms and sense of form are different, and from the 1940's on, their uses have separated. Where Latin music, meant for dancing, is still essentially functional, jazz has long been content to use the vestiges of the dance impulse - riffs, swing - to keep the rhythms supple.

LEAD: COUNTERFEITER: The Story of a Master Forger. By Charles Black and Michael Horsnell. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) ''Successful counterfeiting requires not only skill, patience and a great deal of capital to buy the range of complex machinery which is the forger's stock-in-trade, but an intense appreciation of security.

LEAD: TO hear Pete Seeger tell it, the singer and political activist is falling apart. His voice is ''50 percent gone,'' he says, and he gets by only by ''persuading the audience to sing along.'' His memory is going, too, and that's not all. ''I can't remember where I put my hearing aid five minutes ago,'' he says.

LEAD: After a yearlong break to strengthen security, a joint Peruvian-American force has resumed eradication of coca plants in the Upper Huallaga Valley, a guerrilla stronghold in northern Peru that is the source of half of the world's cocaine crop.

LEAD: A photograph with the Architecture View column on March 4 appeared without a credit. The photograph, of the new J. P. Morgan corporate headquarters on Wall Street in lower Manhattan, was by David Anderson.

LEAD: A GOOD title being hard to find, the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson must be congratulated for '' 'Lite' Works,'' because the show of sculpture it identifies contains at most a couple of calories. To put it another way, the art is as easy on the intellect as it is on the eye and mainly this is because the eight sculptors involved use materials that call for neither a vast studio space nor an arsenal of tools.

LEAD: A terrorist group has claimed responsibility for the fatal crash of two United States helicopters and the bombing of a discotheque, and it threatened more attacks on Americans and United States property. The group calls itself the December 20 Movement after the date of the American invasion of Panama.

LEAD: ON a recent Friday morning, Dr. David Axelrod, the State Commissioner of Health, stood behind the lectern in a large ballroom at the Westchester Marriott Hotel here, speaking to more than 350 people about his proposed universal state health insurance plan. At times his speech seemed more like an appeal than a lecture.

LEAD: Anne Southall Adler, a daughter of Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler, both of New York, was married yesterday to John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr., the son of Mrs. Tarbell of Needham, Mass., and the late Mr. Tarbell. The Rev. Jane P. Henderson performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in

LEAD: A pipeline that ruptured and allowed propane to leak and explode last week will be put back into service within a month, long before investigators know what caused the explosion that killed two people, officials said. Officials at Texas Eastern Products Pipeline Company of Houston said the rebuilt pipeline will be tested by running water under high pressure through the line from Watkins Glen to Selkirk, where the pipeline ends.

LEAD: Hunters in New York State killed 181,879 deer last fall, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation reported. Although this was a 6 percent decrease from 1988, the number of bucks taken, 99,589, was a record high. The previous record, set in 1987, was 97,595.

LEAD: To the Editor: It was encouraging to read in ''A World of Butterflies in Florida'' (Travel, Jan. 28) that Coconut Creek visitors go home with information on the importance of native plants to native butterflies. When preferred plants disappear, butterflies are at risk. Adult butterflies sip nectar from many flowers - primarily yellow, orange, pink and purple ones - but the females require specific plants as host plants for their eggs and food for the caterpillars.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On March 5, the former Ritz Theater on West 48th Street, owned by Jujamcyn Theaters, officially became the Walter Kerr Theater. It is scheduled to open formally on April 16 with ''The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson. During the festivities, Mr. Kerr, the retired chief drama critic of The New York Times, reminisced about the theater he has known over the years.

LEAD: Why, oh why, were the merits of remarkable books ever in doubt? Perhaps nothing is so painful as rejection, and nothing so sweet, especially to an author, as wrongful rejection overruled by history. The assessments that follow did not deter the writers from trying again, nor the public from ultimately reading the books.
LEAD: THE Phoenix Suns guard Jeff Hornacek underwent successful arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove torn cartilage in his left knee, the team announced.

LEAD: In the fickle world of consumption in which R. H. Macy & Company makes its living, every day is another dollar and every day may bring another horror. How is one going to sell those weasel-skin mufflers that only yesterday seemed so haute couture? Why did the buyer have to take 7,000 of the musical cutting boards?

LEAD: In the 18 years she has spent as a crime reporter for The Miami Herald, Edna Buchanan has picked up a lot of stuff besides her 1986 Pulitzer Prize. She has learned police procedures, met strange characters and collected many sad, weird stories, some of which went into her true-crime study ''The Corpse Had a Familiar Face.

LEAD: SEVERAL concerts this week will feature children or will be performed for them. The most ambitious project is today at 2 P.M., when the Allegro Chamber Ensemble appears under the umbrella title of ''Imagination Concerts: A Family Series.''

LEAD: DESPITE unusual spells of mild weather, part of it called the January thaw, this has been a rough winter for plants. Gardeners who have been outside for their annual inspection may have been surprised to find that many of their plants, particularly the broadleaved evergreens, were burned.
LEAD: A $600 MILLION, 800-unit condominium project is planned for one of the most desirable pieces of waterfront remaining in the downtown of this Canadian West Coast city celebrated for its vistas.

LEAD: I am writing in response to the article headlined ''Questions For Guido'' and, in fact, in response to the entire situation surrounding the death of Detective Wustenhoff and the subsequent funeral ceremonies. I am writing because I have additional questions.

LEAD: With enough money, ingenuity and chutzpah, movie makers can do anything. They are able to re-create 19th-century Africa, the battles of the Civil War, volcanic eruptions and the new Dark Ages that will follow World War III. In movies, fetuses can talk and horses fly. Movies make the impossible look ordinary.

LEAD: PRAGUE this spring has a supplementary reason for feeling like a city woken from a bad dream to a world full of promise and delight. Its wine cellars are stocked with the 1989 vintage, one of those that almost sing with perfume. The pale-gold glassfuls from the taps of its wine taverns have the rare quality of effortless excellence that harks back to the days before brand names and back-labels or indeed labels at all.

LEAD: John Delafose and the Eunice (La.) Playboys don't bother with any of zydeco's latest borrowings: no funk, no rock, no country-and-western, just the homegrown heritage of Cajun two-steps and waltzes tinctured with blues and rhythm-and-blues. Wednesday night at Tramps, in the band's New York City debut, the closest thing he sang to a pop song was the Johnny Horton hit ''The Battle of New Orleans,'' from 1959.
LEAD: TOASTMASTERS
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Your question this week sent me into such spasms of laughter that it took a corner of the coffee table to bring my head back to its senses.
LEAD: ON a clear day you can peer into Czechoslovakia and Hungary from the Kahlenberg, the 1,585-foot-high hill on the outskirts of Vienna.

LEAD: Lisa Jayne Auslander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Auslander of New York, and William Samuel Haft, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Haft of Old Westbury, L.I., were married yesterday evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Robert Widom officiated.

LEAD: Arguably, the best criticism of the death penalty I have ever heard came from someone who is for it. In Kevin Toolis's excellent article ''When British Justice Failed'' (Feb. 25), Justice Donaldson is quoted as telling the three men among the Guildford Four that they would have been executed, had hanging been allowed.

LEAD: Joe McIlvaine, the good shepherd who tends the flock of Mets yearlings, calls them baseball's ''prisoners of war,'' but they are not penned in any camp. The problem, as McIlvaine and many other personnel people view it, is that they should be in camp.

LEAD: The appointment last week of Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith as co-directors of American Ballet Theater obviously heralds a new phase in the troupe's history. But through its importance, this decision by the board of an internationally ranked company also symbolizes the implicit closing of a strange era.

LEAD: Centuries ago, an Irish poet, a woman whose name has been lost, wrote: My love is no short year's sentence. It is a grief lodged under the skin Strength pushed beyond its bounds; The four quarters of the world, The highest point of heaven. It is A heart breaking or Battle with a ghost, Striving under water, Outrunning the sky or Courting an echo.

LEAD: On his strolls along the Thames, Tom Binns used to scoop up pocketfuls of sea glass - old bottle tops really - sculpted by currents and washed up on the banks. These pale, irregular fragments have long held a special fascination for the designer, who has only to grind them to turn them into rings.

LEAD: Because of a scheduling conflict, the joint recital by the soprano Kathleen Battle and the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal scheduled for March 25 at Alice Tully Hall has been postponed to Feb. 24, 1991.

LEAD: IF each city has its niche in time, then the turn of the century is where Budapest naturally belongs. It has the boulevards and the opera, the cafes and the trams, the public gardens and private villas. And now, as another era and another century come to a close, it is showing signs of the same freneticism and languor, the same eagerness to do business and seek pleasure that characterized its golden age in 1900.

LEAD: For nearly two months Nadav Henefeld, a 6-foot-7-inch import from Israel, had been enrolled at the University of Connecticut although ineligible to practice with the basketball team because his Scholastic Aptitude Test scores had not been high enough. But he was granted a second chance to take the test.

LEAD: THE Government has initiated scores of civil and criminal lawsuits against financiers whose savings and loan associations went bankrupt. Some have been indicted, some have been acquitted and many have shifted their energies to other kinds of business.

LEAD: THE NATION'S NEWSBROKERS By Richard A. Schwarzlose. Volume One: The Formative Years, From Pretelegraph to 1865. 370 pp. Volume Two: The Rush to Institution, From 1865 to 1920. 366 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. $32.95 each.

LEAD: As everyone knows, stamp collectors are very well organized people who keep elaborate lists of exactly what items they hope to add to their collections, how far their budgets will stretch and how they will display their new material.

LEAD: Livingston $170,000 24 Dogwood Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, porch, living-room fireplace; taxes $2,539. Middletown $160,000 150 Clairmont Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, c/a, fireplace in family room; taxes $3,547.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There are all kinds of reasons why the current Chicago Symphony subscription concerts at Orchestra Hall are significant. But the most compelling is that they mark the arrival of a major new orchestral score, one that addresses a terrible crisis of our time and also manages to make impressive sense on abstract esthetic terms.

LEAD: ''Go fight City Hall'' usually means, ''Don't bother, you can't win.'' But the owners of 184 cooperative apartments at 50 Lexington Avenue fought - and won - and now may get up to $10 million in tax abatements. The dispute involves their claim to 10 years of abatements under New York City's 421a program.

LEAD: As of this weekend, the new additions have yet to prove their value on the road to the cup. (The team was winning when Nicholls joined and later, when Gartner was added.) The line of Kisio-Muller-Ogrodnick is the most consistent and productive. The rest of the team - when uninjured - is of major value.
LEAD: DOING JUSTICE A Trial Judge at Work. By Robert Satter. Introduction by William Styron. 256 pp. New York: American Lawyer Books/ Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
LEAD: Can a basketball team be in serious trouble when the score is 5-2?

LEAD: Lois and Jax, the embattled protagonists of Elizabeth Page's comedy ''Spare Parts,'' are a lesbian couple who decide, without really thinking ahead, to have a child. As the play opens, Lois is making love with Henry, a young man she has picked up in a bar and gone home with for the sole purpose of insemination.

LEAD: Walter T. Ridder, a retired news executive who helped create the Knight-Ridder, Inc., communications organization, died after a long illness Saturday in his home in McLean, Va. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: In 1978, Air Wisconsin had a small fleet of aging, 19-passenger Swearingen Metro planes that shuttled most of its 397,000 riders that year to and from its hub in Appleton, Wis. Just 12 years later, Air Wisconsin has become the nation's largest commuter airline. Its turboprops and jets, with as many as 100 seats, carry more than two million passengers a year.

LEAD: STRAY By A. N. Wilson. 247 pp. New York: Orchard Books. $15.95. (Ages 10 and up) TABITHA By A. N. Wilson. Illustrated by Sarah Fox-Davies. Unpaged. New York: Orchard Books. $14.95. (Ages 8 and up)

LEAD: HE got an early start on his professional career by jumping to the National Basketball Association after his sophomore season at North Carolina State, but the way Chris Washburn sees it, he might have made more money and kept more of it if he had stayed in school another year.

LEAD: A SINGULAR achievement of former Mayor Edward I. Koch's last term was the creation of a huge housing program, which has already produced about 3,500 new subsidized apartments in formerly abandoned buildings in New York City's poorest neighborhoods. About 13,000 other apartments are under construction, and a total of 47,000 are to be renovated by the mid-1990's.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Waters of Port Washington, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Waters, and Kevin John Kells, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Kells of Miami.

LEAD: IN the middle of an Ardsley Village Board meeting last year, the doors burst open as trustees were considering an alteration plan for the municipal building. Paul Ryan, a local resident who had been watching the meeting on cable television, marched in with an idea for a different design.

LEAD: The first significant sign of possible movement by the owners on salary arbitration, the lone remaining major issue in baseball's labor dispute, crept into their talks with the players yesterday.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-19
LEAD: A condom giveaway on St. Valentine's Day at Dayton University has divided student opinion.

LEAD: If you let yourself be intimidated by a great player, you're as good as lost before you sit down to play. Whether you have any reasonable expectation of beating him or not, it is correct to carry the battle to him as early as possible.

LEAD: IF you yearn for the taste of tomatoes but are unimpressed by their quality at this time of year, try roasting them. Ripe hothouse or hydroponically grown tomatoes taste wonderful when cooked this way. They look a mess but they develop an intense flavor, sweet yet sharp, and almost carmelized. They are good with almost any food that likes the flavor of tomato.
LEAD: Steve Georgiadis, a sophomore pitcher for Florida, died of heart complications today after surgery on his left shoulder, the university said.

LEAD: Apparently record companies - no matter how big - more and more feel that pop and rock aren't enough to make them perceived as ''full-line'' record companies; one must be in the classical business, too. Thus it was that Warner Communications (now Time Warner) took the plunge in 1988, buying the Hamburg-based Teldec organization and obtaining a 20 percent interest in the French Erato label, which had been affiliated with RCA.
LEAD: The population of the New York region will increase only moderately but grow significantly older during the next three decades, according to new projections.

LEAD: For 60 years, Novo Industri and Nordisk Gentofte, two Danish companies that sold insulin, were bitter enemies. ''At both companies, the main motivation was to kick the competition,'' said Mads Ovlisen, Novo's chief executive.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins, carrying a black shillelagh and wearing a ''Free Joe Doherty'' button, led 125,000 marchers yesterday in the 228th St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue, past hundreds of thousands of horn-blowing, green-clad and usually sober spectators.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A DAY after he crashed into a concrete barrier while testing a race car in West Palm Beach, Fla., Scott Pruett, the co-rookie of the year in the 1989 Indianapolis 500, was reported in fair condition yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis, where he underwent surgery to repair multiple fractures of both legs.
LEAD: JUST imagine that Oscar Wilde hadn't written ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' We might have been spared ''The Ice Cream Sunday'' by Frank Salisbury.

LEAD: KILLSHOT, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $5.95.) With two professional hit men on their trail, a Detroit ironworker and his wife find out just how much shelter the Federal witness protection program really affords. Elmore Leonard ''dazzles as he sprinkles his work continually with unexpected convolutions,'' Ann Rule said here last year.
LEAD: In the annals of medicine, cures for diseases have come through one person's inspiration or years of research by teams of scientists.

LEAD: Q. The cement deck around our swimming pool has become dark and dirty looking. Scrubbing with bleach solutions has not helped much. Do you know of anything we can use to make the deck look nice again?

LEAD: Marci Lynn Spector, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Spector of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., and Mitchell Brian Rose, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Rose of Kings Point, L.I., plan to marry in December.

LEAD: ''We've tended to trivialize issues to the point where meaningful debate has become almost impossible.'' - Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee. [1:1.]

LEAD: The Army is investigating accusations that two American soldiers killed Panamanian prisoners during the American invasion of Panama, and it is likely to charge at least one of the soldiers with homicide, Army officials said today.

LEAD: SPINOZA AND OTHER HERETICS By Yirmiyahu Yovel. Volume One: The Marrano of Reason. 244 pp. Volume Two: The Adventures of Immanence. 225 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. Volume One, $24.50. Volume Two, $29.50. $45 the set.
LEAD: The dismissal of three Northwest Airlines pilots for allegedly flying under the influence of alcohol has focused renewed attention on Federal rules that govern flying and drinking.

LEAD: For This Week: This is a good week to use fertilizer, especially on woody plants and lawns. But it is too early to remove winter protective mulches from garden borders, flower beds and younger plants; wait. Prune roses when forsythia blooms. Try sharp smelling spice or ground red pepper to discourage squirrels, mice, rabbits and other furry invaders from damaging flowers and plants.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE HOUSE OF MORGAN An American Banking Dynasty and the Rise of Modern Finance. By Ron Chernow. Illustrated. 812 pp. New York: A Morgan Entrekin Book/ Atlantic Monthly Press. $29.95.

LEAD: There are dozens of dishes all over Mexico, especially in the coastal areas, that are a variation on this theme: Fish with vegetables and chilies. Many recipes call for baking the fish and cooking the potatoes separately, then combining them with the rest of the vegetables and cooking further. But the results are equally flavorful if the fish is cooked right along with the vegetables, which saves time and pots.

LEAD: SEVEN members of the Central Connecticut State tennis team were injured, three of them seriously, Friday night when a van carrying them from the Orlando, Fla., airport was struck by a car that crossed the median of an expressway.

LEAD: The image of the dust bowl migration is imbedded in American consciousness, permanently linked to our memory of the Great Depression. It was an epic event. More than a million people, most of them dispossessed farm families, left the declining agricultural regions of Texas, Arkansas, Missouri and Oklahoma during the 1930's and moved west to California.
LEAD: By refusing to make even token efforts to reform their ways, China's hard-line leaders have achieved something that seemed impossible a few months ago: an American consensus on China.

LEAD: Dr. James F. Gilliam, a professor at Princeton's School of Historical Studies for two decades before his retirement in 1985, died on Friday after a long illness, at the Merwick Nursing Home in Princeton, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Princeton.

LEAD: The inspiration may be baroque, but when Franco Zeffirelli speaks about his new production of ''Don Giovanni'' at the Metropolitan Opera, which opens Thursday, he leaves little doubt that the execution will be vintage Zeffirelli.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Mozart: 'Exsultate, Jubilate,' Concert and Opera Arias (7) Felicity Lott, soprano; London Mozart Players conducted by Jane Glover. ASV DCA 683; CD. Even at the risk of duplicating an aria or two in your collection, it is worth seeking out this disk for the stylistic authority, first-class muscianship and all-round expertise offered by this distinguished English soprano.
LEAD: East Germans will vote on Sunday in an election that marks a turning point for the Germans, Europe and Communism.

LEAD: AMERICAN Indians and archeologists are sometimes at odds over the treatment of Indian burial sites. The Indians are in general most concerned that the sites be respected and preserved, while the archeologists are usually more interested in what can be learned from them.
LEAD: THE WRITERS' TRADE And Other Stories. By Nicholas Delbanco. 286 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.
LEAD: CLARK KENT made it look easy. Into the telephone booth and, faster than a speeding bullet, Superman emerged, muscles bulging under royal blue spandex, every hair in place.
LEAD: Nearly 11 months have passed since a Purdue University professor sent a letter critical of the university's personnel practices, a letter that led to his being denied a merit raise.

LEAD: Mary Paige Power and Scott Andrew Metzger are planning an August wedding, the future bride's parents, John F. Power Jr. of Carmel, N.Y., and Lorna Power of New York, have announced. Mr. Metzger is a son of Mrs. Samuel P. Metzger 3d of Rumson, N.J., and the late Mr. Metzger.
LEAD: There were some good things about my first car. For one thing it cost $125. I traded in savings bonds for it, actually what we called war bonds when my grandmother bought them for me.

LEAD: James L. Ketelsen took up running after he had double bypass heart surgery in 1979. He started with 20 minutes a day, then moved up to 30 minutes when his company's in-house fitness manager recommended it.

LEAD: LIKE many New Jerseyans, I have a vegetable garden out back. I grow a half-dozen tomato plants, a few rows of beans, some zucchini - a vegetable smorgasbord. I get a deep satisfaction from working the soil and making things grow. And in raising a portion of our food organically, I enjoy the feeling that I am doing something worthwhile both for my family and for the environment.
LEAD: JUST imagine that Oscar Wilde hadn't written ''The Importance of Being Earnest.'' We might have been spared ''The Ice Cream Sunday'' by Frank Salisbury.

LEAD: The problem-plagued Milwaukee Bucks were missing two starters last night, Jack Sikma and Greg Anderson, along with Ricky Pierce, whom many consider the National Basketball Association's best sixth man, but the Knicks' puzzling slide continued.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mead of Washington have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Mary Hayward Mead, and J. Mark Lennon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Lennon of Haddonfield, N.J.

LEAD: It was a marketers' nightmare: On the day that the Chase Manhattan Corporation launched its Vista Growth and Income Fund, the Dow lost more than 500 points in the dizzying drop that turned October 19, 1987, into Black Monday.

LEAD: Max Nierman, a commodities trader and member of the Chicago Board of Trade for more than half a century, died Friday at the Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 90 years old and lived in Palm Springs.

LEAD: Just over a year ago Bill Buchanan, a personnel specialist between jobs, was given 5 assistants, 150 unassembled cardboard desks, a budget of $500,000, an office key and a mission: Make sure the residents of 42 counties in western North Carolina are counted in the 1990 census.

LEAD: Since the crash of 1987, America's financial markets have taken a number of actions that attempt to corral the more abusive aspects of program trading. But events clearly show that even stronger measures are required not only to restore the integrity of the markets, but to help stem what is rapidly becoming an international crisis.

LEAD: Stung by reports that he had undermined his union's position by back-channel communication with team management, Paul Molitor of the Milwaukee Brewers left the baseball negotiations last night insisting that he stands firmly behind the negotiating position of the Players Association.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Haggerty of Summit, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Ann Haggerty and Gregg H. Beldock, the son of Florence Milan of New York and Howard N. Beldock of Fort Lee, N.J. Miss Haggerty, a graduate of Hollins College, is a manager of program operations at the ABC Radio Network in New York.

LEAD: Heavy rain today forced an overnight delay in third-round play of the Players Championship and may have diminished the chances of some veteran contenders.
LEAD: After teaching history in this small, predominantly Hungarian village in Transylvania for more than 30 years, Istvan Vincze is used to shifts in the official version of the truth.

LEAD: Joan Quigley is no crass self-promoter, of course, but it must have been difficult to stand silent while other people hogged the credit for changing the course of history. Ms. Quigley, who was Nancy Reagan's astrologer, asserted in a memoir published last week that Mrs. Reagan's 1989 memoir greatly understated the astrologer's influence on the Reagan Presidency.
LEAD: WHEN George L. Giguere drives the rural stretch of Interstate 84 between Manchester and the Massachusetts border, he sees an opportunity where other people see just trees.

LEAD: Five firefighters were hospitalized for smoke inhalation yesterday after battling a fire that broke out in the cellar of a largely unoccupied 50-floor office building on Lexington Avenue and East 51st Street in Manhattan.
LEAD: The Soviet Union is the world's largest producer and second-largest exporter of oil. Saudi Arabia is the largest exporter.

LEAD: KILLEEN, TEX., IS HOME TO about 68,000 people and the Army base at Fort Hood. It's a bit of a downtrodden place at the moment, in the wake of the budget-cutting proposal by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney that would substantially shrink the military presence there. On the bright side, however, is miniature golf, whose image in Killeen is undergoing state-of-the-art refurbishing.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Burton D. Cohen of Minneapolis have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Susan Beth Cohen, and Thomas Barry Ginsberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Herman Ginsberg of Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

LEAD: ON a Friday night in Prague in June, as couples strolled across Wenceslas Square or promenaded down the Narodni Street toward the National Theater, Czechoslovak rock fans lined up outside Chelmnice, one of the hottest spots to hear rock in Central Europe.

LEAD: NIGHT AND FOG. By Arne Brun Lie with Robby Robinson. (Norton, $18.95.) Half of ''Night and Fog'' is the story of the Norwegian Arne Brun Lie's year as a political prisoner of the occupying Nazi Government. The other half is the story of how Mr. Lie got up the nerve to talk about that year. The two halves run alongside each other the length of the book and somehow never quite cohere.
LEAD: ON Tuesday, the vernal equinox will occur, and spring will begin. People around Connecticut will mark the occasion with activities that include climbing mountains and planting peas.

LEAD: If there is any reward in architecture to staying the course, it is to be seen right here on Washington Street, where the Newark Museum has recently completed a $21 million reconstruction and expansion. The architect the museum hired was Michael Graves - not the internationally famous Michael Graves of today, architect of Whitney Museum additions and Walt Disney World hotels, but the young and struggling Michael Graves of 1967, a faculty member at the Princeton University School of Architecture.

LEAD: THE main highway from Budapest to the Tokay region runs northwest, skirting Eger, where the famous Bikaver, or Bull's Blood, is made, to Miskolc, a grimy industrial town where the truckers stop before pushing on into the Soviet Union. But wine lovers turn off to the right at Miskolc and something of a miracle seems to take place.

LEAD: Janet Evans and Janel Jorgensen may be 18-year-old Stanford freshmen, but they swam like old hands tonight in the final races of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's championships.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read Carol Kramer's article ''China After Tiananmen Square'' (Travel, Feb. 18) with a mixture of fond memories and sadness. Having completed a tour a few weeks before the Tiananmen incident, I relived our stay (and the guilt we felt when we first arrived) at the incredible Shanghai Hilton, our lovely hotel in Xian and the adventure of traveling on old Russian planes between cities.

LEAD: Those of us who have to sort trash into piles of glass, cans and paper are already aware that there is a garbage crisis. Americans generate more than our fair share of refuse, much of it in the form of non-cycled, non-biodegradeable plastic.
LEAD: The Federal Centers for Disease Control is considering banning most primate imports after a rare, deadly virus turned up in monkeys in at least two laboratories, officials said Friday.

LEAD: A dog is a dog is a dog and a cat is a cat is a cat - to non-dog and non-cat people. But to the enormous fraternity of pet owners, their cats and dogs are as beloved as children. It's therefore no surprise that when Lynne Katsafouros Friedman appeared in public last year in a T-shirt with a hand-painted poodle on it, strangers approached, and when they discovered she had painted it herself, asked if she would do one for them.

LEAD: There is no way that the Rangers' cup will ever runneth over until the Rangers get a bonafide heavyweight to insure that their star players do not get runneth over. JEFFREY BUKANTZ Livingston, N.J.

LEAD: The one title that appears most frequently in the late Herbert von Karajan's discography is Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony, which he recorded seven times over a period of nearly 50 years, with orchestras in Berlin, London and Vienna. The symphonies with which he is most readily identified, though, are Beethoven's, and in that material his recording statistics are impressive.
LEAD: Any other year at this time, you might be reading the annual heart-rending saga of some old pitcher trying to make it through one more spring training.

LEAD: When Anne Meara was growing up on Long Island, she was convinced her family was like no other. She had no intimate knowledge of other families, but she just knew that they and their beautifully modulated voices lived in perfect harmony in an atmosphere of sweet reason. When she was a little older, she knew that romance wasn't romance unless there was background music and, in the distance, a sunset or some other bit of glorious nature.

LEAD: A sojourn in Spain for two members of Siouxsie and the Banshees -the singer Siouxsie Sioux and the drummer Budgie - turned into a record album, ''The Creatures,'' and now a North American tour. The Creatures are still ''just the two of us,'' as Ms. Sioux said from the stage of the Ritz on Wednesday night.

LEAD: Night after night, the games were dropped, the chances at points slipped away. Still, even as the futility stretched to more than a month, the Islanders woke up to the fact that they were not sunk yet.
LEAD: Ernst Bacon, a prolific composer, pianist, conductor and teacher whose career spanned more than six decades, died of heart failure on Friday at his home in Orinda, Calif. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: If one can dream for a moment, Bernie Nicholls will pass the puck to Mike Gartner, who will shoot the puck between the legs of Mike Vernon in overtime of the seventh game of the Stanley Cup final. In reality, Phil Esposito's many trades did not help the Rangers win the cup, so why should Neil Smith's trades be different?

LEAD: When Lindsay Law, the executive producer of American Playhouse, commissioned Craig Lucas to write a film about AIDS, Mr. Law was well aware of the obstacles the project might face. The film, ''Longtime Companion,'' which explores the effect of the disease on the gay community over eight years, was unlikely to find backers with bales of cash begging to finance it.

The two groups will spend $66,700 over the next eight months on outside consultants who will conduct a feasibility study to see if a seven-acre site at Liberty Avenue near Tuckerton Road could be used for food-processing companies.

LEAD: MEN. YOU CAN TAKE them anywhere, but you can't dress them up. This stereotype seems to have haunted males ever since Adam decided that fig leaves were sufficient attire. But although many men still feel they would rather don a straitjacket than a tuxedo, others are discovering that formal can be fun.

LEAD: George Bush wants to be the Education President. Yet he won't spend much money on schools. He wants to end drug abuse. Yet he won't spend much for treatment. He wants to help the poor. But in his 1991 budget, discretionary programs for low-income families are only half what they were, adjusting for inflation, 10 years ago.

LEAD: A major union local, a prominent local church, a cultural group and a real estate developer have worked together to move forward a 23-story office building now under construction at 101 Avenue of the Americas in the so-called Hudson Square area of SoHo. The 31,000 square feet of land on the west side of the avenue between Grand and Watts Streets is owned by the real estate arm of The Parish of Trinity Church, which acquired the property under a grant from Britain's Queen Anne in 1705.

LEAD: On his trip to southern Africa next week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will encourage Nelson Mandela to continue his campaign against apartheid and will also urge the black leader to abandon socialist economic principles, a senior State Department official says.

LEAD: The military junta in the Sudan has introduced an era of repression marked by the detention and torture of suspected political opponents that surpasses the worst excesses of the longtime military Government that ruled from 1969 to the mid-80's, a human rights observer group says.

LEAD: The possibility of legalizing casino gambling in New York City is being studied by the City Council's Committee on Economic Development, but the idea has drawn criticism from Mayor David N. Dinkins.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Man-hunting, like bear-baiting, has no place in a civilized society. Yet in the last month or two the manhunt has become a fact of life in the cultural life of New York. Just the other day, Andre Schiffrin - universally admired and respected as the head of Pantheon Books, and the son of the initiator in Paris of the Bibliotheque de la Pleiade, from which the ongoing Library of America derives - was dismissed from his post.
LEAD: Not long ago a doctor who is the mother of four young children called me with a story. She thought it was big, big enough for a big newspaper. Her day care center was closing.

LEAD: As the 1972-73 coordinator of the Rape Prevention Committee for NOW-NYC, I was pleased to read ''Linda Fairstein vs. Rape'' (Feb. 25). At the time of our campaign to have a rape unit established, the District Attorney's office operated on a rotation system. Any woman brave enough to press charges against a rapist would be assigned to whatever lawyer was next in the rotation line.

LEAD: TENANT rights, especially in a highly regulated environment like New York City's, are in a constant state of flux. Court decisions, administrative rulings and legislative amendments make it hard for tenants and landlords to keep up with their rights and responsibilities. This is particularly true for the narrowly focused changes that do not make headlines when they are announced.

LEAD: The Young Friends of the Library chose the Ides of March, the anniversary of Julius Caesar's assassination, for Bacchanal, the group's second annual fund-raising event, at the New York Public Library on Thursday night. Dress was black tie or toga, and many guests chose the latter, accessorizing their cream-colored gowns with garlands of ivy, fur slippers and leopard-spot shawls.

LEAD: A strike that has crippled public education in West Virginia for the last 10 days neared an end today when leaders of the state's two main teacher unions urged their members to return to work on Monday.

LEAD: At the Garth Chapel in Charlottesville, Va., Susan Phelps Ingersoll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps Ingersoll Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Timothy John Burgess, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brook Gene Burgess of Keyser, W. Va. The Rev. Maurice A. Fetty, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: PERHAPS it was my unexplained Easterner's fondness for the Midwest or had something to do with the approach of my 50th birthday, but as soon as I heard a friend's enthusiastic recounting of his marathon bicycle ride clear across Iowa I knew that this was something for me. Never mind that I had never done even any semi-serious cycling or that my exercise consists mostly of a few weekly sets of tennis and a bit of winter basketball.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MAGGIE SMITH - OR DAME MAGGIE SMITH, TO USE HER NEWLY ACQUIRED TITLE - approaches the Hyatt Carlton Tower hotel in Knightsbridge, showily twirling her left arm in the air. A grand theatrical gesture from a star whose career has shown no shortage of them? Perhaps, but this time, there's an element of triumph in the motion: the notorious arm whose injury partly caused the Broadway postponement of ''Lettice and Lovage'' for a year, is on the mend, and Maggie Smith wants to illustrate its recovery with a flourish.

LEAD: It must be some peculiar twist in the DNA that drives human beings toward extremes of every sort. In politics, whole nations will periodically swing from soul-numbing repression to nearly chaotic freedom, or back again. One school of rigorous poets finds in the 17 syllables of haiku the secret of the universe, while another believes truth is only revealed in random, half-conscious verbiage.

LEAD: VOLVOS and Buicks idled in front of the Great Neck South High School as parents waited for their children. Although it was Saturday, it was just another school day for the 367 students attending the Japanese Weekend School. In Japan, children go to school six days a week. On Long Island they do too.

The pawns were the tribes and leagues of Indians that held the control and wealth of a wide area. Agents of each European power were quick to make any alliance with the Indians that could hurt the other.

LEAD: It seems that dogs have a new best friend up in Alaska. Susan Butcher last week won her fourth victory in the grueling 1,158-mile Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race. Along the way she set a new record time of 11 days, 1 hour, 53 minutes and 28 seconds for the Anchorage-to-Nome run, earning $50,000 in prize money plus a $25,000 bonus from her sponsor, a dog food manufacturer.

LEAD: To the Editor: It seems ironic that China would attempt to exploit the art of the Buddhist religion (''Serene Haven of Buddhist Art,'' Travel, Jan. 14) after having so devastatingly destroyed much of the art of Tibet. Unfortunately, suppression of the Tibetan people continues and we see no evidence that persecution has in any way lessened over the years.

LEAD: APPROVAL has been granted by the City Council here for the world's tallest building. But will it ever be built? And, if it is, will the sky-high rents needed to recoup construction costs make it difficult to attract tenants?
LEAD: RESTAURANT sequels, like those of movies, are usually a disappointment. Experience has taught moviegoers and savvy diners alike to cringe at any new title followed by a Roman numeral.

LEAD: In every college game he has ever played, Philip Hutcheson has scored in double figures. In every college course he has taken, he has received an A. The unassuming Hutcheson, a student at David Lipscomb University in Nashville, has scored more points in a career than any college player in history.

LEAD: Michael Eldred was doing his dance, the one he calls ''pitching and hawking.'' It involves stomping, clapping and shouting to get the attention of people walking by his table on a Brooklyn Heights sidewalk, a table loaded with children's books.

LEAD: This spring, women's sandals have been re-invented so that they can be worn to the office, and the platform shoe, an icon of the 40's, has returned. What's common to both styles is the muted colors: peach, lemon, olive and creamy tomato. This season, many of the freshest styles are also affordable, selling for less than $100.

LEAD: At the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia, Dede Cynthia Zeluck, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Zeluck of Haddonfield, N.J., was married yesterday to John Higman Caron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Blackwood Caron of Greenwich, Conn. Judge Stephen Levin of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas performed the ceremony.

LEAD: It was Alec McCowen's 64th birthday. There were bluebells in the woods near Chichester, where he was playing the tyrannical father in a stage adaptation of Henry James's ''Washington Square.'' So he did what any other sensitive person would have done under the circumstances: he went for a contemplative walk.

LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Ten Escapes to the Exotic'' (Travel, Dec. 24), Jane Perlez refers to David Livingstone as ''the English explorer.'' David Livingstone was born in Blantyre, Scotland, and should have, therefore, been referred to as a Scottish explorer. ANNE H. LISTAK Lake Bluff, Ill.

LEAD: Warsaw wears its woes more prominently than its wonders. It seems at times to have more coal grit to coat its soulless apartment blocks than sunlight to bathe its golden Old Town. But this year the city is wrapped in a sense of history being built day by day, which visitors can feel even behind unappealing facades.

LEAD: We are the parents of the Ralph Ferrandina mentioned in ''The Lady Sometimes Vanishes,'' by Nancy Malitz, (Feb. 25). Teresa is so pure of heart and soul that it appears unreal. We don't believe her career ever comes first; it is people who come first. She has helped us and our son by giving him a bonus of life for the last three years.

LEAD: In response to ''About Men: A Case For Grad School,'' by Mark McGurl (Feb. 18), I pity the writer for his self-deprecating reaction to the relative successes of his former girlfriends. Life is strange, entropic for either sex, and we must fight the inclination to pit ourselves against our fellow humans and against the mentality that promotes such a limited understanding of other people.

LEAD: The engagement of Amy Beth Slove and Thomas Andrew Jakobson has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lawrence Slove of Westfield, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Alan R. Denzer of Greenwich, Conn., and Peter Jakobson of New York and Elberon, N.J.

LEAD: A jury has reported being deadlocked on all eight charges against a Federal district judge accused of trying to influence criminal cases on behalf of friends, but it has been ordered to continue deliberations.

LEAD: BEFORE the decade is out, the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry is expected to cost the Government more than $200 billion. That is much more than the Government will spend on such critical social problems as preschool education, drug control and aid to the homeless. It is more than will be spent on highways, air traffic control and pollution abatement.

LEAD: A new American spy satellite has apparently malfunctioned after less than a month in orbit, and parts of it are expected to be destroyed re-entering the atmosphere within a month, United States and Soviet military space officials say.

LEAD: There's a touch of spring in the air in New York City and something else, too: stray bullets. One day last week, one struck Amy Rosen while she ate her lunch in Central Park. That evening, another struck Loretta Rivera as she walked home from a pizza parlor in Brooklyn. Dr. Rosen, luckily, survived her chest wound.

LEAD: A DESERT SCENE IN WHICH MILlions of dollars change hands under a tent seems better suited to an oil-rich sheikdom than an Arizona polo field called Horseworld. Compounding the strangeness is that the commodity being bought and sold here is not the four-legged means of transportation of years gone by, but the machines that made them nearly obsolete - automobiles.

LEAD: WHEN New Jersey's first Federal prison opens its gates next month, officials say, it will be an example of enlightened penal philosophy - a structure without surrounding walls or guard towers. It will also be a prison that its neighbors have invited into their economically depressed rural community in the hope that it will bring development and jobs, local officials say.

LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact, meeting here under new, democratic conditions, failed to agree today on whether a united Germany should be neutral or aligned with the West. LEAD: Bad habits aren't what they used to be, and neither is ''Bad Habits,'' the twin bill of one-act plays by Terrence McNally that has been given a catch-as-catch-can revival by the Manhattan Theater Club. In the distant year of 1974, when ''Bad Habits'' made its hilarious New York debut, the characters' vices of chain smoking, high-cholesterol gluttony, martini guzzling and sexual adventurism were regarded more as amusingly naughty acts of rebellion, however self-destructive, than as one-way tickets to the grave.

LEAD: Her legs still wobbling from her maiden voyage down the Easy Street trail, Debra Maloney-Evans finds she is actually enjoying herself. For Mrs. Maloney-Evans, this slushy Sunday at Sugarbush's Mount Ellen Ski Area is her first outing on Alpine skis in nearly 20 years, and she admits to having had her doubts.

LEAD: Worried that West Germany is wavering in its commitment to the European Community, France urged it today to absorb East Germany as rapidly as possible and again focus attention on European integration.
LEAD: * Huntington Bancshares Inc., a bank holding company in Columbus, Ohio, to Meldrum & Fewsmith, Cleveland, with a budget of $7 million.

LEAD: More than two months after a revolution that briefly united them, the Hungarians and the Romanians who live together in what is now Romanian Transylvania are once again locked in a centuries-old rivalry that is reviving nationalist fervor on both sides.
LEAD: At first glance, the new advertising for the United States Army's R.O.T.C. recruitment campaign could be mistaken for a Nintendo video game.
LEAD: The Rockets' Red Glare When America Goes to War The Presidents and the People By Richard J. Barnet 476 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would not seek a third full term in office, citing the ''political realities'' facing him and saying he had no taste for the negative campaign tactics he believed necessary to win re-election.

LEAD: While Boris Becker gave too convincing an imitation of a noontime somnambulist, Jean Fleurian, an eccentric Parisian wearing his last pair of sneakers and shorts too new, too large and held up by a safety pin, was wide awake.

LEAD: The Federal appeals court in Boston has declared unconstitutional the 1988 Federal regulations preventing Government-financed family planning clinics from doing abortion counseling.

LEAD: By the end of a long dreary day in a fluorescent-lighted room with windows facing nothing but courthouse brick, Imelda Marcos's notebook was crammed with trivia. She knew that Laverne Hairston likes to watch ''China Beach'' and ''L.A. Law,'' that Manuel E. Rosa enjoys westerns and that Samuel Cerezo plays paddle ball.

LEAD: As the first Met to take batting practice, Howard Johnson swung at the first pitch and pulled a long high drive down the left-field line that had the look of a home run until it curved foul. But the 600 spectators in St. Lucie County Sports Complex cheered anyway. Several minutes later, when HoJo strolled out of the batting cage, the fans applauded.

LEAD: Chris Jackson, Louisiana State's leading scorer in both his freshman and sophomore seasons, announced on Saturday that he would forgo his final two years of college eligibility to enter the 1990 National Basketball Association draft. Yesterday, he became a pro athlete officially when he signed a player-agent agreement with Eddie Miller, a lawyer from Gulfport, Miss., who is one of his longtime friends.(

LEAD: The price of the United States' latest atom-smasher has just jumped a little - from $5.9 billion to $8 billion - and the designs aren't even completed. Before it leaps again, there's time for second thoughts. This dinosaur of a machine may crush more fruitful kinds of physical research.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Atlantic magazine, combining a desire to report the rise in corporate philanthropy over the last decade and to increase advertising revenues, will publish an annual supplement called ''Private Profit Public Gain,'' which will be distributed with its September issue. The Atlantic said it would donate a tenth of the supplement's net revenues to charity.

LEAD: SPRING FASHIONS: NEW YORK Once spring lasted long enough to be a real season with its own coat of navy blue. That first sighting equaled a splurge of daffodils. Spring came serenely in stages of dress code. Now it unfolds haphazardly in maybe two weeks of surprises - forgetful of white gloves.

LEAD: About 800 staff members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization conducted a two-hour strike today to protest a major restructuring of several divisions and the appointment of new senior officers at the organization by its Director General, Federico Mayor Zaragoza.

LEAD: N.B.A. Schrempf Leads Pacers Past Heat Detlef Schrempf scored 20 of his career-high 29 points in the first half last night as the visiting Indiana Pacers took a big lead early and ended a five-game losing streak with a 112-98 victory over the Miami Heat. Six of Schrempf's 14 second-quarter points came during a 12-2 surge that made the score 48-27.
LEAD: Public School 182 in the East Bronx learned yesterday that it had made a phenomenal comeback - the educational equivalent of moving from the league cellar into pennant contention.

LEAD: The White House sharpened the tenor of its statements on Lithuania today, saying an increase in the Kremlin's political pressure against the republic's independence movement was ''cause for concern.'' The Bush Administration called on Moscow to open immediate talks on self-determination with the Lithuanian Government.

LEAD: Frederick R. Clark, a lawyer, banker and former chairman of the New York Power Authority, died of heart failure on Monday at Naples Community Hospital in Florida. He was 73 years old and lived in Loudonville, N.Y., and in Naples.

LEAD: MICROWAVE ovens have not been high on anyone's list of important safety concerns for several years now. Fears that small children will be exposed to low levels of radiation escaping from poorly sealed doors seem to have died down.

LEAD: The failed coup this month in Afghanistan, which united a hard-line Communist general with a fundamentalist guerrilla leader, has shaken the long-held assumptions of nearly all the principals in the nation's long civil war, Afghan exiles, diplomats and others say.
LEAD: Spanish and Central European performers aren't ordinarily considered compatible, but Monday evening's concert by the Cincinnati Symphony at Carnegie Hall disproved that stereotype.
LEAD: Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre, the San Francisco agency formed earlier this month by four executives from Hal Riney & Partners, has picked up its first client.
LEAD: One New York team clinched a playoff berth in the Patrick Division tonight when the Islanders played in suburban Washington in one of their most important games of the season.

LEAD: Think of spandex exercise clothes: tights and a leotard, or a one-piece bodysuit. That's where it all starts. Then add layers. A parka or a T-shirt, an abbreviated sweater or a chiffon dress. If you're feeling fairly sedate, you might wear a long tailored jacket. You might even pull on a skirt, but it must be either micro-mini or nearly ankle-length.

LEAD: A TASTING of vintage port is an experience in sensual overload. Superficially, there is no difference between a port tasting and a red wine tasting; substantively, nothing is the same. The richness, the power, the nuances of the ports are considerably harder to appreciate, and articulate, than those of the red wines.

LEAD: How many movie biggies can be accommodated on a pinhead of a documentary? That seems to have been the challenge of ''The New Hollywood'' the NBC Special tonight at 10. Starting with the much advertised fact that the movie business is controlled by huge conglomerates and dedicated to smash hits, Tom Brokaw goes around asking hot producers, agents, directors and actors how they feel about the pressure to come up with blockbusters.

LEAD: A truck accident caused a failure of electrical power at the Plant Vogtle nuclear station in this eastern Georgia town today, but the resulting brief emergency did not affect the plant's safety, the Georgia Power Company said.
LEAD: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration has been accused of violating Colorado air pollution standards by burning half a ton of cocaine in an incinerator last month.

LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that a taxpayer may not sue for a refund of an erroneous Federal tax payment after the time limit for filing such suits has expired, even if the Government is to blame for the overpayment.
LEAD: The President of Angola says independence for Namibia will give a military advantage to his Government in its long-running war with rightist rebels.

LEAD: NEW HAVEN has long been the gastronomic capital of Connecticut. It is the alleged birthplace of the hamburger (at Louis Lunch) and the calzone (at Tony and Lucille's). It is also home to what some consider the nation's best pizza (at Pepe's or Sally's on Wooster Street).
LEAD: New Ale, New Beer
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that union members who sue their labor union for damages for failing to represent their interests are entitled to have the case heard by a jury.
LEAD: The Rangers yesterday announced that they had agreed in principle to a contract with Rick Bennett, the highly regarded 22-year-old left wing from Providence College.

LEAD: The party that has controlled Village Hall here for 25 years rebuffed its first serious challenge in recent memory today to win the elections for mayor and all three trustee positions. The winning party, the Unity Party, defeated candidates from the Integrity Party and the Independent Party.

LEAD: A mischievous, movie-struck little boy called Toto leans out the window of the Cinema Paradiso's projection room and looks out on the public square. As the grandfatherly Alfredo turns the projector around, the image of a Chaplinesque comedian glides across the walls of the room and out in the open air, to reappear as a gigantic moving picture on a building across the way.
LEAD: Debris from a secret American spy satellite has begun falling from space and burning up from the heat of re-entering the atmosphere, the Pentagon said today.

LEAD: The Miniscribe Corporation, the financially troubled computer disk drive maker, has received three preliminary bids, its chairman, Richard Rifenburgh, said. He said the company expects formal offers later this week. Mr. Rifenburgh would not disclose the bidders or their offers, but he said he was optimistic a deal could be reached.
LEAD: Summer Sanders won her first national swimming championship tonight. But even that, she said, was not the best thing that had ever happened to her.
LEAD: The case of Joseph Hazelwood went to the jury today after a prosecutor portrayed him as a reckless drunk and a defense attorney called the Exxon Valdez skipper a scapegoat of political powers.

LEAD: Representative Gus Savage has claimed victory in the Democratic primary for nomination to a sixth term in Chicago's Second Congressional District after an unexpectedly strong challenge from a relative newcomer.
LEAD: With a lot of distraction from the opposition, the Devils never found any rhythm tonight and suffered a 3-2 setback to the Flyers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
