LEAD: A concert version of Jerome Kern's ''Cat and the Fiddle'' is to be presented in six performances starting on April 18 at 8 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall. With original orchestrations, this is believed to be the first New York revival of the show since it opened on Broadway in 1932.

LEAD: FRESH venison, once considered a seasonal treat, is now appearing all year on the tables of consumers who yearn for a red meat that is tender, tasty and lean. It is served regularly in many restaurants across the nation and sold in many supermarkets and specialty shops.

LEAD: President Chaim Herzog chose Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, this evening to take on the difficult job of trying to form a new Government. The President urged Mr. Peres to complete the task as soon as possible.

LEAD: On a quiet, tree-lined street in this affluent town, Binyamin Krivonosov sat in his new apartment and surveyed three couches and armchairs, two coffee tables, two dinette sets and two refrigerators crowding the room.

LEAD: Evaluating schools in this country has always been a political battlefield.

LEAD: Eric J. Schmertz, a labor mediator and former dean of Hofstra University Law School, has been selected to be New York City's chief labor negotiator, aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday.

LEAD: Jeff George, the Illinois quarterback, announced yesterday in Champaign, Ill., that he would forgo his final year of college eligibility to enter the National Football League draft. College juniors must declare their intentions to the N.F.L. by tomorrow. The 6-4, 216-pound George completed 474 of 789 passes in two years with the Illini, and his 5,189 passing yards placed him third among all Illinois quarterbacks.

LEAD: SOMEDAY I hope to visit Santiago de Compostela, in northwestern Spain. This historic city, at the end of a famous medieval pilgrimage route, houses the shrine of St. James the Apostle. It fascinates me because the route is marked by the emblem of St. James, scallop shells.
LEAD: New York City and New Haven, Conn., have formed a task force to bring a major part of the 1994 World Cup soccer tournament to the metropolitan area.

LEAD: The Raytheon Company pleaded guilty today to obtaining secret Air Force budget documents illegally, and it agreed to pay $1 million in fines and penalties.

LEAD: Serrano and Molinari Capture House Seats Jose Serrano of the South Bronx and Susan Molinari of Staten Island overwhelmed their opponents yesterday to win special elections. Mr. Serrano will replace Robert Garcia, while Ms. Molinari will succeed her father, Guy V. Molinari. Page B1. LEAD: United States trade negotiators have been hammering away for years to open Japanese markets, yet many American companies, even giants like Citibank, the nation's largest bank, find Japan a daunting challenge. They have discovered that the real problem is not so much governmental or cultural barriers, but that doing business here is too costly and competitive to justify a major effort.

Now, New York's most populous borough is forging a new history, as shown by the array of galleries, nightclubs, performance spaces and food shops that have recently opened. These additions to Brooklyn's cultural map are usually different from similar venues in Manhattan.

LEAD: A fire burned down 763 houses and left almost 4,000 people homeless in the Myanmar capital of Yangon, according to a report today. It took three hours to control the blaze, said the report from the country formerly known as Burma. According to the report, the fire began Tuesday in a house and quickly spread.

LEAD: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the captain of the Exxon Valdez, was acquitted today of the most serious charges involving the worst oil spill in United States history, but was convicted of a single charge of misdemeanor negligence.
LEAD: A forensic dentist said today that two wounds said to be bite marks on the body of Kelly Ann Tinyes did not match dental impressions taken from Robert Golub, who is charged with killing her.

Tickets are $17.50 to $22.50.

LEAD: What makes Brooklyn clubs so nice is similar to what makes the borough itself pleasant: smaller crowds, less pressure and more variety than in Manhattan. While the level of talent is not as high as in Manhattan, that is not always the point. Brooklyn clubs, if one can make generalizations at all, are good places for novice musicians and artists to learn about stagecraft, to experiment without the fear of failing in front of high-paying audiences.

Foreseeing a mud-slinging campaign for which he has no stomach, he wisely opts for honorable retirement.

LEAD: An obituary on March 10 about Ron Wolin, an antiwar advocate who brought a successful lawsuit to permit the distribution of political and religious leaflets in publicly owned transportation terminals, misstated later decisions on the issue. Unlike transportation terminals, privately owned shopping centers in New York and nearly all other states are still permitted to limit leaflet distribution and solicitation.

LEAD: This week, Andre Agassi described himself as ''complicated, very complicated.'' But he also pledged to be uncomplicated while on the tennis court, which is why he has earned the opportunity to play for the $179,000 title at the Lipton International Players Championships on Sunday.
LEAD: A year after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the nation is making halting progress toward improving the safety of oil transportation.
LEAD: The Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to disband their forces in Honduras by April 20, five days before the inauguration of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua.

LEAD: Japan asked the United States today for help in checking the fall of the yen, but the United States went along only part way, arguing that the reasons for the yen's weakness are largely Japanese and that there is little Washington can do.

LEAD: The family feud that has convulsed Editions Gallimard for the last two months ended up in court today when Antoine Gallimard's brother and two sisters formally challenged his control over France's most prestigious publisher.

LEAD: For the second time in 10 years, Canada is caught in the throes of an emotional and divisive debate over its future as a united country. Once again, the issue is language. For the moment, the tone - in either French or English - is pessimistic.

LEAD: A 15-foot-high concrete-block wall under construction collapsed yesterday morning in Brooklyn and crashed through a warehouse ceiling, killing two people and seriously injuring several others, the authorities said.

LEAD: The Boeing Company is seeking shareholder approval to more than double the number of common shares outstanding to 600 million, but the company said in its proxy statement that it had no immediate plan to issue more stock. Boeing has 230.6 million common shares outstanding. Shareholders will vote on the proposal at the company's annual meeting on

LEAD: An appeals panel today rebuffed an attempt by John E. List, who is accused of killing his family 18 years ago, to move his trial out of Elizabeth and sequester the jury because of the publicity his case has drawn.

LEAD: W. L. Gore & Associates Inc. is making angry noises about bagpipes. The Newark, Del., company makes Gore-Tex, the breathable, waterproof fabric, and last year patented a synthetic bag to replace the traditional animal skins used on Scottish bagpipes.

LEAD: A lawyer who in 1988 pressed regulators to refrain from seizing a failing savings and loan was given a $49,000 no-bid consulting contract last year to advise a Federal agency involved in the bailout of the savings industry.

LEAD: In a move welcomed by advocates for the disabled, the Bush Administration has proposed that operators of federally aided bus lines be required to provide door-to-door service in specialized vans for disabled people who do not benefit from wheelchair lifts and other special devices on buses.

LEAD: At Public School 153 in Co-op City in the Bronx, there was the delicious feeling last year that they had beaten the odds. Test scores showed that almost 95 percent of the students read at grade level or above, raising the school's rank to 9th from 328th among the city's 616 elementary schools.
LEAD: James D. Wolfensohn, an investment banker, arts patron and chairman of Carnegie Hall in New York, was selected today to become chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.
LEAD: Reducing the amount of fat in the diet is more important than changing the kinds of fat consumed in preventing obstructive lesions in the heart arteries, researchers said yesterday.

LEAD: That he has a passion for country-and-Western music is all that most Americans know about President Bush's esthetic leanings. This week, however, they found out something more, and better. In opposing Senator Jesse Helms's proposals to hamstring the National Endowment for the Arts, Mr. Bush proved himself to be a friend to all artists.

LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge said Thursday that he would probably choose a New York investment group's $650 million bid for financially ailing Allegheny International Inc. if the group can raise the cash. Japonica Partners is competing with Allegheny International's management to take over the Pittsburgh-based maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Just when the Loyola Marymount team seemed to have finally run out of steam and come to the end of its glorious and melancholy journey, one that had captured the interest and curiosity of a nation, the Lions found a way to win.

LEAD: Contrary to expectations - or fears - Helgi Tomasson is not turning the San Francisco Ballet into a copy of the New York City Ballet, where he danced for 15 years under George Balanchine's tutelage.
LEAD: ''This is where it all began,'' said the man called Smooth, pointing across the street to the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company will close its plant in Livingston, Scotland, and move its operations to three other sites. The plant repairs computer boards and assembles work stations. Its 240 workers will be offered jobs elsewhere with the company. The computer, electronics and instruments company acquired the Livingston plant when it bought Apollo Computer Inc.

LEAD: A man who says he aided George Steinbrenner in his feud with Dave Winfield over contributions to the Winfield Foundation was arrested yesterday and charged with threatening physical harm to Steinbrenner and Winfield and with trying to extort money from the Yankees' owner, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

LEAD: ''Beijing Watermelon,'' Nobuhiko Obayashi's new Japanese film, is a sentimental but never a convincingly sweet tale about a Tokyo greengrocer who nearly bankrupts the family business by helping a succession of poor Chinese students.

LEAD: Wilt Chamberlain, the second-leading career scorer in National Basketball Association history with 31,419 points over 14 seasons, has seen his jersey number, 13, retired by the Los Angeles Lakers, for whom he played his six final seasons, ending in 1973. Now the Philadelphia 76ers, with whom he played three and a half seasons in the mid-1960's, would like to honor their home-grown 7-foot-1-inch hero, too.
LEAD: Basketball
LEAD: ''We are under constant pressure from the outside. A certain kind of psychological warfare is being waged against Lithuania.'' - President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania. [1:6.]
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Here is a tip for people buying a home computer: Charge it on either a gold Visa or a gold Mastercard. Simply by using one of the bank cards, your computer's guarantee will be doubled, up to an additional year. That may not be the case if you pay for the system using American Express.

LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission has requested more information for its antitrust review of the proposed acquisition of a majority of Genentech Inc. by Roche Holding Ltd., the two companies said today. Jack Murphy, a spokesman for Genentech, said it was too early to tell whether the additional Federal review would delay the completion of the transaction.

LEAD: John Cale and Bob Neuwirth envisioned a cracker-barrel apocalypse in ''The Last Day on Earth,'' a set of songs they wrote together and presented on March 16 at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights. It was a kind of song cycle; the selections were played virtually without interruption, and a recurring theme appeared at the beginning, middle and end.

LEAD: Nearly half a century after a company here began processing fuel for nuclear weapons, St. Louis and several western suburbs are battling over a new disposal plan for millions of cubic yards of dirt contaminated with uranium, thorium, radium, actinium and other radioactive elements that are polluting the water, soil and air.
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration approved a novel type of drug yesterday for the treatment of a rare genetic disease that devastates the immune system.

LEAD: Undersized, underdog Minnesota executed its defensive game plan to perfection tonight and bounced Syracuse from the national collegiate tournament with an 82-75 victory in a Southeast Regional semifinal.

LEAD: The judge in the trial of Joseph J. Hazelwood sentenced him today to serve 1,000 hours of community service cleaning the beaches fouled when the Exxon Valdez ran aground a year ago Saturday while under his command.

LEAD: A report in ''At the Movies'' in Weekend yesterday about John Frankheimer's new film, ''The Fourth War,'' misidentified one of his previous films. It is ''The French Connection II,'' not ''The French Connection.''
LEAD: Taxpayers can minimize the likelihood of an audit by the Internal Revenue Service if they avoid certain common errors and are alert to areas the I.R.S. considers prone to abuse.
LEAD: Stocks rose slightly yesterday after the rebound in Tokyo, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 8.56 points, to 2,704.28, in slow trading.
LEAD: President Bush said today that he opposed statehood for the District of Columbia, the subject of renewed debate in this troubled, heavily Democratic city.
LEAD: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested early yesterday and charged in a series of sexual assaults of five girls ranging in age from 9 years old to 17, the police said.
LEAD: Hardly a day has gone by in recent months without some act to cut the heroic image of Tito down to size, revealing the late President as exceptionally greedy, mendacious and vainglorious.
LEAD: The United States and Japan said today that they had reached preliminary agreement on measures that would significantly open the Japanese market to the most powerful American-made computers.
LEAD: N.B.A. ; Celtics Survive Hawks' Surge

LEAD: Teams headed by Dan Morse of Houston and Zia Mahmood of Manhattan clashed in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here today. After 16 deals of a scheduled 64, Morse led Zia by 29 imps.

LEAD: Lothar de Maiziere, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union, which won the parliamentary elections on Sunday, ended five days of uncertainty today by declaring his readiness to head East Germany's first freely chosen and non-Communist Government.

LEAD: Ronald T. Lyman Jr., who retired in 1970 as a general partner of Scudder Stevens & Clark after 40 years with the Boston investment firm, died of a stroke on Monday at Roper Hospital in Charleston, S.C. He was 84 years old and lived in Boston and Charleston.
LEAD: The Whirlpool By Jane Urquhart 214 pages. David R. Godine. $18.95.

LEAD: While the big-time ''programs'' are competing to reach the Final Four of college basketball, one school has already won its national championship. The University of Rochester in upstate New York defeated DePauw of Indiana for the Division III title last Saturday. The final score was 43-42.

LEAD: Has your makeup outlasted its shelf life? Makeup that sits in a drawer or handbag exposed to atmospheric and temperature changes can break down. Ingredients in cosmetics, like those in food, can separate or turn rancid. And each application introduces dirt and oil, though this can be mitigated by using clean brushes and applicators.
LEAD: Days after winning a bitterly fought primary election here, Representative Gus Savage is back in the trenches, this time in a battle over remarks he made in the closing days of the campaign.

LEAD: The top leaders of the Democratic National Committee, led by the party's chairman, Ronald H. Brown, today strongly endorsed a plan to cut Social Security taxes, despite opposition among the Democratic leadership in Congress.
LEAD: Researchers at a California company won two patents this week involving insecticides derived from bacteria that they said do not harm humans.

LEAD: The Rustavi Company, a Georgian folk music and dance troupe from the Soviet Union, is to make its American debut at 8 P.M. on April 5 at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street. The 60-member group plans six performances, the last on April 8. Tickets are $20 to $35 at the box office and Ticketron outlets.

LEAD: General Mills Inc. has begun an experimental business delivering casual food like chicken wings, roast chicken and sandwiches to customers ordering by telephone. Called Bringer's, the service is provided to people who live in southwest Minneapolis and parts of suburban Edina, Richfield and Bloomington.
LEAD: A year ago, Imre Pozsgay was a major force for change within Hungary's ruling Communist Party. Five months ago, he was considered a sure bet to be President.

LEAD: Calling them ''my eyes and ears in their communities,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday appointed directors of three ''constituency offices'' - for Latino Affairs, African-American and Caribbean Affairs, and European-American Affairs.

LEAD: Two Florida inventors won patent approval this week on a class of lightning rods shaped like feather dusters. The advantage of the rods, they say, is that they dissipate far more of the ground's static electricity and sharply reduce the chances of being struck by lightning.

LEAD: George Cooper, deputy chairman of the department of biology at City College of the City University of New York, died of cancer on Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Orangeburg, N.Y.
LEAD: From the sidelines, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Lithuania seem to be two prideful political forces blundering toward a fateful collision.

LEAD: There are 1,300 students at Public School 94 in the northern Bronx, but it is impossible to miss Richard Segarra. At age 12, he is a husky 5 feet 10 inches tall, bigger than most of the teachers, a sixth grader with the proportions of the high-school linebacker he hopes to be.

LEAD: The oil industry said yesterday that it would take modest actions aimed at preventing spills in New York Harbor and making responses quicker. Environmental groups criticized the measures as ineffectual.

LEAD: Mongolia's Communist legislators formally abolished their party's monopoly on power today and approved elections with more than one candidate. But the election law was drafted before recent democracy protests and does not mention a role for opposition parties, officials said.
LEAD: This village has been called many things in its two years of life: a developer's dream, an experiment in self-determination, a joke. Now call it defunct.

LEAD: What may have seemed a good idea to many Cuban exiles in Miami - beaming U.S.-made TV programs at Cuba - gives worrisome signals of turning into a turkey. Every bit as troubling, arguments over the new service have damaged morale at the already existing and highly professional Radio Marti. This is a double misfortune, and

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the Federal inquiry into Pentagon purchasing misstated the number of people cleared of charges. Two men, not one, have been acquitted. In addition to Dale Schnittjer, a vice president at Teledyne Electronics, who was cleared on three criminal charges last April, Leonard L.

LEAD: As black workers cut sugar cane in the 1940's, a narrator notes that these happy laborers are following the ''hereditary urge to go back to the plantation.'' That archival clip, included in Stephanie Black's ''H-2 Worker,'' suggests how little the plantation mentality has changed in nearly 50 years, though today the sugar-cane growers rely on Jamaicans imported to
LEAD: The Coast Guard suspended its search for nine men today after concluding that they had drowned when their fishing trawler capsized and sank in the frigid Bering Sea.

LEAD: The automobile industry's important spring selling season has started poorly. Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks in mid-March were down by 9.5 percent from a year ago, with all of the Big Three companies reporting declines today.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will announce on Monday that it is starting its own credit card, people familiar with the company's plans said. A.T.&T. scheduled a news conference at its Manhattan headquarters. The company will introduce a new card combining the billing of A.T.&T. credit-card calls with the billing of meals, hotel rooms and other goods and services, the sources said.

LEAD: Consumers who think they can spot the bargains and the pitfalls in the supermarket aisles should pay close attention in the light bulb section, a part of the store where choices are multiplying, where common terms don't mean what people think they do, and the important measure, light, is almost always overlooked.
LEAD: * Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp., Pittsburgh, said it had increased its stake in Midway Airlines Inc., Chicago, to 12.4 percent, or 1.2 million common shares.
LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Monday headed ''Overall U.S. Market for Cigars'' referred incorrectly to sales figures shown for big manufacturers.
LEAD: The UAL Corporation said yesterday that it had changed its standstill agreement with Marvin Davis to allow the West Coast investor to buy additional shares in the company.

LEAD: The Soviet authorities sent a column of tanks and paratroopers rumbling past an all-night session of the Lithuanian Parliament early this morning, in what witnesses described as the strongest attempt yet to intimidate the republic into abandoning its declaration of independence.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A new disagreement between American and French scientists has erupted over their competing claims to have discovered the AIDS virus, with the leader of the French research group urging the head of the United States team to admit that he was mistaken.

LEAD: A work by the composer William Bolcom that was to have had its New York premiere this summer at the Mostly Mozart Festival has been postponed because of scheduling difficulties, a spokesman for Lincoln Center said.

LEAD: ABC has announced the addition of three new half-hour children's programs to its Saturday morning schedule, including an animated show about Roseanne Barr as a 10-year-old. The programs are to join the schedule on Sept. 8.

LEAD: The New England Patriots signed six Plan B free agents yesterday, including three former Giants: the running back George Adams, the tight end Zeke Mowatt and the offensive tackle Damian Johnson. The team also added the center Bob White, formerly of Dallas, and the linebackers Richard Harvey from Buffalo and Richard Tardits from Phoenix.

LEAD: David Moss's Dense Band dispenses noisy free improvisation in handy, accessible form - song-length pieces with a beat. The Dense Band, which performed on Monday night at the Knitting Factory, is built around Mr. Moss's talents as a drummer and a free-form vocalist. Whether or not he is sitting at his drum kit - which includes a steel drum, an electronic drum pad and various crumpled cymbals as well as ordinary trap drums - he can pour out syllables, meaningless or not.

LEAD: No matter what economic changes are made next in Brazil, the world's largest exporter of coffee and the largest supplier to the United States, American coffee drinkers will almost certainly be paying more next month at the supermarkets.
LEAD: Following is the text of a resolution passed by the Lithuanian Parliament early this morning, as translated by the Lithuanian Information Service:

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities meandered in a narrow range yesterday before closing slightly higher. Traders were extremely nervous and unwilling to take significant positions because of several factors that developed during the week, dealers said.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Don Giovanni,'' its first staging of Mozart's Olympian tragicomedy since the celebrated Eugene Berman production more than 30 years ago, is beautiful to look at. That can come as no surprise: the director and set designer is Franco Zeffirelli, who always brings to opera a painter's vivid sensitivity to colors and an obsessive need to splash his ideas on large canvases.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Valdez Skipper Sentenced To 1,000 Hours of Cleanup
LEAD: The United States has protested to Zaire over attacks on two lawyers who were investigating human-rights practices there, State Department officials said today.
LEAD: Miffed at not having a say in the revised regular-season schedule, major league umpires said today that they would protest by not working spring training games.

LEAD: John M. Poindexter's lawyers disclosed in court today a summary of classified information indicating that a House committee was told in late 1985, when aid to the Nicaraguan rebels was barred by Congress, that the United States was apparently directing their insurgency.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: New York State's Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, said last summer that the position of New York City schools chancellor should be abolished. But today he reversed himself and endorsed the agenda of the current Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez.
LEAD: Bernard Russo, a 36-year-old video engineer, camped overnight outside City Hall here. His mission: to enroll his 5-year-old daughter, Lilly, in the Daniel Webster Magnet School.

LEAD: The United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, said today that a substantial streamlining of Western curbs on high-technology exports to Eastern Europe is likely to be completed by June.

LEAD: The game for New York City scholastic bragging rights was played 200 miles upstate at the Civic Center tonight in one semifinal of the New York State Federation of Secondary Schools Athletic Associations Class A tournament.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings to find a way to counteract the Soviet decision. The Soviet announcement said that Aeroflot would no longer issue tickets to Soviet Jews planning to emigrate to Israel by flying through Hungary, a heavily used transit point.

LEAD: David W. Mullins Jr., the Bush Administration's first nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, testified today that he supports the central bank's current strategy of fighting inflation by keeping interest rates high.

LEAD: For several months, William Drozdal waited for a contractor to finish the front of his house after parts of it were ripped off during a renovation project. But after reading a newspaper article, Mr. Drozdal, an accountant in Rochdale, Mass., learned that he, too, had been ''ripped off,'' as he put it.

LEAD: Robert Karplus, a professor of physics at the University of California at Berkeley for more than 35 years who led in developing new techniques for teaching science in elementary schools, died of a heart attack on Thursday at a convalescent home in Moraga, Calif. He was 63 years old and lived in Orinda,

LEAD: Buckle your seatbelts on Saturday afternoon for an exhilarating example of what everyone here is calling the new wave of college basketball, a style that's high on freewheeling shots and low on patience, offering pressure defense for 40 minutes, and a thrill a second.

LEAD: The world's largest cocoa-producing countries agreed today to support a two-year extension of the International Cocoa Agreement, with all provisions on price supports frozen for the period, a spokesman for the producers said.
LEAD: The day after New York City bulldozed a statue built by East Harlem children, city officials promised yesterday to restore it.

LEAD: With a string of impressive performances in track, road racing and cross-country in the last 10 weeks, Lynn Jennings, a Yankee individualist who loves to train alone, has emerged as the leading female distance runner in the United States.

LEAD: The Republican national chairman, Lee Atwater, was hospitalized today for the second time this month. He complained of queasiness that aides said was caused by an imbalance of medication for treatment of a benign brain tumor.

LEAD: After a 13-month absence from the National Hockey League because of involvement with cocaine, Bob Probert resumed play with the Detroit Red Wings on Thursday night against the Minnesota North Stars and had Detroit's only goal in a 5-1 loss.

LEAD: In Bertolt Brecht's first play, ''Baal,'' written when he was 20 years old, the protagonist is a poet who leads a life of ''sensational immorality.'' The play was indirectly prophetic of what might have become of Brecht himself if he had not continued on his course toward art, philosophy and self-realization.

LEAD: Just two weeks after the National Football League completed a television agreement that will guarantee each team an average of $32 million a year for the next four years, two teams began to pass on the big bucks to their star players.

LEAD: A Receding Issue As Israel's major parties struggle to put together a government with potential coalition partners, one bargaining chip that caused consternation for many American Jews in the past is missing. This time around, none of the small, pivotal religious parties is demanding legislation that would narrow the definition of who is
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The official murder of a British freelance journalist, Farzad Bazoft, in Baghdad put the spotlight on Iraq for a few days. It should stay there. Torture, summary execution, flagrant violation of the most basic human rights have not been wiped out, and Iraq remains one of the world's worst offenders.
LEAD: John Jardine, who coached the Wisconsin football team from 1970 through 1977, died of heart failure today at the University of Wisconsin Hospital. He was 54 years old.

LEAD: Four days after baseball ended its 32-day lockout of spring training camps, Commissioner Fay Vincent appeared in the dugout of the Mets' camp today, sat on the bench wearing a white sun visor, watched batting practice and said: ''I'm here to watch and to heal.''

LEAD: A grand jury yesterday declined to indict a construction worker who said he had acted in self-defense when he killed a homeless man by slamming his head onto a subway platform at Columbus Circle in January.

LEAD: Shortly after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo assigned Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine to lead New York's lobbying for a coveted Federal contract for an atom smasher, Mr. Lundine was spit at and pelted with stones by Rochester residents who opposed the project.

LEAD: The United States Government has given Japan a list of more than 200 suggested policy changes aimed at eliminating barriers faced by foreign companies operating in Japan, a news report said today.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings today to find a way to counter the Soviet decision.

LEAD: Greeted by scattered chants of ''power is ours,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met here today with leaders of the African National Congress, who urged him to keep pressure on South Africa's white-minority Government.

LEAD: Does a society that compels students to attend school have a duty to insure their safe arrival and departure? Absolutely. But New York City is not doing its duty. Violence by youths against schoolmates, and against any adults who get in the way, is an increasing phenomenon.

LEAD: Ball State came within several seconds and one shot of upsetting the University of Nevada-Las Vegas tonight in the semifinal round of the West Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum.

LEAD: Col. Jack Knowles (Roy Scheider) is the sort of guy who, upon hearing that three bullies stole his young son's bicycle in the schoolyard, wonders why the boy couldn't hang on to it; after all, there were only three of them. This kind of attitude made him a hero in Vietnam, but since then he has been a belligerent misfit.

LEAD: Anthony J. Prudenti, a contractor who was Suffolk County Republican chairman from 1980 to 1984, died of a heart attack on Thursday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Blue Point, L.I.

LEAD: Stanley's Washboard Kings, a jazz quintet that features washboard and the combination of comb and tissue paper that is sometimes known as a blue blower, was a sextet at its weekly session on Tuesday at the Cajun Restaurant, 129 Eighth Avenue near 16th Street.

LEAD: MONDAY: Charles H. Keating is scheduled to testify at a United States District Court hearing in Washington on the Government takeoveof Lincoln Savings. TUESDAY: The Federal Open Market Committee meets. Economists expect no easing in credit conditions. WEDNESDAY: Revised fourth-quarter gross national product and new home sales for February.

LEAD: Chile and Mexico renewed diplomatic relations on Friday, more than 15 years after they were broken by Mexico in protest over the military coup that ousted President Salvador Allende Gossens. A ceremony here marking the restoration of relations was attended by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and his Chilean counterpart, Patricio Aylwin.
LEAD: Her name was Estelle. I should have known the broad spelled trouble when she came into my office and started talking about the canon. The literary canon.

LEAD: LAST week Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed a tantalizing peek at how he intends to use his new powers as President to push through radical economic changes. LEAD: MAGGIE JAKOBSON - that's the way her family spells it - has dubbed voices for television cartoons, taught sign language to a chimpanzee and swum with dolphins.
LEAD: After 48 years, a run of bad luck even a rigged roulette wheel might have trouble reproducing, the numbers could finally break right for the Rangers today at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: Roman Catholic leaders have been talking as if being a little bit against abortion is like being a little bit pregnant. But Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago says reasonable minds, or at least politicians' minds, can differ on the subject. Even while Catholic officeholders are more or less obligated to oppose abortion, he said, they should not have to fear punishment for disagreeing on how to do that.

LEAD: Marcia Harriet Perlstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Perlstein of Oakland, Calif., was married last evening to Dr. Lawrence Bradley Lusk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Lusk of White Plains. Rabbi Robert S. Kirschner officiated at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco.

LEAD: Political and business leaders have been saying for years that for Vancouver the future is the Pacific Rim, but, it seems the future is now. This city on the west coast of Canada is thriving with new citizens, new buildings and new investment.

LEAD: HYPERION (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95; Spectra/Bantam, Paper, $4.95) and THE FALL OF HYPERION (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95) by Dan Simmons make up a single thousand-page novel about the last days of a vibrant yet self-destructive galactic civilization called the Hegemony.

LEAD: In a project intended to symbolize the winding down of the cold war, nuclear missiles of the kind that the Russians and the Americans have aimed at each other will soon be placed side by side in museums in Washington and Moscow.
LEAD: SHARK TANK Greed, Politics, and the Collapse of Finley Kumble, One of America's Largest Law Firms. By Kim Isaac Eisler. 236 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $18.95.
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has approved what it says is the first genetically engineered food product for humans, an enzyme used in making cheese.

LEAD: The dollar is still going in two directions these days, continuing to strengthen against the yen while weakening against the German mark. The victory of a coalition of conservative parties in the East German elections last Sunday added pressure to the drive to unify the Germanys, and that in turn helped push the mark up against the dollar.

LEAD: Emily Lloyd doesn't play the sort of movie teenager who worries about what she's going to wear to the high-school prom or about having a date with the handsome senior who also happens to be the Harvard-bound captain of the football team.

LEAD: Alison Fay Brecher and Eric Scott Savitch were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York by Rabbi Philip Graubart, assisted by Rabbi Paul Siegel and Cantor David Lefkowitz. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernd Brecher of Hartsdale, N.Y. The bridegroom is the son of Mr.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: One could argue that modernism, for all its art-for-art's-sake veneer, is at heart Romantic. Painters like Piet Mondrian, sculptors like Constantin Brancusi and photographers like Alfred Stieglitz all wanted to get to a spiritual dimension with their pared-down forms, and they relied on inner sensibility as their means of discovery.
LEAD: Live by the buzzer, die by the buzzer. Connecticut tried it once too often at this regional, and will not be heading west as a consequence.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Skittish investors should stay out of today's ''junk bond'' market. But conditions are ideal for ''bottom fishers,'' the hardy souls with a strong tolerance for risk who scout for bargains in the ruins. And, according to Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser, closed-end funds are the best bargains in today's junk market.
LEAD: If the owners and the players have a new labor contract, can a timetable for major league expansion be far behind?
LEAD: THE last act has opened in a long-running zoning drama in the Windsor Terrace section of Brooklyn.

LEAD: Tradition holds sway again on the bunny trail, with ruffles and lace for girls and nautical themes for boys this Easter, perhaps because the holiday offers a rare chance to get the children into dress-up clothes.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V. Myers of Richmond have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Priscilla Claire Myers and Dr. Michael Anthony Rossetti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Rossetti of New York. Dr. Myers, 28 years old, is a dentist, as is her fiance, 27. Both are graduates of the Medical College of Virginia.
LEAD: VINTAGE QUILTS
LEAD: The University of Connecticut's basketball season of a lifetime ended suddenly this afternoon with the same type of buzzer-beating shot that two nights before had extended it.

LEAD: Phoebe Neville often suggests an oracular priestess in her dances, and when she literally plays with fire by tossing a fireball from one gloved hand to another in her solo ''Memory,'' she again seems to possess a magic power.

LEAD: Alvin R. Jennings, a former managing partner of Coopers & Lybrand and a past president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, died of a stroke on March 14 in Miami, where he lived in retirement. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: Because of a producer's schedule change, a theater listing and a picture caption on page 45 of the Arts and Leisure section today, about the Off Broadway play ''Neddy,'' are outdated. The play, at the American Place Theater, opens next Sunday, not today.

LEAD: IMAGINE a hotel room decorated in shades of black and blood. Dangling above the bed is a sinister-looking ax blade; at the foot of the bed, a freshly bricked-over passageway, behind which some poor soul, the tip of whose cap is still visible, has met an untimely end reminiscent of ''A Cask of Amontillado.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has named his first Cabinet, balancing the choice of some of his closest partners in change with two figures who have been openly hostile to aspects of his program, the official press agency Tass reported today.

LEAD: The music was liturgical, but the choreography looked pastoral. Nevertheless, the sacred and the secular harmonized today when the Garden State Ballet offered Peter Anastos's new ''Gloria'' at the Montclair State College Memorial Auditorium.

LEAD: Franco Zeffirelli's production of ''Don Giovanni'' made its debut on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera, the 13th new production underwritten by Sybil Harrington, the Texas philanthropist. Carroll and Milton Petrie gave the opening-night party, and the guests applauded the principals as they arrived at the champagne supper.

LEAD: Howard Spira, a self-described gambler who was arrested Friday on Federal charges that he threatened George Steinbrenner and tried to extort money from Steinbrenner and Dave Winfield, was released on bail yesterday.

LEAD: SATYAJIT RAY: The Inner Eye. By Andrew Robinson. (University of California, $29.95.) Film buffs will be fascinated by ''Satyajit Ray,'' a study of India's most widely acclaimed director. Born into a gifted Calcutta family in 1921, Mr. Ray shot his first movie, ''Pather Panchali,'' with amateur actors and no script; its budget was so minuscule that at one point the director had to pawn his wife's jewelry to buy lunch for his crew.

LEAD: GREAT PLAINS PATCHWORK: A Memoir. By Marilyn Coffey. (Iowa State University, $21.95.) The novelist Marilyn Coffey has put together an entertaining, insightful collection of stories, combining fact and legend, about her beloved central plains between the mid-1880's and the late 1950's. ''Like a speck on the eastern horizon appears a wagon loaded with Coffeys,'' who in 1885 migrated west to the Great Plains from Illinois.

LEAD: Stephanie Anne Wagoner, the daughter of Geraldine C. Wagoner of Mahwah, N.J., and the Rev. Roy W. Wagoner of Bergenfield, N.J., was married yesterday to James Allen Kloiber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Kloiber of Fort Atkinson, Wis. The Rev. James Steele officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N
LEAD: Nanook of Smithtown

LEAD: Behind every tract of rain forest that is cleared, every factory that is shuttered and locked and every oil-clogged beach lies an investment decision. These decisions may have paid big dividends to shareholders and other investors - they may have made certain individuals wealthier - but they also have harmed the economy, society and environment.

LEAD: Taiwan is not the ''Free China'' it claims to be. But at least it now shows willingness to move in that direction, in contrast to a deepening chill in mainland China. Taiwan's reforms are worth encouraging, both for themselves and for the healthy example they might set for future leaders in Beijing.
LEAD: Two people were killed and 32 injured today when a tour bus returning to Massachusetts from New York City overturned on Interstate 684 in Armonk, officials said.

LEAD: Cheryl Ann Jagolinzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Jagolinzer of Framingham, Mass., was married last evening in Newport, R.I., to Jonathan Grant Marcus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Marcus of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Mark Jagolinzer, a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Oceancliff Resort.
LEAD: SUDDENLY, prominent Congressmen are proposing higher taxes and President Bush is reading their lips. Almost overnight, a Federal tax increase seems possible.

LEAD: A document can convey intelligence, but until recently it lacked intelligence of its own. This newspaper, for example, cannot write itself, deliver itself to subscribers, or tailor its contents automatically to the interests and reading level of a particular subscriber.

LEAD: It's not necessarily survival of the fittest in the dance world; it may only be survival of the luckiest. When a production vanishes from a repertory, no one can predict if it will be gone for a season or for all eternity. Shockingly few creations of the past were notated when they were new. Even in our own age of film, videotape and crusading notation societies, numerous dances still go unrecorded.
LEAD: THE GROWTH EXPERIMENT How the New Tax Policy Is Transforming the U.S. Economy. By Lawrence Lindsey. 260 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.
LEAD: As Patrick Ewing sat in front of his locker last night, the 7-foot center must have been asking himself, ''How much more can I do?''
LEAD: I found Marlene Fanta Shyer's ''Changing Thoughts on Fur'' [Opinion, Feb. 18] to be a curious mixture of confusion, fallacy, rationalization and hypocrisy.

LEAD: A rapidly expanding Canadian hotel company, the Journey's End Motels Corporation of Belleville, Ont., has entered into a deal to erect a 31-story hotel at 15 Cliff Street between John and Fulton Streets - the fourth hotel project in the financial district since the stock market crash of October 1987.

LEAD: Temple Bat Yam in Newport Beach, Calif., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Amy Lyn Zuker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert Zuker of Newport Beach, to Dr. Steven S. Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack W. Schwartz of Port Washington, L.I.
LEAD: Criticized for years by some senior Government officials for not taking a more active role in the war on drugs, the Central Intelligence Agency seems to have abandoned its former reluctance.

LEAD: An Wang, the founder of Wang Laboratories and the inventor of a doughnut-shaped ring of iron that served as the core of computer memory until the microchip came along, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Dead Poets Society 1989. Touchstone. $89.95. Laser disk, $39.99. 2 hours 8 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Robin Williams dispenses Whitman and robust advice at Welton Academy in Peter Weir's film, an Academy Award candidate for best picture. Imitating John Wayne and barking ''carpe diem'' (''seize the day''), Mr.

LEAD: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?

LEAD: Babies born too soon, too small and too sick are given a fighting chance in the neonatal unit at University Hospital here. The infants' emotional growth often rests in the arms of volunteers who have nothing to give but their love.

LEAD: Thomas Gallant, a young oboist, has had a worthy career championing new music and other frontiers of his instrument's repertory, and he put together a piquant assortment of mostly marginalia for his program on Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall. But it proved a self-effacing showcase for his own talents.
LEAD: Robert A. Miller, a member of the new generation of black fashion designers, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: IF Gov. Jim Florio's first two months in office are any indication, he is going to leave the state much different from the way he found it.
LEAD: Thirty-six students from Columbia University and Barnard College spent spring break helping to repair a Methodist health center and camp that was severely damaged by Hurricane Hugo.

LEAD: Wendy M. Akins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Akins of Alta Dena, Calif., and Jonathan D. Doniger, a son of Audrey C. Doniger of Westport, Conn., and Alan F. Doniger of New York, are planning a May wedding.
LEAD: Two decades ago, a swindler named Michael Hellerman carried out a series of stock frauds involving top mobsters and then became an informer who testified against his former associates.
LEAD: THERE are many very good reasons for studying history in school.

LEAD: IT was after dark when the bus to Xapuri in northwestern Brazil ran out of gas about a mile from town. An earlier breakdown on the highway from Rio Branco, the capital of Acre state, had stranded the 50 passengers aboard for five hours until a replacement bus arrived. At roadside, as the group shared soft drinks and candy bars, an easy camaraderie sprang up.

LEAD: In the fallout from baseball's labor dispute, one temporary rule threatens the sanctity of its statistics. Ordinarily a starting pitcher must complete at least five innings in order to be eligible for a victory. But for the first 14 days of the season that opens on April 9, three innings will be enough.

LEAD: For This Week: Prune rose of Sharon, large-flowered hydrangea, buddleia and other shrubs that will flower on this year's growth. Apply general garden fertilizer to trees and shrubs; wait to uncover perennials. Use a spading fork to turn the compost pile. Prune roses. Rake up winter debris from the lawn and use a calibrated spreader to apply lime and fertilizer.

LEAD: Jennifer Alison Downey and Rene Clement Dussault are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. John A. Downey of New York and Elsie W. Downey of Closter, N.J., have announced. Mr. Dussault is a son of Evelyn Dussault of Schenectady, N.Y., and the late Rene C. Dussault. Miss Downey, 29 years old, is a special-education teacher at the Dr.

LEAD: Two picture captions on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with an article about historic recordings, are reversed. The picture at the top right shows Ferruccio Busoni; the one next to it shows Alfred Cortot.

LEAD: A DARKLY gleaming lidded lacquer bowl is set before the diner. He (or she) mumbles ''Itadakimasu'' (I receive), lifts the lid and sets it aside. The glossy white grains carefully mounded within give off a sweet fragrance. Chopsticks are raised and plunged into the steaming rice. The meal begins.

LEAD: ''EVERYBODY'S insurance was the levee, and it's gone,'' lamented a resident of Elba, Ala., which was largely under water last week after flood waters ripped through the town's 52-year-old levee.

LEAD: The guiding force behind music in our time is recycling. As if trapped in some futuristic society marooned in space, composers seem forever doomed to sift through the same dusty files in search of reusable materials. We have become so used to this circular activity that in talented hands it can pass for creativity or even genius.

LEAD: The on-going debate among hobbyists about whether ''philatelic creations'' deserve a place in a serious collection takes an odd twist in an odd corner of the world, the South Pacific island of Niuafoo.
LEAD: Plan for New Tax In Canada Irks Tour Companies

LEAD: Two very different political visions collided here today: A group of centrist Democrats asserted that the national party must change to reclaim the support of middle-class voters, while the Rev. Jesse Jackson asserted that the American mainstream was moving toward him.

LEAD: Honking his car horn to summon a friend from an apartment house above, the driver seemed unperturbed when an egg launched by someone in the building splattered on the road close to where he was parked.
LEAD: LOUISE NEVELSON A Passionate Life. By Laurie Lisle. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Summit Books. $24.95.

LEAD: ''Lost in a Flurry of Cherries,'' the Japanese experimental drama that ends its residence at La Mama E.T.C.today, is only about 70 minutes long. But by its end, the cold, mysterious play with spectacular stage effects leaves one feeling wind-blown and a little breathless from its energy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE road leading into the Mercy Center in Madison hugs a stretch of woods that taper out to the sea. Nearby, in an open parcel, stands an old greenhouse, several sand-colored buildings and a towering 18-room mansion built in the 1940's by W. T. Grant, the dime-store magnate. The house was built of brick and California redwood.

LEAD: ''And the Soul Shall Dance,'' Wakako Yamauchi's Depression-era drama, remembers the time when California law forbade Japanese immigrants to own their own land. Farmers who had come to the United States in search of a better life were obliged to sign two-year leases on the property they cultivated.

LEAD: May wedding plans for Lori Susan Winters and Theodore Rapp Samuels 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rapp Samuels of St. Louis, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morley D. Winters of St. Louis. Miss Winters, 30, graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University and received an M.B.A.
LEAD: BARBARA WALTERS An Unauthorized Biography. By Jerry Oppenheimer. Illustrated. 368 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FREE ATTRACTIONS

LEAD: A SURGE of leasing activity in Fairfield County, particularly by companies moving out of New York City, is turning Fairfield commercial realtors here bullish for the first time in almost three years.

LEAD: FACED with a rise in tourism and second-home development, officials in this western Maine mountain town are requiring developers to assume many of the public costs of growth. They must help to pay for sewer and road construction and for the hiring of staff to review projects.
LEAD: An Wang Is Dead at 70
LEAD: ''I BURIED three husbands,'' she told me. ''I don't think I have the energy for another one.''

LEAD: HEBRON'S Democratic chairman, Robert McKay, arrived early for the party's town committee meeting at Town Hall on Tuesday evening to turn on the lights and set up the metal chairs. He unfolded a few extra, he said, because this was the meeting to pick delegates to the state nominating convention in July.

LEAD: WATCH out for a spate of ''Jekyll and Hydes.'' No fewer than three musical adaptations of the 1886 Robert Louis Stevenson classic are going around. Another, a Ridiculous Theatrical Company production, which is in a class by itself and may be the most sensible approach of all, has just closed in New York.

LEAD: Dave Holmes realized that the meeting was turning into a disaster. After three uplifting days, the top worldwide managers in Du Pont's wire and cable unit had suddenly become defeatist and morose.
LEAD: Richard R. regained the lead from For Really in the final stride of a stretchlong duel to win the $110,800 Bay Shore Stakes by a long nose yesterday at Aqueduct.
LEAD: A middle-aged man with a long history of psychiatric problems and arrests for theft has been charged with possession of $20 million worth of stolen rare books.

LEAD: A conservative coalition made significant gains in parliamentary elections today, but it may not have won enough seats to wrest power from Prime Minister Bob Hawke's Labor Party, unofficial results showed.

LEAD: Fairfield, Conn.$295,000 344 Wilson Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; double-pane windows, 2-car garage; taxes not yet determined. Monroe, Conn.$220,000 371 Hammertown Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old raised ranch; 2-car garage, pool, 3 acres; taxes $2,601. Stratford, Conn.

LEAD: I realize that colleges are making a lot of money from these athletes but the opportunity for an education, when used wisely, is far more beneficial. The scholarship for an education should be the real prize. Money and the chance to play in the big leagues has become the creed of too many young athletes.

LEAD: East Orange $106,500 328 Tremont Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old colonial; eat-in-kitchen, c/a, full basement; taxes $3,005. Farmingdale $129,900 113 South Main Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 59-year-old colonial; w/w carpeting, enclosed porch, fireplace; taxes $1,559.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It is like a vast stucco spaceship, set gracefully into the brown hills just north of San Francisco, and it stands as Frank Lloyd Wright's crowning achievement on the West Coast as surely as the Guggenheim Museum culminates his career on the East Coast. The building is the Marin County Civic Center, a combination office building, courthouse and library, and it was conceived not only as an adventurous piece of architecture but also as a visionary piece of planning: a unified governmental center for a growing suburban region.
LEAD: BEAUTY AND THE BEAST Visions and Revisions of an Old Tale. By Betsy Hearne. Illustrated. 247 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $29.95.

LEAD: Joseph J. Hazelwood was by himself before the jurors, and perhaps that helped him. In the end, they did not hold him responsible for the Exxon Valdez spill last year, though he was convicted of a misdemeanor and sentenced to pay $50,000 and spend 1,000 hours cleaning oil-stained beaches.

LEAD: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Frances Dalton, a daughter of Mrs. James Joseph Dalton of Seattle and the late Mr. Dalton, to Jeremy Eardley Bloomer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Eardley Bloomer of Oley, Pa. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Margaret A. W. MacDonald, a news anchor at WSOC-TV in Charlotte, N.C., and M. Duncan Grant, a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Pepper, Hamilton & Scheetz, were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Robert Doss performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Except in obscure publications, cinematographers never get credit for the look of a movie. It's not that directors deliberately usurp the praise. But parceling out credit is so complicated that the director becomes the winner by default.

LEAD: Joseph J. Hazelwood remembers that in the worst of times, when his name was splashed in headlines and the lawsuits rolled in like the tide, he identified with the persecuted hero of a classic novel.
LEAD: PERENNIAL favorites during the holiday season, the Vienna Choir Boys will return to Bushnell Memorial Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. for a spring concert.

LEAD: RAAY-NOR'S CABIN sits on the south side of Sunrise Highway in Baldwin, a nostalgic reminder of the past. This time capsule of a restaurant, which opened in 1949, shows little evidence of the culinary changes of the last 40 years.

LEAD: The Government of President F. W. de Klerk is considering changes in South Africa's segregated system of education that could open the way for black children to start attending some white public schools next year.

LEAD: To improve response times, top officials of the Emergency Medical Service have told managers they want emergency vehicles to react to calls within seconds and personnel to spend no more than 15 minutes at scenes of emergencies, an E.M.S. official said last night.

LEAD: In a season of premature cherry blossoms and untimely tulips, one all-American plant is giving no ground to this headlong spring - symplocarpus foetidus, less elegantly known as skunk cabbage. After poking its tip out of half-frozen soil, it waited to open its burnished green and purple sheaths and now, right on schedule, is sprouting the big leaves, which, when stepped on, smell terrible.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the derivation of ''gunsel'' (Letters on Travel, Jan. 21), the word does indeed derive from the old middle-high German word Gansel (little goose). It is used to describe young, if empty-headed, girls. With that meaning, the word is still used in Bavaria, Austria and the German-speaking section of

LEAD: May wedding plans for Diane E. Dillworth and Richard E. Mayberry Jr. have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Dillworth of Hollis, Queens. Mr. Mayberry is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayberry of Rochester.

LEAD: As they vote on Sunday to elect a government freely for the first time in more than four decades, Hungarians will continue a process that began here almost two years ago, long before the political whirlwind that swept through the rest of Eastern Europe last fall.
LEAD: THE next time you hear that ''Anything Goes'' is coming around, you might as well ask, ''Which 'Anything Goes?' is it anyway?''

LEAD: The most prestigious event in the contract bridge calendar, the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, was won Friday night by a group headed by Dan Morse of Houston. His teammates were John Sutherlin of San Francisco, Tom Sanders of Nashville, Bill Pollack of Englewood, N.J., Mike Kamil of Bergenfield, N.J., and Ron Gerard of White

LEAD: ''It's going to be very artsy-craftsy,'' is the way John H. Lese describes a condominium project he has started in the center of the Hudson River village of Nyack, N.Y. The 20 two-story town houses and five shops are in four Victorian-style buildings that Mr. Lese says are being designed with projecting bays, wide board fascias and trim, and clapboard and brick finishes to ape some of the village's older buildings.

LEAD: Jacqueline Ann Sheahan, the daughter of the late Deirdre J. Sheahan of Mendham, N.J., and the late Donald P. Sheahan of New York, and Arthur Joseph Holly, the son of Mrs. Arthur J. Holly of Bloomfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Holly, have announced plans to marry in June.
LEAD: Saving the planet is very much in vogue. It's also in Harper's Bazaar, Elle and Mademoiselle.

LEAD: WIND: Stories, by Leigh Allison Wilson. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Set in upstate New York, Leigh Allison Wilson's second collection of short stories is about lost souls wandering through a world where nothing much makes sense. ''While the hard-edged, unembellished Oz that she dares to dream is a land we may not eagerly enter, it is also one we cannot easily leave,'' Jennifer Krauss said here last year.

LEAD: Gary Kasparov did not have an easy time in the Linares International Tournament in Spain, which ended Feb. 24. For the moment he has given up the Gruenfeld Defense, which he used with reasonable success against Anatoly Karpov in their last two title matches. A good guess is that he does not want everyone he meets to be educated in its niceties as a result of seeing his Karpov games.

LEAD: Deborah Shakespeare of Palm Beach, Fla., and Frank Shakespeare of La Jolla, Calif., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Fredricka Stefanie Shakespeare and Mark Scott Manning, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Manning of McFarland, Wis.
LEAD: Jack Disbrow Gunther, a chemical industry executive and conservationist, died of pneumonia on Friday in Hartford Hospital in Hartford.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 102 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 2 5 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington, the other in Hollywood.

LEAD: Since ancient times, cities have arisen out of transportation routes. New York City was no different: today's metropolis emerged from a prosperous port, but it emanated also from the metropolis below. Its streets cling to the massive transportation network beneath them. A visit to the New York Transit Museum in Brooklyn offers a chance to explore the workings of that network at leisure.
LEAD: WOMBS AND ALIEN SPIRITS Women, Men and the Zar Cult in Northern Sudan. By Janice Boddy. 399 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $23.95.
LEAD: ''This has the feel,'' said the man from Nikko Securities, ''of a bubble being burst.''

LEAD: This is in response to Dan Harrison's attack on County Legislator Paul Feiner's introduction of legislation to ban styrofoam food containers in Westchester [Letters to the Westchester Editor, Feb. 18] .

LEAD: As I sit here writing my check to pay another installment of my student loan, my heart bleeds for today's student athletes. Having their dorm rooms, tuition and books paid for isn't enough. The universities now need to pay them some spending money on the side.

LEAD: JAMES MICHENER has said that books are a ''marvelous instrument of civilization,'' imbued with the power ''to monitor and give guidance to nations.'' Harry Hoffman, chief executive of Waldenbooks, the largest American bookstore chain, recently asserted that books are often ill-conceived products that are filled with too many pages and too much small print to be able to ''counter things like Nintendo and television.
LEAD: THE CLONING OF JOANNA MAY By Fay Weldon. 265 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: THE GOOD NEWS IS THAT EPIDENDRUM ilense (above), a rare orchid native to Ecuador, is being propagated in cultivation to the degree that it is available to collectors. The bad news is that ilense has almost certainly disappeared from its natural habitat, a casualty of the dwindling rain forest.

LEAD: AIDS is fast becoming the worst epidemic of the century in New York City. The disease has already claimed the lives of more than 16,000 men, women and children, and health officials suspect the actual number is higher than medical records show.
LEAD: No loitering, no talking, no negativism. But have fun, guys.

LEAD: ''History cannot remember a time when we did not hate our women,'' Gerry Spence, the Wyoming lawyer, wrote in his 1986 book, ''Trial by Fire: The True Story of a Woman's Ordeal at the Hands of the Law.'' He was referring to Miss Wyoming, whom he represented in a libel suit against Penthouse magazine.

LEAD: One of the biggest attractions of the pop music world is following the spins of its wheel of fortune and watching where the golden arrow comes to rest. Each month brings a surprise or two, but when a deserving artist like Bonnie Raitt is suddenly, unexpectedly rewarded, one's fascination in the whole hit-making process becomes rekindled.

LEAD: Now the terrorists of the Middle East are threatening to bomb the planes and airports of some of the countries that supplied them with explosives and guns for so long - the Soviet Union and its recent satellites in Eastern Europe.
LEAD: My attention has been called to the Feb. 25 article ''Tokyo Quartet Playing Beethoven Cycle.''
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: THE names may change in the restaurant business, but often the premises, the ownership and sometimes even the type of cuisine remain the same. That is largely the case with the new Beijing restaurant in downtown Stamford, whose previous name was Ching Ching. The cream-colored walls, dark wainscoting and seating arrangements are familiar and seemingly changeless.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: If Sandinista militants doubted the political orthodoxy of a comrade named Herty Lewites Rodriguez, they got their proof on election day. While other Sandinista candidates were crushed in the national balloting on Feb. 25, Mr. Lewites turned this tidy village into a something of an electoral miracle, leading his hometown Sandinista ticket to victory by a margin of 24 percentage points.

LEAD: Behind closed doors, Myanmar's military rulers are committing monstrous deeds. The latest is a mass forced relocation of the urban population reminiscent of Pol Pot's Cambodia. The outside world could bring effective pressure for change - but only if all concerned put humanity ahead of commercial advantage.

LEAD: I couldn't help but notice in the photographs accompanying your article ''When British Justice Failed,'' by Kevin Toolis (Feb. 25), on page 35, in the photograph of the aftermath of the bombing of the Horse and Groom, the two men who appear to be comforting the dazed woman in the foreground bear an uncanny resemblance to the two Irish Republican Army men as pictured in the inset photographs.

LEAD: Why does one listen to old recordings, especially to very old ones with their surface noise and low-end reproduction of sound? One potent reason is the simple lure of history. Records now reach back far beyond the memories of even the most senior concertgoers, and to the extent that musical interpretation is an important sphere of endeavor, its history is worth understanding.

LEAD: FROM its beginning almost four years ago, the story of the Iroquois pipeline has not been pleasant. In meeting after meeting with residents of the towns along its proposed route, the company planning it has encountered a loud and long barrage of verbal and legal opposition. Nevertheless, the project's propects became stronger.

LEAD: Even a generally first-rate television production can leave the impression of an opportunity missed - especially when the focus in on the extraordinarily urgent subject of racial tensions in the United States.

LEAD: Three years ago, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Committee on Curricula approved a 12-subject experimental program titled ''Human Contexts of Science and Technology.'' It was an attempt to make undergraduates more aware of the impact of science and engineering on society.

LEAD: After several days of intensive consultations with the small religious parties that could put him in power, the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, has made no visible progress toward obtaining the one vote he needs to form a new Government.

LEAD: The Lipton's new and youngest champion, Monica Seles, still 16 and sprouting fast, had quieted her renegade giggle and erupted in less triumphant grunts in the year that passed since she captured her first and only championship at Houston.

LEAD: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was in custody yesterday on charges that he raped or sexually abused six girls, aged 9 to 17, often in hallways or elevators or on rooftops in the Brownsville section, the police said.
LEAD: The Thai Prime Minister has proposed moving about 276,000 displaced Cambodians from existing border camps to neutral ones free of political control by the warring Cambodian factions.

LEAD: What is it about Paris that brings out that extra bit of flair in the way women dress, that makes an outfit look just that much smarter than it would anywhere else? LEAD: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the article (Travel, March 4) on my favorite place, Petra. I know it well, having spent several months over the past few years engaged in photographic work there.
LEAD: IN a case of competitive shuttle diplomacy, Westchester and Suffolk County officials have been flying back and forth to Washington to plead for Federal help in fighting Lyme disease.

LEAD: News flash: The Kennedy Library at Harvard University, to encourage better leadership, will bestow its first Profile in Courage Award this year on a public official who follows his conscience instead of the opinion polls.

LEAD: Margaret Louise Jacobs, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. J. Kenneth Jacobs of Nashville, was married there last evening at the Temple to Samuel Allan Flax, a son of Mrs. Louis Flax of Rockville, Md., and the late Mr. Flax. Rabbis Randall Falk and Stephen Fuchs officiated.

LEAD: AT the Blue Hill Cultural Center here, it is spring. The Canada geese, without which no such center is complete, are stomping around the lake and the equally predictable Henry Moore bronze figure, a splash of verdigris in a taupe landscape, seems ready to join them.

LEAD: College athletes should be paid; too many of them spend years of their lives entertaining the public without ever receiving the lucre now associated with a professional career. However, unlike the pros, all college athletes should be paid the exact same wage, whether they are starting centers or benchwarmers.

LEAD: Television viewers this week will have a chance to see three short, offbeat movies that are the results of a project designed to nurture a fresh crop of directors eager to try their hand at feature-length films. Presented under the umbrella title ''Triple Play,'' the package will be shown on PBS's American Playhouse series Wednesday at 9 P.M.

LEAD: MATTHEW MURPHY, a 24-year-old a page at the Scarsdale Library, recently bought a bicycle with his own money. ''He is so proud of it,'' said his mother, Helen F. Murphy. ''His wheels have made him even more independent. And knowing that he earned the money himself gives him such satisfaction.''
