LEAD: International organizations increasingly rank this strife-torn Andean nation among the world's violators of human rights.

LEAD: The marriage of Lisa Kathleen Guglielmone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tito W. Guglielmone of Oakdale, L.I., to Frederick Joseph Gillis, a son of Miriam Gillis of Port Charlotte, Fla., and the late Judge Joseph A. Gillis of Detroit, took place yesterday at St. John Nepomucene Roman Catholic Church in Bohemia, L.I.

LEAD: Dr. Sylvia R. Kodsi, a resident in ophthalmology at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York, and Dr. Michael E. Rettig, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the New York University Medical Center, plan a May wedding.
LEAD: The Devils got into sync at the Spectrum this afternoon and ended a losing streak at two games with a 5-2 triumph over the Flyers.

LEAD: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?
LEAD: As a person who tries to watch his weight and keep in fair physical condition, I am constantly reading articles about foods, recipes and so forth and their effects on our bodies.

LEAD: Lithuanian officials refused today to comply with Moscow's demand to turn over hundreds of army deserters, declaring that they would not be intimidated by the Kremlin's theatrical early morning parade of tanks and military vehicles here in the Lithuanian capital.

LEAD: THE weather has felt like spring on and off for weeks but now it's official. And like the wardrobe and the garden, it's time for the menu to change Springtime calls for asparagus, artichokes, shad, soft-shell crabs, your own newly created salads, new potatoes, fresh herbs, scallions and light soups, stews and pasta dishes.

LEAD: A month ago in this space a question was posed: Would ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' Warner's smash-hit cop thriller released on Feb. 8 at $24.98, sell as well as or better than it rents? Furthermore, would a movie rated R sell in a family-oriented market? And would it sell after the Christmas season - in years past, the prime time for selling videos?

LEAD: Sit in a room long enough with Margaret Tyzack and sooner or later, as at that fabled Parisian cafe, everyone you know will pass by. Miss Tyzack, who opens with Maggie Smith in Peter Shaffer's ''Lettice and Lovage'' this evening on Broadway at the Barrymore, is a natural chameleon, with a temperament so mercurial that she seems, as she talks, to take on a new persona with each thought.

LEAD: As the population of gypsy moths begins to rise throughout the Northeast, one state, New Jersey, is about to begin the largest spraying program in its history to try to counter the devastation that the leaf-eating insect is expected to inflict this year.

LEAD: Frustrated by what they call a moral wasteland on campus, politically conservative Harvard students have founded a magazine that they say preaches the ''absolute truth'' on issues like abortion, homosexuality and affirmative action.

LEAD: Peter Wheeler's recent letter to the New Jersey editor in response to my interview on machine translation seems to miss certain points. First, I was not talking about how to run a translation service business. I was talking about fully automatic high-quality machine translation systems.

LEAD: THE Governor of New Jersey has come came up with an alternative to tiptoeing around tax increases: jump in with both feet, to the tune of $2 billion; and while you're at it, overhaul the tax system, wipe out a $580 million deficit and redistribute wealth all at the same time.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Richard Pullman, a truck driver, got a rude awakening on New Year's Day, when he discoverd that thieves had stolen his truck and cargo while he was sleeping in a motel in Evanston, Wyo.

LEAD: American and European corporations are hunting a rare and elusive quarry: the high-level Japanese executive willing to abandon lifetime employment with a Japanese company for speedier advancement and more money at a Western concern.

LEAD: Some see the West Regional final matchup between Loyola Marymount University and the University of Nevada, Las Vegas here Sunday as classic: the good guys (L.M.U., if you've been following the sports news the last couple weeks) against the bad guys (U.N.L.V., if you've been following the sports news the last few decades).

LEAD: Three huge blobs and a giant baby took over the stage on March 17at the Triplex Theater I of the Borough of Manhattan Community College. One blob even rolled into the audience and seized a woman's shoe for its dinner. At moments like these, Imago, the Theater Mask Ensemble, was inspired fun that had the audience squealing with laughter.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was most surprised to read that visitors to Boston are advised to call the Boston Garden for information on tickets for Celtics games (''What's Doing in Boston,'' Travel, Jan. 7). One has as much chance of obtaining Celtics tickets from the Garden box office as winning the lottery.
LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle winding up to deliver a pitch during a visit to the Oakland Athletics' training camp Friday in Phoenix. (Associated Press)

LEAD: NOW is the time to think about having enough water for the garden. Although no one can ever predict the weather accurately, it is practical to think ahead. Even those pundits who forecast weather several days in advance are often wrong.

LEAD: While I am reluctant to sound a dissonant note about the schools' attempt to build self-esteem, I feel compelled to write to speak negatively about a Band-Aid approach to children's emotional well-being.

LEAD: There are still people in Elba, Ala., who remember March 14, 1929, when flood waters from the Pea River inundated the small southeastern Alabama community, almost wiping it off the map. But once the 3.2-mile-long levee surrounding the town was built in 1938, no one ever expected to see that kind of devastation again.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Lennard Wharton of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ruth Margot Wharton to Stephen J. McDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. McDonald of Canton, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The ''Your Own Account'' column on March 11, discussing loans against 401 (k) plans, misstated the tax deductibility of interest on such loans in 1990. No interest deduction is allowed for 401 (k) loans secured by employee pre-tax contributions.

LEAD: The marriage of Terrell Elizabeth Polk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Polk of Lake Charles, La., to Thomas Raymond Donahue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Donahue of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE first Federal allocation for studying Lyme disease is the incentive for a contest of sorts between Westchester and Suffolk Counties, whose officials are competing here for a share of the $500,000 available.
LEAD: RENOIR ON RENOIR Interviews, Essays, and Remarks. By Jean Renoir. Translated by Carol Volk. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $47.50. Paper, $14.95.
LEAD: The United States and Japan have begun to defuse the trade tensions threatening to destroy their global partnership.

LEAD: ''I'm a wild animal; no one can tame me,'' says David Cale, expressing his outsider's vision of the world. There is something undomesticated, almost anti-theatrical about this performance artist. Those unfamiliar with his work might wonder if he had just wandered on stage from the audience. Because the sky is blue, he asks if he is breathing blue air - and he contemplates what birds are thinking about as they fly, leaving the suggestion that thinking might be antithetical to flying.

LEAD: Having watched and waited as two leading contenders bloodied each other in an image-bruising power struggle, Prime Minister Michel Rocard has emerged as favorite to become the Socialist Party's candidate to succeed President Francois Mitterrand.

LEAD: Each of the last four years, the Government of Japan has declared a well-publicized war on this country's astronomical and still-rising land prices, the world's highest. But despite the strong oratory, the soldiers in the war never seem to leave their barracks.

LEAD: For good reasons as well as bad, audio lives by unceasing innovation. New ideas constantly come along, partly to keep the kettle boiling (that's a bad reason) and partly because nothing is ever quite good enough for perfectionists (let's call that a good one).

LEAD: William E. Grady High School of Brooklyn completed its finest basketball season ever tonight by winning the New York State Federation Class A championship with a 78-67 victory over Hempstead of Long Island before a crowd of 3,292 at the Civic Center here.
LEAD: ''GOOD evening, ma'am. This is a ride spot-check.
LEAD: Felix W. Salmaggi, an opera impresario and theater manager, died of cancer on Monday at the Hospice of Northern Virginia in Arlington, Va. He was 77 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Rushton W. Skakel of Greenwich, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced October wedding plans for Mrs. Skakel's daughter Elizabeth Marion Howland and Robert E. Mallozzi 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mallozzi of Darien, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla.

LEAD: From the outside, today's automobiles still appear to be nearly all steel. But about 8 percent of their weight consists of composites -strong, light combinations of complementary substances. Bumpers, doors, body panels and station wagon tailgates are all commonly made from these materials. Ten years ago, the composite content was less than 2 percent; by the year 2000, some producers of composites contend, their materials will predominate.

LEAD: With the victory by a group of conservative parties in East German elections last Sunday seeming to pave the way for a quick reunification of the Germanys, investment strategists are busy picking ''unification plays.''

LEAD: Judith Lynn Slayback, an electrical engineer, and Gary Joseph Sikora, a senior engineer, both at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in Baltimore, are planning a May wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Russell Slayback of Greens Farms, Conn., have announced. Mr. Sikora is a son of Mr.

LEAD: FOR more than 40 years, 401 Fifth Avenue, the old Tiffany Building at 37th Street, has been a notorious object lesson in how not to treat a landmark. Its facade is begrimed, its windows are dirty and storefronts have been shoved into what was once the most elegant selling floor in New York.

LEAD: Jill Andrea Rose, a teacher in the Westside Montessori School, and Steven G. Shapiro, a partner in the law firm of Mantel & Shapiro, both in Manhattan, were married last evening at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Colton performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Nine months after she had been raped, with her trauma still fresh and the case against her assailant languishing in court, Nancy Ziegenmeyer was sitting in the Grinnell College library, studying the law of sexual assault. During a break in her work, she came across a column in The Des Moines Register.
LEAD: EVER YOURS, FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE Selected Letters. Edited by Martha Vicinus and Bea Nergaard. 461 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: Travelers to Greece more than a century ago returned to other European countries with the eyeless, mouthless Cycladic idols that historians at the time described as primitive, even ugly. Today these 5,000-year-old white marble figures - most of which depict women with their arms folded flat against their chests - are among the most prized of ancient artifacts and are viewed by many curators, historians and collectors as, in Picasso's words, ''magical objects.
LEAD: They are gone but not forgotten. And, this may come as a shock to students of ''chemistry'' in sports, the mythical men of the Mets are not entirely missed.

LEAD: A band of youths who call themselves the Legion of Doom mandated the death penalty for members who dated outside the group, and they tried to carry out the sentence on an 18-year-old member, the police charge.

LEAD: All college athletes in revenue-producing sports should be paid. To ease the burden on smaller, less affluent programs, the N.C.A.A. should set aside money from all tournament revenue and provide participants their shares. All athletes would be paid equally, using minimum wage as a guideline, just as if their extracurricular activity were a part-time campus job.

LEAD: Joanne Zaiac, a management supervisor at Wunderman Worldwide, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam in New York, was married last evening to Robert D. Coven, an associate at Paine Webber in New York. Rabbi Gary Glickstein officiated at Temple Beth Sholom in Miami Beach. The bride, who is 28 years old and will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr.

You may recall that two thieves made off with more than $200 million worth of masterpieces: Vermeer, Rembrandt, Degas, Manet and, somewhat inexplicably, a bronze beaker from the

LEAD: A two-year-old company, Phoenix Lasers Systems Inc., in San Francisco, has applied laser techniques developed for the military to ophthalmic surgery. The new system combines a low-energy blue-green laser with a computer workstation. The system is employed in the surgical technique called refractive keraplasty, which is used to alter the shape of the cornea to repair vision impairments, including near- and far-sightedness and glaucoma.

LEAD: CONTRADICTIONS, YES. CONTROVERSY, NO. IN AJU thimble, that will be the most provocative story from the American fall fashion market. As Seventh Avenue's top designers and manufacturers gear up for the all-important showings that start this week and crescendo the next, it is clear that no dramatic silhouette shifts are in store.

LEAD: No one could accuse Donald Byrd of timidity. From the start of his choreographic career in the mid-1970's, Mr. Byrd has taken on complex issues including prejudice, the effects of negative reviews on artists, the AIDS crisis and life seen as an evening in a disco. His choreographic voice - and electric presence - are both velvety and intensely abrasive.

LEAD: THE FOOD OF NAPLES, LIKE THEJU city itself, is at its most exuberant at Easter when this ancient town shakes off the torpor induced by Lent and the gray damp of a Mediterranean winter. Neapolitan cooks are brimming with vitality, turning out feasts with gusto. But the food at Easter feasts throughout the city is far from the pizza and spaghetti with red sauce that most Americans associate with Naples.

LEAD: THE Hoff-Barthelson School in Scarsdale opens its 25th yearly Baroque Festival tonight at 7 P.M. and it continues later at several sites as student, faculty and guest artists perform.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has had commissioners leave state service for the private sector before, but Julio A. Martinez will be the first to turn up under the Governor's second-floor window at the State Capitol in Albany selling hot dogs, knishes and soda. Mr. Martinez, a former heroin addict who was often described as ''inspiring'' by Mr.

LEAD: WHEN spring presents the opportunity to open a home to the outdoors, owners of double-hung windows often find them stuck tight. Sometimes, the cause is paint applied during a winter remodeling; most of the time, the cause is swelling of wooden window parts because of moisture.

LEAD: ARTHUR WALLACE, a smarmy divorce lawyer, is railing about the decline of the nuclear family. Forty-seven percent of the households in New York City are merged - the result of split-ups and remarriages.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: When people say they have too little sun to grow flowers, I like to show them a tiny ''garden room'' by the northeast corner of my house in Princeton, N. J. It is nine-feet by nine and one-half feet, shaded, and filled with wonderful blossoms.

LEAD: Margaret M. Harkin and Joseph P. Richardson were married yesterday at St. Aedan's Roman Catholic Church in Pearl River, N.Y., by the Rev. Albert Polt. Mrs. Richardson, 23 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Harkin of New City, N.Y. A graduate of Fordham University, she is an officer in consumer banking at the Chemical Banking Corporation in New York.

LEAD: All of Gerhard Richter's work can be seen as a struggle with ideology. He has moved back and forth between abstract and figurative styles, and between small hazy photorealist still lifes and landscapes and large gestural abstractions so physical that they seem to take over their room. He has consistently tried to make art that is provocative and pleasing without advancing any one program or theory.

LEAD: FROM Manhattan, where television signals can't leap tall buildings in a single bound, to Manhattan, Kan., people cannot live without cable television. But much as they love it, some viewers love to hate it, too.

LEAD: Laurel Watts, a student at Brown University, grew up believing that Communism was a ''done deal.'' Now that the regimes are unraveling, she wants to see what is going on, especially among her counterparts. ''They're a curiosity to us because they're the people we weren't supposed to meet,'' she said.
LEAD: Pat LaFontaine scored his second goal of the game and 51st of the season with 44 seconds left in the third period to give the Islanders a 5-5 tie with the Edmonton Oilers tonight.

LEAD: Kevin Toolis's article helped to rectify the slander against four blameless individuals. The author, however, may have overlooked the most sobering aspect of the case: was it bigotry - or racism - that triggered the illegal and excessive response of the authorities?

LEAD: Sheila Anne Maher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Maher of Palm City, Fla., was married yesterday to Gregory John Mayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Mayer of Ludlow, Vt. The Rev. Philip Galiano, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at O'Byrne Chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N

LEAD: Absolutely not. College is not an institution where athletes should be paid. They should pay attention to getting good grades and completing school. If it gets that far, why not pay high school athletes? This way by the time they reach college, they can be well off within four years, or less.
LEAD: AGAINST THE GRAIN An Autobiography. By Boris Yeltsin. Translated by Michael Glenny. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

LEAD: All sides in Nicaragua's long civil conflict today hailed the contras' agreement on Friday to disband their army, apparently eliminating the most important obstacle to a peaceful transfer of power on April 25 between the Sandinistas and the newly elected government.
LEAD: The Government sent soldiers across the province of Kosovo today to restore order after renewed unrest touched off by a mysterious illness affecting hundreds of ethnic Albanians.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A retired general in the armed forces of the Dominican Republic has jumped bond and returned to his homeland rather than face trial on charges of a bribery scheme aimed at freeing seized drug-smuggling planes, the Government says.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Harman Brown Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Susan Harman Brown and Brian Wilfred Haumersen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Haumersen of Cambridge, Md.

LEAD: LIKE much of Brazil's heritage, the tradition of Brazilian needlepoint comes from its Portuguese past. The stitches found in intricate needlepoint tapestries or rugs have been developed from the Portuguese Arraiolos stitch, named after a small town in Portugal.
LEAD: FOREPLAY By Catherine Roman. 386 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

LEAD: As other Latin American countries clamp down on illicit narcotics, Ecuador is emerging as an important shipment point both for importing chemicals needed to produce cocaine and for exporting the drug itself to the United States, Federal officials say.
LEAD: Some tanks that store atomic waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation could explode and spew radiation into the air because hydrogen gas is building up inside them, a new Federal study says.

LEAD: The fifth annual Morningside Dance Festival got off to a briskly produced start on Tuesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The weeklong festival, presented by the Department of the Arts in Education at Teachers College of Columbia University, opened with eight works that stressed the virtues of solid craft and literate themes.

LEAD: To the Editor: The recent discussion regarding excessive profits by American agencies renting cottages in Britain (Letters on Travel, Jan. 14) prompts us to share a similar experience. We wrote to a series of British rental agencies directly. Several responded promptly with brochures, including one from an agency in Virginia.

LEAD: In their first encounter since their countries ended a 12-year rift in December, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today in Libya, the official Libyan news agency said.

LEAD: FOR most visitors to Brazil, the only glimpse of the land mass between Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo comes as a green blur from the window of an airplane, en route from one city to the other. The area is known as the Costa Verde, or Green Coast, and even from an altitude of 23,000 feet there is no mistaking why.
LEAD: PACE UNIVERSITY has reached to Chicago for a new president to help focus the identity of an increasingly comprehensive and complex educational system as it prepares for a new century.

LEAD: When the lights flickered out in President Vytautas Landsbergis's office one evening this week, Carla Gruodis feared Moscow was at work again, turning up the psychological pressure on the Lithuanian President and his rebellious Government.

LEAD: The engagement of Anita Miriam Moss to Philip Matthew Sher has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Moss of New York. Mr. Sher is a son of Miriam Sher of Johannesburg. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Come Easter, three weeks hence, some people will stick bunny ears through holes cut in their straw hats and take a stroll down Fifth Avenue. Others will place things like stuffed chickadees, wooden soldiers, origami tulips and dried fruit on their hats, as they take part in the annual procession past St.

LEAD: There's no question that as far as kids are concerned, parents can be downright embarrassing at times. It's true that some parents manage to scrape by and that some are actually O.K. But generally, in the eyes of most offspring, parents could stand a lot of improvement.

LEAD: ON A MILD, LATE-JANUARY DAY, WHILE his fellow professionals scramble toward a weekend payday on the Monterey Peninsula some 3,000 miles away, Curtis Strange is back home on the range, hard at practice. With monotonous regularity, Strange, a lanky, prematurely gray-haired 35-year-old, slaps golf ball after golf ball into the slight Virginia breeze.

LEAD: CHANCELLOR HELMUT KOHL customarily reaches his maximum heft at this time of year, just before his annual Eastertime course of weight reduction. A year ago, with public opinion polls tracking a precipitous plunge, the bulk seemed to be political dead weight. This year it looks like pure gold: Mr. Kohl stands at the peak of his career, and if things keep going his way, by this time next year he could be the first chancellor of a reunited Germany.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Patricia Crews and Scott Moger were married last evening by Rabbi Phillip A. Labowitz at the Brazilian Court Hotel in Palm Beach, Fla. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Zagor of New York and Norwich, Vt. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Moger of Sunrise, Fla.

LEAD: Gerald V. Bull, a Canadian-born rocket scientist and international arms consultant who ran afoul of a weapons embargo against South Africa, was shot to death on Thursday night at his apartment in a suburb of Brussels, the authorities said. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: College athletes are already paid. They live in preferred accommodations called athletic dorms. They eat at special restaurants called training tables. They get weekend trips - staying at five-star hotels, when motels are available to provide the same basic services. They are provided with great seats at all their games, tickets that are often scalped.

LEAD: At the first informal meeting of the Bush Cabinet, in Blair House a week before the Inauguration, George Bush pulled a handwritten list out of his pocket and read what he called ''The Marching Orders.''

LEAD: In prospect, Dave Edmunds's Rock-and-Roll Revue was a fine idea. Mr. Edmunds - a Welsh guitarist, singer and producer who is one of the most knowledgeable fans of basic rock-and-roll - would sing a few songs, then lend his band to kindred spirits: the 1950's Bronx doo-wopper Dion, the English songwriter Graham Parker and the Texas blues-soul singer Kim Wilson of the Fabulous Thunderbirds.

LEAD: Yes, pay college basketball players! Rename Division I the N.C.A.B.A. (with B for basketball) and continue the championship format as it exists now, recognizing it for what it truly is: a revenue-producing business with paid athletes whose primary interest is athletics, who are representing the college during their contracted four-year tenure.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: James D. Heslin, an executive with the Tishman Construction Corporation for 23 years, died of a heart attack on Thursday at St. Clare's Hospital in New York City. He was 60 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

LEAD: Marion Paisley Nammack and Richard Stuart Paganello, account executives at Authenticolor, a New York graphics concern, were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York by the Rev. Richard Leonard. Mrs. Paganello, 34 years old, is a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Griswold Paisley Delacroix Nammack.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL The Tokyo stock market has caught New York on the way down. An investor who bought Japanese stocks on Sept. 4, 1987 would now be no better off than one who bought American stocks the same day. A 6.9 percent drop in the Nikkei average last week, to 30,372.16, left the total value of Tokyo's stocks slightly lower than New York's.

LEAD: Colleges with major basketball and football programs should be allowed to recruit talented athletes who are academically unqualified and hire them to play their sports. These players would receive salaries, live in apartments off campus, and have four years of eligibility. They would neither attend classes nor earn credits toward degrees.
LEAD: PALESTINE AND ISRAEL The Uprising and Beyond. By David McDowall. 322 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95.

LEAD: For all the high-flying rebounds and wondrous shots that Arkansas and Texas tossed at each other here this afternoon, the finish came down to one of basketball's most elementary phases: free throws. Hit or miss. Arkansas missed plenty in the waning minutes, but the Razorbacks' Ron Huery made two crucial ones with 16 seconds left to lift Arkansas to an 88-85 victory and the Midwest Regional championship before 16,143 in Reunion Arena.
LEAD: India withdrew the last of its troops from Sri Lanka today, ending an ill-fated three-year involvement in the island's ethnic strife.

LEAD: With his ammunition dumps resupplied, Gen. Michel Aoun, commander of the Christian part of the Lebanese Army, is ready to open a new offensive to suppress his militia rivals in the Christian enclave north of here, Lebanese military officials said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Twenty-seven people were injured today in an evacuation of a Cathay Pacific Airways jet from Hong Kong with 300 passengers that began leaking fuel after landing at Narita airport here, officials said. Strong winds rocked the inflatable escape chutes, knocking the passengers down, officials said. All but one of the injured were released later today after treatment.

LEAD: YOU'RE GOING TO SEE some changes on the ice,'' a construction engineer told me as we changed into polar garb for the flight from New Zealand to Antarctica. ''Whatever you do, don't get caught throwing away a cigarette butt or beer can.''

LEAD: BAVARIA, in the 18th century, was one of the largest states in Germany, a prosperous electorate whose rulers and people shared a taste for cheerful splendor, and in the rococo, then the prevailing international style, they found just the right way to express themselves. The result is a dazzling series of secular and religious buildings, many of them set in spectacular

LEAD: If the world were as simple as we sometimes wish it could be, cameras would look the same, do the same things and cost the same. But man's ingenuity knows no bounds, so we are faced with a plethora of models, features and competing brands.
LEAD: With the Knicks apparently headed for the playoffs, the team has announced details of a postcard lottery to allocate tickets to home games.

LEAD: There is considerable disagreement among biologists and anglers over whether Atlantic coast stocks of Atlantic striped bass have recovered sufficiently to allow more harvesting by sport and commercial interests in the coming season.
LEAD: A Federal district judge here has temporarily blocked enforcement of a new Guam law that is the most restrictive abortion statute in any American jurisdiction.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article ''Suddenly, It's Eastern Europe'' (Travel, Feb. 11) failed to highlight one of the great attractions of visiting Eastern Europe this year: remarkably low prices not seen in Western Europe for decades. Currency reform in several Eastern European countries gives tourists more local money per dollar than ever before.

LEAD: Concerts devoted to the works of a single composer may lack the variety we expect of an evening in the concert hall. But one virtue they offer is unity. The listener, once drawn into the composer's world, need not jump centuries and styles every 20 minutes.

LEAD: The Democratic Party today approved the rules under which it will pick its 1992 Presidential candidate, and did so with a speed and civility that was almost breathtaking to party leaders who lived through the fierce squabbles of the last two decades.

LEAD: The life of Ernest Hemingway has been chronicled, celebrated and analyzed so exhaustively that its scenes now constitute the elements of a myth, the periodic retracing of which has become a kind of pilgrimage (or gravy train) taken by writers and readers alike. A. E. Hotchner, the author of ''Papa Hemingway,'' a classic of Hemingway hagiography, has hit the trail again and served up in HEMINGWAY AND HIS WORLD (Vendome Press, $45) an encyclopedic buffet, full of fascinating rare photos of

LEAD: Sometimes science is served best by unscientific methods. For years researchers wondered if the hairy-eared dwarf lemur still existed; they had never seen one alive. Last week it was reported that the animal, the second smallest primate (the mouse lemur is smaller in dry seasons), was alive and well in a Madagascar rain forest.

LEAD: An article last week about people involved in savings and loan failures included erroneous statements about Thomas M. Gaubert, the former head of the Independent American Savings and Loan Association of Dallas. Mr. Gaubert has not been sued in a civil case by the Government. In an agreement with regulators, he was banned from the savings industry in 1986 because of dealings with an Iowa savings institution that led to large losses, not because of the failure of his own institution.

LEAD: A successful sports program can be a university's foremost attraction when it comes to recruiting students, not just athletes but eggheads such as myself. While at the University of North Carolina, I carried out my plan to have a double major: English and basketball attendance. Student athletes are a useful commodity, they bring exposure and revenue to colleges.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A SLIGHT rush of musty, stone-cooled air wafts through the opening as the guide pockets his key and steps into the dark behind the door. He flicks on a feeble light to illuminate a narrow stairway leading down into the tomb, and motions for us to descend.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FIVE months into the nation's first complete state takeover of a public school system, Dr. Elena J. Scambio, the state-appointed Superintendent in Jersey City, is trying to combine the big stick with a soft touch as she seeks to lift the city's educational system from the morass it has floundered in for years.

LEAD: AS today's fast-track couples scramble to keep on top of their jobs and raise the children, there is little time left for anything else, least of all romance. So believes Candice Barnett-Foti, who is building her business by trying to make every day Valentine's Day.

LEAD: To the Editor: I found it ironic that on the day we were making a 10-hour journey home from Whistler, British Columbia, to New York you published a glowing report on ''Endless Trails in Western Canada'' (Travel, Jan. 21). Our experience was quite different from your reporter's.

LEAD: When a piano competition offers its winner an Alice Tully Hall recital and when the first prize is shared, what is the equitable solution? Simple multiplication, according to the Palm Beach Invitational International Piano Competition - two winners, two full recitals, back to back on a single evening.

LEAD: The New Yorker, whose shabby, cluttered, out-at-the-elbow offices have been a constant in the midtown literary scene since 1935, finally is moving - but only 60 feet south. Now at 25 West 43d Street, Eustace Tilley will flit across to 20 West 43d and more space in November, along with 300 other employees.

LEAD: Alan Weisman's article (''An Island in Limbo,'' Feb. 18) helps to bring more understanding to the problem facing Puerto Rico for so long. I cannot agree more with Cancel Miranda's statement, ''Any foreigner has more rights than Puerto Ricans in their own land.'' I visited Puerto Rico and came back pained.

LEAD: Will Dave Winfield, Kirk Gibson and Dwight Gooden be ready for the start of the season? Are Carlos Baerga, Eric Anthony and Ben McDonald ready to take their places as major league starters? Do Gary Carter, Dan Quisenberry and Bill Buckner have enough left to warrant being given jobs? Can Rick Aguilera adjust to a pivotal new role?
LEAD: The words collaborative and interdisciplinary do not trip off the tongue of the average 9-year-old, but some fourth graders at the Post Road School here have learned them in a special way.
LEAD: On the fifth day of a gentle spring, with the Yankees working under a warm sun and George Steinbrenner observing from the dugout, the mystery of the missing pitcher took another strange twist.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Soviet Union is entitled to pursue deserters from its army but should not act against the independence movement in Lithuania, Vice President Dan Quayle said today.

LEAD: IT is just after 9 A.M. on a Friday in the middle of the month. Many of the stiff plastic chairs at the Essex County welfare office on Rector Street in Newark are already filled with women and babies, grandmothers, lunch bags and, here and there, a few men. Phones ring and ring unanswered, and from behind the long counter a woman calls for the next client.

LEAD: They came to New York from Israel a year and a half ago. She was planning to pursue her painting, he was thinking of ''spending some time in Central Park enjoying his life.'' But somehow, Lynda and Shimon Sandhaus's big adventure took an unexpected turn. The couple started a business of reproducing fragments of Mrs.

LEAD: The question is not whether the college athlete should be paid; he (or she) is paid now, in an approved, legitimate, and generous way. At Notre Dame for example, each of the 19 incoming football scholarship freshmen receive a yearly benefit (tuition, room, board) having an approximate value of $15,000.

LEAD: AMID the feast of information and candor set forth by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, it is worth pointing out that the spectral figure of agitprop - the weary old Bolshevik specialist in manipulating information - still holds a high place at the table of glasnost. In the war of nerves between the Kremlin and the breakaway republic of Lithuania, Soviet Government dominance of most information channels has been on display with a pervasiveness that Lenin first dreamed of.

LEAD: Q. We inherited some walnut furniture that has a considerable amount of carving. We would like to strip off the old finish down to the original wood. We called for professional estimates, but found the cost quite high, and so we would like to do the stripping ourselves. Can you offer some pointers?

LEAD: Before reading ''The Drink of Millions'' I would have assumed that Joseph Conway, head of the Bureau of Water Supply, had at least an inkling that it is important to conserve water. Isn't his agency responsible for all those ''Don't Drip New York Dry'' posters I see in public restrooms and on the subway?

LEAD: Dr. Shelley B. Weinstock, an assistant professor of chemistry at Barnard College, and Paul V. Bartick, a children's author and a staff consultant at the Children's Television Workshop in New York, were married last evening at the Columbia University Chapel. Rabbi Michael Paley officiated.

LEAD: Sure, go ahead and pay the college athlete; continue to foster the illusion of success that participation in a Division I program perpetuates. An illusion I might add that will principally affect the black athlete, already disillusioned by the prospects of acquiring a piece of the American Dream.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 18 about skiing in Switzerland referred incorrectly to Zermatt. As a reader has recently written to point out, Zermatt indeed has snow-making machines, at the Rothorn-Blauherd-Sunnegga area and the Theodul section.

LEAD: The United States has made it clear to the Soviet Union that using force in Lithuania would harm Soviet-American relations but is still accepting Moscow's assurances that no such action will be taken, Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today in an interview. Other Administration officials said there were signs of heightened Soviet military activity in the Baltic republics but no indication of an impending crackdown.
LEAD: A plan to make legal aid agencies bid for the right to represent some children in Family Court has opened a dispute over the way the city hires lawyers to represent poor people.

LEAD: It was well past midnight as police cruisers and ambulances converged, screeched to a halt and disgorged dozens of paramedics and police SWAT teams in front of the Allegheny County Soldiers and Sailors War Memorial Hall on Fifth Avenue. High drama turned into low comedy when a paramedic knocked over a stretcher, a cop had an unmanly struggle getting out of a cruiser and another cop's gun belt fell off.
LEAD: CERVANTES By Jean Canavaggio. Translated by J. R. Jones. 348 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended Mar. 10 MANHATTAN East Midtown $275,000 300 East 54th Street (Connaught Tower) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hour doorman, dining room, river view, health club; maintenance $1,161, 80% tax-deductible (Broker: S. W.

LEAD: China and Israel have exchanged unofficial liaison offices to coordinate the growing contacts between them, but diplomats and Chinese officials say Beijing is very unlikely to grant diplomatic recognition to Israel anytime soon.

LEAD: In rented quarters here in a nondescript office park on the northern outskirts of Atlanta, Mickey A. Hall is busy living out his own version of ''Field of Dreams,'' the movie about a farmer who builds a baseball stadium in his cornfields in response to an inner voice.

LEAD: When Mephistopheles shows up wearing a gold Rolex he's truly a creature for our age. Meet the yuppie devil: relaxed, assured, the very model of casual elegance even if he has no visible means of support. He loves risks, particularly if they're being taken by others. He loves comfort, especially comfort of the high-tech, high-gloss kind.

LEAD: Rosario Castellanos took the title of her play ''El Eterno Femenino'' from Goethe, but nothing else. ''The eternal feminine leads us on,'' the German poet says at the end of ''Faust.'' To the Mexican novelist and poet, this famous tag line was obviously something of a joke, perhaps a bitter one, and her dark comedy supplies a feminist corrective to women's history.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The engagement of Nancy Porter Gilbert to Kenneth Kimball Holland has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Frederick A. Gilbert of Osterville, Mass. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: Li Zhen, a veteran of the Long March and the first woman to become a general in China, died on March 11, China Daily said today. She was 83 years old.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fisher Shearman Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Nicole Dolores Shearman to Nicholas George Fluehr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David George Fluehr of Carmel, Calif. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Charles P. Smyth, a chemist on the Princeton University faculty for more than 40 years, died on March 18 at his home in Bozeman, Mont. He was 94 years old.
LEAD: The Record Notes column last Sunday misidentified the company for which Daniel Barenboim recorded Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. The label is Erato.

LEAD: Bowers and Merena, Inc. of Wolfeboro, N. H. will hold an auction Wednesday through Saturday at the Vista International Hotel, 3 World Trade Center, New York City. Colonial-era paper money and copper coins, tiny California fractional gold pieces, Hard Times tokens and the ''king of Canadian coins'' - a 1921 half-dollar are just a few of the many incredible coins to be sold.

LEAD: The Argentine Supreme Court has rejected all appeals and ordered that Josef Schwammberger, an accused Nazi war criminal, be extradited to West Germany. Mr. Schwammberger was arrested more than two years ago on a ranch in Cordoba province.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently shepherded 100 rolls of 35-millimeter film across more than 25,000 miles of the Far East where our worst enemies were a series of high-powered X-ray machines and a handful of inquisitive baggage examiners. Some machines carried the false assurance: ''X-Ray Safe,'' and every examiner politely and firmly said, ''This machine will not damage your film.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Hagerty of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Tobin Hagerty, to Scott Drew Carroll, a son of Valerie Carroll of Peekskill, N.Y., and the late Donald P. Carroll. The wedding is to be next year.

LEAD: Carole Rose Bernstein, a daughter of Irene Bernstein of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Alan Bernstein, and Dr. Neil David Herbsman, a son of Dr. Horace Herbsman of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Brenda Herbsman, have announced their engagement. A December wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: May wedding plans for Kimberly Michelle Rosso and Michael Peter Morovich, a son of Ann Morovich of Far Rockaway, Queens, and the late John Morovich, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Rosso of Manhasset, L.I.

LEAD: THEY SAY GOOD BURGUNDY IS hard to find these days. Maybe so. But a Burgundy-lover wandering around the wine shops in New York City recently would have had no trouble finding some really superb wines. How about a 1985 Grands-Echezeaux or a 1985 Beaune Greves or a 1986 Richebourg or a 1985 Clos de la Roche or a 1986 Le Montrachet or perhaps even a 1987 Corton
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) A professor's past association with Vietnamese terrorists catches up with him, with dramatic consequences. 2 2 5 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO!
LEAD: CITIZENS in New Jersey know what unplanned growth will bring: a blighted environment, gridlock in farm country, cities in deeper decay, communities that have lost their sense of place.
LEAD: ENCLOSED IS AN article from The Houston Post of Feb. 12,'' writes Andrew Hero, the kind of specific citator that lexicographers like, ''which uses the expression tickety-boo.''
LEAD: Change in Co-op Shares
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It is so rare that the press pays any attention to the need for schools to promote positive self-esteem in children that one hesitates to criticize the well-meaning article [''How 'Magic Circles' Build Self-Esteem,'' Feb. 18] .
LEAD: The strike by workers at 11 Hawaii hotels ended today when the sides agreed to a tentative five-year contract that will achieve pay parity with hotel workers on the mainland, officials said.

LEAD: Deborah Clare Wise and Brooke Unger were married yesterday at the Sudbury Registry in Suffolk, England, by Doreen Capon, the superintendent registrar. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen George Wise of Houghton Hall in Cavendish, Suffolk. Her husband is a son of Prof. Irwin Unger of New York and the late Bernate
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''I come from a small Midwestern town, and this only happened in places like Los Angeles or Dallas or New York or Chicago. I was from Iowa. I had never given it a thought. But now I'm going to do my damnedest to keep it from happening to another woman.'' - Nancy Ziegenmeyer of Grinnell, Iowa, speaking of rape.

LEAD: I am responding to Darren Kazimir's letter analyzing the basketball skills of those ''older guys'' (About Men: ''What Do You Call an Aging Hoopster,'' by Erich Rupprecht, Feb. 4). As the wife of a 41-year-old die-hard lunch-hour basketball player, I see my husband as a competitive sportsman with a fervor for basketball bordering on a religious experience.

LEAD: For years, California bankers have been bracing for the second California gold rush. Come next January, banks from other states can expand into the state's huge and lucrative market. And bankers in the state have feared that New York giants like Citicorp, Chase and Chemical would swoop in and buy large California banks, creating continent-spanning empires.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Being saved by the bell is one thing. What happened in New Jersey Friday night was downright ridiculous. Indeed, after Bobby Czyz won a unanimous decision from Uriah Grant in a light heavyweight fight in Atlantic City, the biggest question was whether the bout had been a boxing match or an episode of ''The Gong Show.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Alexandra Sargent to Theodore John Corcoran, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Corcoran of Somers, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Diana Woods Sargent of Penllyn, Pa., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Hugh Alexander Anderson Sargent of Gywnedd Valley, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: At Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Diane L. Rodolitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Rodolitz of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Alan J. Ransenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Ransenberg of Skokie, Ill. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal and Cantor Tibor Kelen officiated.

LEAD: The engagement of Marianne McLoughlin to John Michael Marquardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Marquardt of Glencoe, Ill., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. McLoughlin of Rye, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: He has won 21 Professional Bowling Association championships, not to mention more money, $1.4 million, than any other P.B.A. bowler, so it should come as no surprise that Marshall Holman has been elected to the P.B.A's Hall of Fame in Akron, Ohio.

LEAD: Sheila A. Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Carey Jr. of Locust, N.J., was married in San Francisco yesterday to Parker S. Bryan, a son of Carleton F. Bryan of San Francisco and the late Carol P. Bryan. C. Zook Sutton, a retired judge of Alameda County (Calif.) Superior Court, officiated at the Pacific Union Club.

LEAD: As more free markets open in Eastern Europe, progress continues on the Pacific rim and Europe moves toward economic unification in 1992, Purdue is striving to keep pace by adopting curriculum changes that will internationalize the outlook and training of its students.
LEAD: The engagement of Rita Caviglia to Robert White Gadsden has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Eugene John Caviglia of Montauk, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHAT happens when a family member dies abroad? Events after the deaths of Marver and Sheva Bernstein, two of the four Americans who were among the 17 people who died in the Heliopolis Sheraton fire in Cairo March 1, offer a case study of how the State Department responds to such incidents overseas and provide insights that people hope they will never need.

LEAD: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company offered two big works and a little one on Wednesday night at the City Center Theater (131 West 55th Street). Fifteen dancers swept across the stage in a repeat performance of Mr. Cunningham's recent ''Inventions.'' And 14 human figures were on view in this season's first performance of ''Field and Figures.
LEAD: International

LEAD: East Marion $1.5 million Rocky Point Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, patio, barn, 26 acres, 700-foot waterfront; taxes $7,700. Greenport $206,000 215 Fourth Street 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 100-year-old Dutch colonial; 2 parlors, wraparound porch, 2 barns, 0.75 acre; taxes $5,000.

LEAD: Loren Celia Hecker and Jeffrey Zane Taufield were married last evening at the Burden mansion in New York by Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein. The bride is the daughter of Wilma K. Hecker of New York and the late Marvin S. Hecker. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Robert S. Taufield of Englishtown, N.J., and the late Mr.

LEAD: Elizabeth Polk Guest, a patron of classical music in New York and Washington, died of a heart attack on Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 79 years old and lived in Islesboro, Maine, and Front Royal, Va.
LEAD: The article ''Adding Up the Costs of Changes at the Top'' in the same issue misidentified the creator of the film ''Railroad Turnbridge.'' It is the work of Richard Serra.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Rapid changes in New York's real estate market are leading to confusion among many home seekers: Is it better these days to buy or to rent, and what, and where, and even how?

LEAD: Nancy Ellen Haar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence M. Haar of Port Washington, L.I., was married last evening to Anthony Francis Buffa, a son of Betty M. Buffa of Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., and the late Sebastian A. Buffa. Rabbi Ramie Arian officiated at the Columns in Manhattan.
LEAD: The United States and Japan are making headway on trade disputes.
LEAD: In an effort to control costs, keep sponsors in Winston Cup racing and prevent the best-financed teams from taking over, Nascar has put a limit on private test sessions.

LEAD: After two days of student protests demanding that the University of California at Berkeley insure greater ethnic diversity of students, faculty, staff and curriculum, university administrators have made several concessions on minority admissions.
LEAD: An East German newspaper today reported the discovery of mass graves of thousands of people, including civilians, who died at a former Soviet prison camp set up after World War II.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry L. Mullins of Lynchburg, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Lee Mullins to Jonathan Philip Steinberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Steinberg of Westport, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: The engagement of Kyle Kathleen Woodward to Richard Carl Savarese has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Woodward of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The wedding is to take place in June.
LEAD: When George Steinbrenner initially encountered Howard Spira, the Yankees' owner seemed only too eager to hear what the man on the other end of the telephone had to say about Dave Winfield.
LEAD: PERCY AND THE FIVE HOUSES By Else Holmelund Minarik. Illustrated by James Stevenson. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Cinema Studio, a small two-screen movie house near Lincoln Center that has attracted a loyal following with a mix of foreign and offbeat first-run films for 30 years, will close its doors soon - perhaps as early as Thursday.

LEAD: THREE small bus lines, serving 7,000 riders a month in the Danbury, Middletown and Windham areas, could stop running as early as June 30, unless the state agrees to pay about $238,000 a year in subsidies to keep them going.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I DISCOVERED NATALIA Ginzburg in 1971. I was in Florence; my friend and I, having just graduated from college, were doing the contemporary version of the grand tour: a trip around Europe carrying backpacks, hitchhiking, staying in cheap pensiones. I decided that I should buy an Italian book; I went into a bookstore and my eye fell on Natalia Ginzburg's Le piccole virtu.
LEAD: As if enough unpleasantries were not already associated with the month of April - showers, taxes and fools - a stock market forecaster in Chicago has added another: losses.

LEAD: The stars of black charity galas now come not only from the worlds of sports, entertainment and politics. Increasingly black corporate executives, entrepreneurs and heads of minority-owned businesses are turning heads in the ballrooms where elegantly dressed couples dine and dance for causes.

LEAD: Senate 1. Clean Air Act: Vote to kill an amendment to a compromise bill to reduce air pollution that would have added, among other things, a new and stricter round of auto emission controls to the measure that White House and Senate negotiators had worked out. Approved 52 to 46, March 20.
LEAD: The Federal Centers for Disease Control has halted imports by three of the nation's largest monkey dealers because of concerns about a spreading virus.

LEAD: The battle in the jungle is doomed from the outset as again the Bush Administration -- like its predessors -- ignores a basic tenet of economics: if there is no demand, there will be no need for supply (''In the Cocaine War, the Jungle Is Winning,'' by Michael Massing, March 4). The produce of the jungles in South America is feeding what the article refers to as ''the nation's immense, insatiable habit.

LEAD: Mr. Weisman glorified Puerto Rico's independence movement and implied that this option is the only one that will leave Puerto Ricans with dignity. He has forsaken Puerto Rico's political reality. When Puerto Ricans talk of ''el pais,'' (the country), the vast majority refer to our people, not a nation-state.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An article on March 18 about a horse cooperative in South Salem, N.Y., incorrectly described its rings. There will be four indoors and one outdoors.
LEAD: Dawn Staley scored 6 of Virginia's 9 overtime points as the Cavaliers beat Tennessee today, 79-75, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I East Regional final.

LEAD: At a time when receding Soviet military power suggests that hundreds of billions of dollars will be cut from the Pentagon budget in this decade, the Bush Administration and Congress are so absorbed in the politics of the moment that neither has begun to develop a strategy for using the money.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Namibia misstated the starting date of the war of independence there. The war, which ended in 1989, began in 1966, not 1986.
LEAD: There can be little doubt that bridge is the ideal game for those with physical handicaps. The tournament world readily adapts to accommodate them.

LEAD: Radiation technicians will go on strike Monday at 38 nuclear power plants that have closed down for refueling, according to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, which is seeking recognition as the workers' bargaining agent.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: It's a safe bet that when Alviero Martini arrived at Kennedy International Airport from Italy recently, he had more bags than any other traveler. He was carrying dozens of samples of his new luggage collection, and you might say it stopped traffic. ''Everyone wanted to know where I got it,'' he reported with glee.

LEAD: ANYONE who bought a cooperative apartment in a New York City conversion in the last few years probably assumed that the shareholders would quickly take over control of the board of directors and the building from the sponsor.
LEAD: The complex nature of the debt agreement negotiated between Mexico and its creditor banks last month has led to some confusion regarding its implications for Mexico's economy.
LEAD: Out of the corner of my eye, I catch the morning's headline: ''Baseball Settles Contract.''

LEAD: Near the end of his first set on Monday at the Bottom Line, the English saxophonist Courtney Pine silenced his backup trio and performed a tour de force. Using circular breathing to play nonstop, he reeled off hyperfast arpeggios, John Coltrane's ''sheets of sound'' technique, to create a thick, pulsating, slowly changing drone that went on and on - at first stubbornly, then with its own unearthly timing.

LEAD: MY husband, John, and I and two of our sons, Ian, who's 23, and Kit, who's 20, recently returned from two weeks spent investigating a canyon. Not the Grand Canyon, but the canyon that separates their generation from ours; we did our exploring while on a trip to England and Scotland, but it's the canyon I'll remember when Moffatt and Edinburgh, Ironbridge and Kings have faded.

LEAD: LOOSE JAM. By Wayne Wilson. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Poor Henry Brown. Standing on his redwood porch in yuppified Morro Bay, Calif., this Vietnam veteran, sometime guitarist, record-store manager and reluctant hero of Wayne Wilson's ''Loose Jam'' sees his old Army buddy Miles Duckworth coming right for him.

LEAD: Coach Gene Keady of Purdue has acknowledged in a letter to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I basketball committee that he made inappropriate comments after Purdue's elimination from the N.C.A.A. tournament last Sunday.

LEAD: To the Editor: What you told F. W. B. of Boseman, Mont., about finding tennis courts in Italy (Q & A, March 11) was all well and good; tennis clubs are listed in the telephone directory. But there is another, quite simple way to find out if a hotel or resort has a tennis court: look for the symbol (crossed tennis racquets) in the Michelin red guide to Italy.

LEAD: It began with a half-dozen ''toolies'' fastened on a dream. There was the understanding they would be set free of the ''mucky-mucks.'' And the inspirational spirit was a plucky man named James D. Stryker, whom colleagues call the Strykeforce, as if he were a comic-strip superhero of business.

LEAD: Census questionnaires are arriving in households across the nation this month, ready to collect bits of personal information that will send representatives to Washington, reveal new markets to businesses and teach Americans a little more about themselves.

LEAD: LISTENING to Nelson Mandela chastising Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d last week for deciding to meet with President F. W. de Klerk, it was easy to wonder whether anything had really changed in the debate over American policy toward South Africa.

LEAD: Italy's national television network, which will serve as the host broadcasting company for the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy this year, has developed what could be the ultimate officiating aid, a sophisticated replay system that simulates any conceivable camera angle and works within seconds.

LEAD: Some 400 Vanderbilt University undergraduates are on a three-week regimen of low-fat, low-sodium and high-fiber foods intended to make them healthier and wiser - and perhaps a trifle wealthier, too.

LEAD: New York City plans to add hundreds of millions of gallons daily to its water supply - from the polluted Hudson River (''The Drink of Millions,'' by Elizabeth Kolbert, March 4). The plan relies on the Army Corps of Engineers High Flow Skimming Project.

LEAD: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Kathryn Ann Kamerschen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Kamerschen of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Edward James Streator 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Streator Jr. of London. The Revs. Terence L. Elsberry and John C. Harper performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Congratulations to Cindy and Joe Bogan for their compassionate aid to wildlife (''Couple's 2d Career Is Caring for Wildlife,'' Feb. 18). Ocean County has its own dedicated wildlife rehabilitators in the persons of Virginia and Arne Andresen of Toms River, who have been restoring the health of all manner of wild creatures for 17 years.
LEAD: WHITE PLAINS
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On the eve of the Southeast Regional final matching Minnesota and Georgia Tech for the right to go to the Final Four, a team that won't be going to Denver next weekend was still smarting today over a play from Friday night's game.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about corporate health and fitness programs misstated the number of workers participating at the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. It is 97,000, not 70,000.

LEAD: I STRAIGHTENED UP from my weeding as the frenzied mutterings of anger reached me from the house. My muscles tightened. The screams were so muffled I could barely hear them. ''Get away from me, you filthy slut. Leave me alone!''

LEAD: Cross-Country Jennings Captures Title: Lynn Jennings of the United States won the women's senior race yesterday at the world championships in Aix-les-Bains, France. Jennings, a 29-year-old from Newmarket, N.H., covered the 3.6-mile course in 19 minutes 21 seconds to win by more than 50 yards.

LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union are increasing foreign arms sales in advance of major new agreements to slash the level of conventional forces in Europe, American officials and arms industry executives say.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Al Amir

LEAD: Dried beans, peas and lentils are the trend-setting foods of the 90's, appearing on menus where nutrition and taste meet. One big drawback is that they take so long to cook. An alternative is canned beans, and as canned foods go they are among the best. And while lentils do not come in cans, they do come in more than one color.

LEAD: ''I'm all for change and variety,'' says the guitarist and lutenist Julian Bream. ''Your experience of life is to a large part distilled into your performing. As you grow older, you concentrate on aspects of music that you perhaps only touched on earlier.''
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

LEAD: Orange balloons wandered around Carnegie-Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus this month, signaling the celebration of International Women's Day. The balloons, provided by the Carnegie-Mellon Women's Center, were distributed to passers-by - female passers-by that is. Men who wanted balloons were refused.

LEAD: ''One of the major missions of a cinematographer today,'' says Allen Daviau, the cinematographer Steven Spielberg entrusted with the filming of the fabulous ''E. T.'' ''is guiding the marriage of video and film technology.'' Mr. Daviau's statement reflects the fact that nowadays movies are seen far more frequently on the home television screen than in the theater.

LEAD: Lanky and bespectacled, his hair falling in his eyes and with a scraggly mustache, Charly Garcia looks more like a distracted graduate student than a rock star. But in Argentina, he has been a major figure in rock for nearly two decades as a member of two leading groups, Sui Generis and Seru Giran, and as a band leader since 1982.

LEAD: Elliott S. M. Gatner, who retired in 1981 from Long Island University after helping to shape that institution in a 45-year career as a history professor, librarian and administrator, died of lung cancer on Friday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Bellerose,

LEAD: AN OAK SPRING SYLVA A Selection of the Rare Books on Trees in the Oak Spring Garden Library. By Sandra Raphael. Illustrated. 147 pp. Upperville, Va.: Oak Spring Garden Library. Distributed by Yale University Press. $40.
LEAD: Only at the very end, and in excruciatingly small type is there an acknowledgment of the persnicketiness of the dirty big job.

LEAD: As Puerto Rico's only United States Representative, I closely read your article on Puerto Rico's political status. The issue is as complicated and many-layered as Alan Weisman tries to present in his piece, but a few of his observations provoke raised eyebrows among the veterans of this debate over statehood, independence or commonwealth (which

LEAD: After passing cardiovascular tests performed on Friday in Atlanta, Kal Daniels was given permission to participate in full spring drills with the Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday in Vero Beach, Fla.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was shocked at the use of the word schizophrenia regarding a divided Berlin (Travel, Feb. 25). Multiple personality disorder would be the correct phrase - several different personalities.
LEAD: When Ellen Ahlgren heard that thousands of babies infected with the AIDS virus were living out their short lives in cold and sterile hospital cribs, she decided to make them some quilts.

LEAD: THE early buyers in new suburban housing developments usually look forward to the day when construction stops and the bulldozers are silent. LEAD: In this city of rapid political change and some of the foulest air, water and soil in Poland, a former farmer has moved into a local palace, pledging that the fight against the filth has begun.

LEAD: AT first I blame the bed for my morning stiffness, for the pain in my lower back. The bed is old, the mattress soft. The box spring broke when we moved into this house several years ago. ''It's got to be the bed; look how long we've had it,'' I say to my wife.

LEAD: When Libya's poison-gas plant burned down last week, many people were relieved. Instead, they should have been horrified - just as they were by the recent revelations that Czechoslovakia's ousted Communist Government had shipped 1,000 tons of lethal Semtex explosives to Libya.

LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate fell to 7.5 percent in February from 7.7 percent in January, but the rate is expected to move higher in coming months, the Government said Friday. The retail price index rose sixth-tenths of 1 percent in February from January, the Central Statistical Office said. It said the March figures would probably be raised by increases in mortgage rates and in excise duties announced in the new budget.

LEAD: The AquaJogger, which is made of a foam material, fits securely around the waist by adjusting a strap of rubberized elastic webbing. The product is not a flotation device. With your legs and arms suspended in water, you are able to simulate any activity that might be part of a fitness routine on land.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The savings industry had its worst year ever in 1989, with losses soaring to $19.2 billion, regulators said. Although a record loss had been expected, the amount surprised experts. Indeed, losses from operations for 485 troubled institutions amounted to $2.6 billion in the fourth quarter, equivalent to a taxpayer loss of $29 million a day as long as the institutions stayed open in that period.
LEAD: Dr. Benjamin Morton Siegel, a scientist and educator, died on Thursday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Sarasota.

LEAD: John Dexter, a leading English director of theater and opera, died of heart failure in a London hospital on Friday. He was 64 years old. Mr. Dexter, who won two Tony Awards, was known for the sweep of his directorial imagination with contemporary plays as well as with classics. One of a corps of directors who in the late 1950's and early 60's led the Royal Court Theater into the arena of new and venturesome plays, he was closely identified with the early work of Arnold Wesker.

LEAD: Copper prices plunged yesterday even though there is a growing global shortage of the important industrial metal.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the causes of death for the 87 victims of the fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx misidentified the director of the trauma center at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He is Dr. Roger Yurt.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers placed bids on $10 billion worth of new two-year notes - the only real activity of the day.

LEAD: A RETAILING phenomenon that has grown to more than 500 stores but lacks a Manhattan outlet, Toys ''R'' Us Inc., has leased most of four floors in Herald Center, the retail complex opposite Macy's that has been dogged by problems since opening six years ago.

LEAD: Six more underclassmen, including the running back Reggie Cobb of Tennessee, have been cleared for the N.F.L. draft, bringing to 28 the number of non-seniors who will be included in the April 22 selections. Cobb, who was suspended from his college team last fall after failing a drug test for the third time, was one of four running backs in the group approved since last Friday, the cutoff date for applying.

Uncomfortably often, it is technology, not practice, that makes perfect.

LEAD: LAST fall, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art announced plans to stay open late on Friday and Saturday evenings instead of Tuesdays, it seemed that another well-established tradition was being needlessly tinkered with; it wasn't broken, so why fix it? How could a museum hope to compete for attention on weekend evenings, hours already so flooded with entertainment options?

The mill, the Golden State Newsprint Company in Pomona, Calif., also operates 10 recycling centers.

Bruins Take the Adams Title The Boston Bruins secured the Adams Division title and clinched the league's best record as well yesterday as Craig Janney's goal with 3 minutes 9 seconds left gave them a 3-2 victory over the Hartford Whalers in Boston. LEAD: German unity might seem to be the stuff of right-wing dreams. In fact, it has proved something of a nightmare for the far-right Republican Party.

LEAD: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would remove the word ''degradable'' from boxes of its Hefty plastic trash bags. In doing so, it is apparently bowing to demands from environmental groups and the threat of legal action by the attorneys general of eight states.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 506 money market mutual funds decreased by $522.1 million, to $391.62 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 158 institutional funds decreased by $603.7 million, to $91.39 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were up by $495.6 million, to $133.87 billion.

LEAD: A report that 146 peasants from Yunnan Province on China's southwest border used dirty drug needles and infected themselves with the AIDS virus has sent shivers throughout China.

LEAD: In the foreground, New York leaders are battling over the state's next budget. But meanwhile, they are finally beginning to respond to criticism of the sloppy fiscal practices that have helped put the state into its fiscal morass. In what amounts to an admission of guilt, politicians of both parties concede that they've let the state get deeply into debt, and want to borrow enough to retire all or part of an accumulated deficit that's reached nearly $5 billion - a record high.

LEAD: ''Most of the things that are likely to help solve the long-term care problem are being tried in some pilot project somewhere, but we're really still at the very beginning.'' So said Dr. Burton Reifler of Winston-Salem, N.C., the operator of a pilot project, in the four-part New York Times series on long-term care that concludes today.

LEAD: Seven months after voters approved a new system for electing the City Council, a Federal judge has ordered that another plan be drawn within 30 days to offer better representation to black and Hispanic people. He also ordered new elections as soon as possible but set no date.
LEAD: The American League yesterday rescheduled the 41 games postponed by the 32-day lockout and set four of them for July 11, the day after the All-Star Game, which is traditionally an off day.
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about money market funds misidentified the distributor of Evergreen Tax-Exempt Fund. It is the Evergreen Asset Management Corporation.

LEAD: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts today applauded the decision of a Cincinnati museum to seek a ruling from the courts on whether the sexually explicit photography of Robert Mapplethorpe is obscene.

LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave tentative support today to Treasury Department efforts to increase the regulatory power of the Securities and Exchange Commission and reduce that of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: * Burlington Industries, Greensboro, N.C., a subsidiary of Burlington Holdings Inc., New York, announced the resignation of Richard Altman, president of its Burlington Knitted Fabrics division. Frank S. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive of Burlington Industries, will assume Mr. Altman's responsibilities.

LEAD: George A. McKenna, a retired battalion chief in the New York City Fire Department and a former manager of security at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Sunday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Holliswood, Queens.

LEAD: The difference between ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' the live-action film and ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' the animated television show can be measured in whiskers, matted fur, beady eyes and desiccated paws. These belong to Splinter, the wise old rodent who is the mentor of the four title characters, a debonair fellow in the animated version and a thoroughly disgusting one here.

LEAD: The ice hockey program at SUNY-Plattsburgh, a Division III school, has been put on probation for two years for rules violations that the National Collegiate Athletic Association said included having athletes live at the homes of boosters.

LEAD: New York's highest court today became the first in any state to rule that lawyers for criminal defendants cannot dismiss prospective jurors because of their race. In issuing the unanimous decision, the court also upheld the manslaughter convictions of three young men in the Howard Beach racial attack case.
LEAD: Just two years after it was started, 7 Days magazine, which has amassed a small but dedicated following among Manhattan's trend-setters, is up for sale.

LEAD: The outcome of the Lockheed Corporation's proxy fight with a group headed by Harold C. Simmons may not be known for several weeks, but it became clear at the company's annual meeting today that institutional shareholders have already become winners in the battle.

LEAD: Poland is preparing for free elections for a completely reorganized local government that Solidarity supporters hope will break the grip of the Communist Party bureaucracy throughout the country.
LEAD: Data from weather satellites show no evidence of global warming in the 1980's, scientists say, but it will take at least another decade of measurements to draw a firm conclusion.

LEAD: The three Kentucky Derby preps tomorrow might better be called Derby-prep preps. Each is a warm-up for a more significant prep race under similar conditions next month that is likely to draw the same cast.

LEAD: The Northrop Corporation, which last month pleaded guilty to criminal fraud charges, was sued today by the Justice Department for more than $5 million in related civil damages involving false test results on jet parts.

LEAD: The University of Colorado announced yesterday that Joe Harrington of Long Beach State had been hired as head coach. LEAD: Rickie Lee Jones gets away with enough quirks to sink half a dozen other singer-songwriters. LEAD: A leading pro-independence militant was killed in fighting in Jammu and Kashmir today and 10 other people died in a separate incident, the authorities said. The deaths struck a blow against the powerful movement that has swept the region for more than four months.

LEAD: In an impassioned closing argument, the chief prosecutor in the trial of John M. Poindexter said today that the Government had presented ''overwhelming evidence'' against the former national security adviser, justifying a verdict of guilty on all five criminal charges.

LEAD: Rival Christian forces fought pitched battles for control of Lebanon's Christian heartland today, leaving at least 26 people dead, as a rickety truce between the factions finally fell apart, the police said.

LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their February meeting to continue the policy aimed at maintaining high interest rates to keep inflationary pressures under control, according to minutes released today.

LEAD: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Thursday about the Colorado-Ute Electric Association's intention to file for bankruptcy protection misstated its financial condition. LEAD: Arthur Levitt Jr., the former head of the American Stock Exchange, was appointed chairman of the New York City Public Development Corporation yesterday. The quasi-public organization is responsible for directing the city's commercical, industrial and waterfront development.

LEAD: Japan Air Lines has placed 10 orders and 10 options with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to buy new MD-11 jetliners from the company. The deal is worth about $2 billion. J.A.L. is one of 30 customers that have placed a total of 340 orders and other commitments for the MD-11, which replaces McDonnell Douglas's DC-10.

LEAD: In the high-wire act that most people call Italy, where Government disaster is often only a misstep away, doomsday scenarios are in full bloom for the World Cup soccer finals that will be held here in June.

LEAD: Jeffrey A. LEAD: The mood was for the most part light and even frivolous on Tuesday when the Fifth Annual Morningside Dance Festival presented its second showcase program at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

LEAD: Corn farmers intend to increase plantings this spring to 74.8 million acres, up 4 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said today.
